The <literal role="func">EXTRACT()</literal> function uses the
          same kinds of <replaceable>unit</replaceable> specifiers as
          <literal role="func">DATE_ADD()</literal> or
          <literal role="func">DATE_SUB()</literal>, but extracts parts
          from the date rather than performing date arithmetic. For
          information on the <replaceable>unit</replaceable> argument,
          see <xref linkend="temporal-intervals" />.

Given a day number <replaceable>N</replaceable>, returns a
          <literal role="type">DATE</literal> value.

Returns a representation of the
          <replaceable>unix_timestamp</replaceable> argument as a value
          in <replaceable>'YYYY-MM-DD hh:mm:ss'</replaceable> or
          <replaceable>YYYYMMDDhhmmss.uuuuuu</replaceable> format,
          depending on whether the function is used in a string or
          numeric context. <replaceable>unix_timestamp</replaceable> is
          an internal timestamp value representing seconds since
          <literal>'1970-01-01 00:00:00'</literal> UTC, such as produced
          by the <literal role="func">UNIX_TIMESTAMP()</literal>
          function.

The return value is expressed in the session time zone.
          (Clients can set the session time zone as described in
          <xref linkend="time-zone-support" />.) The
          <replaceable>format</replaceable> string, if given, is used to
          format the result the same way as described in the entry for
          the <literal role="func">DATE_FORMAT()</literal> function.

Returns a format string. This function is useful in
          combination with the
          <literal role="func">DATE_FORMAT()</literal> and the
          <literal role="func">STR_TO_DATE()</literal> functions.

Returns the hour for <replaceable>time</replaceable>. The
          range of the return value is <literal>0</literal> to
          <literal>23</literal> for time-of-day values. However, the
          range of <literal role="type">TIME</literal> values actually
          is much larger, so <literal>HOUR</literal> can return values
          greater than <literal>23</literal>.

Takes a date or datetime value and returns the corresponding
          value for the last day of the month. Returns
          <literal>NULL</literal> if the argument is invalid.

<literal role="func">LOCALTIME</literal> and
          <literal role="func">LOCALTIME()</literal> are synonyms for
          <literal role="func">NOW()</literal>.

<literal role="func">LOCALTIMESTAMP</literal> and
          <literal role="func">LOCALTIMESTAMP()</literal> are synonyms
          for <literal role="func">NOW()</literal>.

Returns a date, given year and day-of-year values.
          <replaceable>dayofyear</replaceable> must be greater than 0 or
          the result is <literal>NULL</literal>.

Returns a time value calculated from the
          <replaceable>hour</replaceable>,
          <replaceable>minute</replaceable>, and
          <replaceable>second</replaceable> arguments.

The <replaceable>second</replaceable> argument can have a
          fractional part.

Returns the microseconds from the time or datetime expression
          <replaceable>expr</replaceable> as a number in the range from
          <literal>0</literal> to <literal>999999</literal>.

Returns the minute for <replaceable>time</replaceable>, in the
          range <literal>0</literal> to <literal>59</literal>.

Returns the month for <replaceable>date</replaceable>, in the
          range <literal>1</literal> to <literal>12</literal> for
          January to December, or <literal>0</literal> for dates such as
          <literal>'0000-00-00'</literal> or
          <literal>'2008-00-00'</literal> that have a zero month part.

Returns the full name of the month for
          <replaceable>date</replaceable>. The language used for the
          name is controlled by the value of the
          <literal role="sysvar">lc_time_names</literal> system variable
          (<xref linkend="locale-support" />).

Returns the current date and time as a value in
          <replaceable>'YYYY-MM-DD hh:mm:ss'</replaceable> or
          <replaceable>YYYYMMDDhhmmss</replaceable> format, depending on
          whether the function is used in a string or numeric context.
          The value is expressed in the session time zone.

If the <replaceable>fsp</replaceable> argument is given to
          specify a fractional seconds precision from 0 to 6, the return
          value includes a fractional seconds part of that many digits.

Adds <replaceable>N</replaceable> months to period
          <replaceable>P</replaceable> (in the format
          <replaceable>YYMM</replaceable> or
          <replaceable>YYYYMM</replaceable>). Returns a value in the
          format <replaceable>YYYYMM</replaceable>.

Returns the number of months between periods
          <replaceable>P1</replaceable> and
          <replaceable>P2</replaceable>. <replaceable>P1</replaceable>
          and <replaceable>P2</replaceable> should be in the format
          <replaceable>YYMM</replaceable> or
          <replaceable>YYYYMM</replaceable>. Note that the period
          arguments <replaceable>P1</replaceable> and
          <replaceable>P2</replaceable> are <emphasis>not</emphasis>
          date values.

Returns the quarter of the year for
          <replaceable>date</replaceable>, in the range
          <literal>1</literal> to <literal>4</literal>.

Returns the second for <replaceable>time</replaceable>, in the
          range <literal>0</literal> to <literal>59</literal>.

Returns the <replaceable>seconds</replaceable> argument,
          converted to hours, minutes, and seconds, as a
          <literal role="type">TIME</literal> value. The range of the
          result is constrained to that of the
          <literal role="type">TIME</literal> data type. A warning
          occurs if the argument corresponds to a value outside that
          range.

This is the inverse of the
          <literal role="func">DATE_FORMAT()</literal> function. It
          takes a string <replaceable>str</replaceable> and a format
          string <replaceable>format</replaceable>.
          <literal role="func">STR_TO_DATE()</literal> returns a
          <literal role="type">DATETIME</literal> value if the format
          string contains both date and time parts, or a
          <literal role="type">DATE</literal> or
          <literal role="type">TIME</literal> value if the string
          contains only date or time parts. If the date, time, or
          datetime value extracted from <replaceable>str</replaceable>
          is illegal, <literal role="func">STR_TO_DATE()</literal>
          returns <literal>NULL</literal> and produces a warning.

The server scans <replaceable>str</replaceable> attempting to
          match <replaceable>format</replaceable> to it. The format
          string can contain literal characters and format specifiers
          beginning with <literal>%</literal>. Literal characters in
          <replaceable>format</replaceable> must match literally in
          <replaceable>str</replaceable>. Format specifiers in
          <replaceable>format</replaceable> must match a date or time
          part in <replaceable>str</replaceable>. For the specifiers
          that can be used in <replaceable>format</replaceable>, see the
          <literal role="func">DATE_FORMAT()</literal> function
          description.

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SELECT STR_TO_DATE('01,5,2013','%d,%m,%Y');</userinput>
        -> '2013-05-01'
mysql> <userinput>SELECT STR_TO_DATE('May 1, 2013','%M %d,%Y');</userinput>
        -> '2013-05-01'

description.para:
Scanning starts at the beginning of
          <replaceable>str</replaceable> and fails if
          <replaceable>format</replaceable> is found not to match. Extra
          characters at the end of <replaceable>str</replaceable> are
          ignored.

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SELECT STR_TO_DATE('a09:30:17','a%h:%i:%s');</userinput>
        -> '09:30:17'
mysql> <userinput>SELECT STR_TO_DATE('a09:30:17','%h:%i:%s');</userinput>
        -> NULL
mysql> <userinput>SELECT STR_TO_DATE('09:30:17a','%h:%i:%s');</userinput>
        -> '09:30:17'

description.para:
Unspecified date or time parts have a value of 0, so
          incompletely specified values in
          <replaceable>str</replaceable> produce a result with some or
          all parts set to 0:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SELECT STR_TO_DATE('abc','abc');</userinput>
        -> '0000-00-00'
mysql> <userinput>SELECT STR_TO_DATE('9','%m');</userinput>
        -> '0000-09-00'
mysql> <userinput>SELECT STR_TO_DATE('9','%s');</userinput>
        -> '00:00:09'

description.para:
When invoked with the <literal>INTERVAL</literal> form of the
          second argument, <literal role="func">SUBDATE()</literal> is a
          synonym for <literal role="func">DATE_SUB()</literal>. For
          information on the <literal>INTERVAL</literal>
          <replaceable>unit</replaceable> argument, see the discussion
          for <literal role="func">DATE_ADD()</literal>.

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SELECT DATE_SUB('2008-01-02', INTERVAL 31 DAY);</userinput>
        -> '2007-12-02'
mysql> <userinput>SELECT SUBDATE('2008-01-02', INTERVAL 31 DAY);</userinput>
        -> '2007-12-02'

description.para:
The second form enables the use of an integer value for
          <replaceable>days</replaceable>. In such cases, it is
          interpreted as the number of days to be subtracted from the
          date or datetime expression <replaceable>expr</replaceable>.

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SELECT SUBDATE('2008-01-02 12:00:00', 31);</userinput>
        -> '2007-12-02 12:00:00'

description.para:
<literal role="func">SUBTIME()</literal> returns
          <replaceable>expr1</replaceable> minus
          <replaceable>expr2</replaceable> expressed as a value in the
          same format as <replaceable>expr1</replaceable>.
          <replaceable>expr1</replaceable> is a time or datetime
          expression, and <replaceable>expr2</replaceable> is a time
          expression.

Returns the current date and time as a value in
          <replaceable>'YYYY-MM-DD hh:mm:ss'</replaceable> or
          <replaceable>YYYYMMDDhhmmss</replaceable> format, depending on
          whether the function is used in a string or numeric context.

If the <replaceable>fsp</replaceable> argument is given to
          specify a fractional seconds precision from 0 to 6, the return
          value includes a fractional seconds part of that many digits.

<literal role="func">SYSDATE()</literal> returns the time at
          which it executes. This differs from the behavior for
          <literal role="func">NOW()</literal>, which returns a constant
          time that indicates the time at which the statement began to
          execute. (Within a stored function or trigger,
          <literal role="func">NOW()</literal> returns the time at which
          the function or triggering statement began to execute.)

In addition, the <literal>SET TIMESTAMP</literal> statement
          affects the value returned by
          <literal role="func">NOW()</literal> but not by
          <literal role="func">SYSDATE()</literal>. This means that
          timestamp settings in the binary log have no effect on
          invocations of <literal role="func">SYSDATE()</literal>.

Because <literal role="func">SYSDATE()</literal> can return
          different values even within the same statement, and is not
          affected by <literal>SET TIMESTAMP</literal>, it is
          nondeterministic and therefore unsafe for replication if
          statement-based binary logging is used. If that is a problem,
          you can use row-based logging.

Alternatively, you can use the
          <option role="mysqld">--sysdate-is-now</option> option to
          cause <literal role="func">SYSDATE()</literal> to be an alias
          for <literal role="func">NOW()</literal>. This works if the
          option is used on both the master and the slave.

The nondeterministic nature of
          <literal role="func">SYSDATE()</literal> also means that
          indexes cannot be used for evaluating expressions that refer
          to it.

Extracts the time part of the time or datetime expression
          <replaceable>expr</replaceable> and returns it as a string.

<literal role="func">TIMEDIFF()</literal> returns
          <replaceable>expr1</replaceable> minus
          <replaceable>expr2</replaceable> expressed as a time value.
          <replaceable>expr1</replaceable> and
          <replaceable>expr2</replaceable> are time or date-and-time
          expressions, but both must be of the same type.

The result returned by <literal>TIMEDIFF()</literal> is
          limited to the range allowed for
          <literal role="type">TIME</literal> values. Alternatively, you
          can use either of the functions
          <literal role="func">TIMESTAMPDIFF()</literal> and
          <literal role="func">UNIX_TIMESTAMP()</literal>, both of which
          return integers.

With a single argument, this function returns the date or
          datetime expression <replaceable>expr</replaceable> as a
          datetime value. With two arguments, it adds the time
          expression <replaceable>expr2</replaceable> to the date or
          datetime expression <replaceable>expr1</replaceable> and
          returns the result as a datetime value.

Adds the integer expression
          <replaceable>interval</replaceable> to the date or datetime
          expression <replaceable>datetime_expr</replaceable>. The unit
          for <replaceable>interval</replaceable> is given by the
          <replaceable>unit</replaceable> argument, which should be one
          of the following values: <literal>MICROSECOND</literal>
          (microseconds), <literal>SECOND</literal>,
          <literal>MINUTE</literal>, <literal>HOUR</literal>,
          <literal>DAY</literal>, <literal>WEEK</literal>,
          <literal>MONTH</literal>, <literal>QUARTER</literal>, or
          <literal>YEAR</literal>.

The <replaceable>unit</replaceable> value may be specified
          using one of keywords as shown, or with a prefix of
          <literal>SQL_TSI_</literal>. For example,
          <literal>DAY</literal> and <literal>SQL_TSI_DAY</literal> both
          are legal.

Returns <replaceable>datetime_expr2</replaceable> minus
          <replaceable>datetime_expr1</replaceable>, where
          <replaceable>datetime_expr1</replaceable> and
          <replaceable>datetime_expr2</replaceable> are date or datetime
          expressions. One expression may be a date and the other a
          datetime; a date value is treated as a datetime having the
          time part <literal>'00:00:00'</literal> where necessary. The
          unit for the result (an integer) is given by the
          <replaceable>unit</replaceable> argument. The legal values for
          <replaceable>unit</replaceable> are the same as those listed
          in the description of the
          <literal role="func">TIMESTAMPADD()</literal> function.

This is used like the
          <literal role="func">DATE_FORMAT()</literal> function, but the
          <replaceable>format</replaceable> string may contain format
          specifiers only for hours, minutes, seconds, and microseconds.
          Other specifiers produce a <literal>NULL</literal> value or
          <literal>0</literal>.

Returns the <replaceable>time</replaceable> argument,
          converted to seconds.

Given a date <replaceable>date</replaceable>, returns a day
          number (the number of days since year 0).

Given a date or datetime <replaceable>expr</replaceable>,
          returns the number of seconds since the year 0. If
          <replaceable>expr</replaceable> is not a valid date or
          datetime value, returns <literal>NULL</literal>.

If <literal role="func">UNIX_TIMESTAMP()</literal> is called
          with no <replaceable>date</replaceable> argument, it returns a
          Unix timestamp representing seconds since <literal>'1970-01-01
          00:00:00'</literal> UTC.

If <literal role="func">UNIX_TIMESTAMP()</literal> is called
          with a <replaceable>date</replaceable> argument, it returns
          the value of the argument as seconds since
          <literal>'1970-01-01 00:00:00'</literal> UTC. The server
          interprets <replaceable>date</replaceable> as a value in the
          session time zone and converts it to an internal Unix
          timestamp value in UTC. (Clients can set the session time zone
          as described in <xref linkend="time-zone-support" />.) The
          <replaceable>date</replaceable> argument may be a
          <literal role="type">DATE</literal>,
          <literal role="type">DATETIME</literal>, or
          <literal role="type">TIMESTAMP</literal> string, or a number
          in <replaceable>YYMMDD</replaceable>,
          <replaceable>YYMMDDhhmmss</replaceable>,
          <replaceable>YYYYMMDD</replaceable>, or
          <replaceable>YYYYMMDDhhmmss</replaceable> format. If the
          argument includes a time part, it may optionally include a
          fractional seconds part.

The return value is an integer if no argument is given or the
          argument does not include a fractional seconds part, or
          <literal role="type">DECIMAL</literal> if an argument is given
          that includes a fractional seconds part.

When the <replaceable>date</replaceable> argument is a
          <literal role="type">TIMESTAMP</literal> column,
          <literal role="func">UNIX_TIMESTAMP()</literal> returns the
          internal timestamp value directly, with no implicit
          <quote>string-to-Unix-timestamp</quote> conversion.

The valid range of argument values is the same as for the
          <literal role="type">TIMESTAMP</literal> data type:
          <literal>'1970-01-01 00:00:01.000000'</literal> UTC to
          <literal>'2038-01-19 03:14:07.999999'</literal> UTC. If you
          pass an out-of-range date to
          <literal role="func">UNIX_TIMESTAMP()</literal>, it returns
          <literal>0</literal>.

Returns the current UTC date as a value in
          <replaceable>'YYYY-MM-DD'</replaceable> or
          <replaceable>YYYYMMDD</replaceable> format, depending on
          whether the function is used in a string or numeric context.

Returns the current UTC time as a value in
          <replaceable>'hh:mm:ss'</replaceable> or
          <replaceable>hhmmss</replaceable> format, depending on whether
          the function is used in a string or numeric context.

If the <replaceable>fsp</replaceable> argument is given to
          specify a fractional seconds precision from 0 to 6, the return
          value includes a fractional seconds part of that many digits.

Returns the current UTC date and time as a value in
          <replaceable>'YYYY-MM-DD hh:mm:ss'</replaceable> or
          <replaceable>YYYYMMDDhhmmss</replaceable> format, depending on
          whether the function is used in a string or numeric context.

If the <replaceable>fsp</replaceable> argument is given to
          specify a fractional seconds precision from 0 to 6, the return
          value includes a fractional seconds part of that many digits.

This function returns the week number for
          <replaceable>date</replaceable>. The two-argument form of
          <literal role="func">WEEK()</literal> enables you to specify
          whether the week starts on Sunday or Monday and whether the
          return value should be in the range from <literal>0</literal>
          to <literal>53</literal> or from <literal>1</literal> to
          <literal>53</literal>. If the <replaceable>mode</replaceable>
          argument is omitted, the value of the
          <literal role="sysvar">default_week_format</literal> system
          variable is used. See
          <xref linkend="server-system-variables" />.

Returns the weekday index for <replaceable>date</replaceable>
          (<literal>0</literal> = Monday, <literal>1</literal> =
          Tuesday, hellip <literal>6</literal> = Sunday).

Returns the calendar week of the date as a number in the range
          from <literal>1</literal> to <literal>53</literal>.
          <literal role="func">WEEKOFYEAR()</literal> is a compatibility
          function that is equivalent to
          <literal role="func">WEEK(<replaceable>date</replaceable>,3)</literal>.

Returns the year for <replaceable>date</replaceable>, in the
          range <literal>1000</literal> to <literal>9999</literal>, or
          <literal>0</literal> for the <quote>zero</quote> date.

Returns year and week for a date. The year in the result may
          be different from the year in the date argument for the first
          and the last week of the year.

The <replaceable>mode</replaceable> argument works exactly
          like the <replaceable>mode</replaceable> argument to
          <literal role="func">WEEK()</literal>. For the single-argument
          syntax, a <replaceable>mode</replaceable> value of 0 is used.
          Unlike <literal role="func">WEEK()</literal>, the value of
          <literal role="sysvar">default_week_format</literal> does not
          influence <literal role="func">YEARWEEK()</literal>.
MySQL has support for full-text indexing and searching:

itemizedlist.para:
A full-text index in MySQL is an index of type
          <literal>FULLTEXT</literal>.

Full-text indexes can be used only with
          <literal role="se">InnoDB</literal> or
          <literal role="se">MyISAM</literal> tables, and can be created
          only for <literal role="type">CHAR</literal>,
          <literal role="type">VARCHAR</literal>, or
          <literal role="type">TEXT</literal> columns.

<literal>MySQL</literal> provides a built-in full-text ngram
          parser that supports Chinese, Japanese, and Korean (CJK), and
          an installable MeCab full-text parser plugin for Japanese.
          Parsing differences are outlined in
          <xref linkend="fulltext-search-ngram" />, and
          <xref linkend="fulltext-search-mecab" />.

A <literal>FULLTEXT</literal> index definition can be given in
          the <literal role="stmt">CREATE TABLE</literal> statement when
          a table is created, or added later using
          <literal role="stmt">ALTER TABLE</literal> or
          <literal role="stmt">CREATE INDEX</literal>.

For large data sets, it is much faster to load your data into
          a table that has no <literal>FULLTEXT</literal> index and then
          create the index after that, than to load data into a table
          that has an existing <literal>FULLTEXT</literal> index.

description.para:
Full-text searching is performed using
      <literal role="func">MATCH() ... AGAINST</literal> syntax.
      <literal role="func">MATCH()</literal> takes a comma-separated
      list that names the columns to be searched.
      <literal>AGAINST</literal> takes a string to search for, and an
      optional modifier that indicates what type of search to perform.
      The search string must be a string value that is constant during
      query evaluation. This rules out, for example, a table column
      because that can differ for each row.
There are three types of full-text searches:

itemizedlist.para:
A natural language search interprets the search string as a
          phrase in natural human language (a phrase in free text).
          There are no special operators, with the exception of double
          quote (") characters. The stopword list applies. For more
          information about stopword lists, see
          <xref linkend="fulltext-stopwords" />.

Full-text searches are natural language searches if the
          <literal>IN NATURAL LANGUAGE MODE</literal> modifier is given
          or if no modifier is given. For more information, see
          <xref linkend="fulltext-natural-language" />.

A boolean search interprets the search string using the rules
          of a special query language. The string contains the words to
          search for. It can also contain operators that specify
          requirements such that a word must be present or absent in
          matching rows, or that it should be weighted higher or lower
          than usual. Certain common words (stopwords) are omitted from
          the search index and do not match if present in the search
          string. The <literal>IN BOOLEAN MODE</literal> modifier
          specifies a boolean search. For more information, see
          <xref linkend="fulltext-boolean" />.

A query expansion search is a modification of a natural
          language search. The search string is used to perform a
          natural language search. Then words from the most relevant
          rows returned by the search are added to the search string and
          the search is done again. The query returns the rows from the
          second search. The <literal>IN NATURAL LANGUAGE MODE WITH
          QUERY EXPANSION</literal> or <literal>WITH QUERY
          EXPANSION</literal> modifier specifies a query expansion
          search. For more information, see
          <xref linkend="fulltext-query-expansion" />.

syntax.programlisting:
>
<replaceable>search_modifier:</replaceable>
  {
       IN NATURAL LANGUAGE MODE
     | IN NATURAL LANGUAGE MODE WITH QUERY EXPANSION
     | IN BOOLEAN MODE
     | WITH QUERY EXPANSION
  }

description.para:
The <literal role="op">BINARY</literal> operator converts the
          expression to a binary string. A common use for
          <literal role="op">BINARY</literal> is to force a character
          string comparison to be done byte by byte rather than
          character by character, in effect becoming case-sensitive. The
          <literal role="op">BINARY</literal> operator also causes
          trailing spaces in comparisons to be significant.

The <literal role="func">CAST()</literal> function takes an
          expression of any type and produces a result value of the
          specified type, similar to
          <literal role="func">CONVERT()</literal>. For more
          information, see the description of
          <literal role="func">CONVERT()</literal>.

In MySQL 8.0.17 and later, <literal role="se">InnoDB</literal>
          allows the use of an additional <literal>ARRAY</literal>
          keyword for creating a multi-valued index on a
          <literal role="type">JSON</literal> array as part of
          <literal role="stmt">CREATE INDEX</literal>,
          <literal role="stmt">CREATE TABLE</literal>, and
          <literal role="stmt">ALTER TABLE</literal> statements.
          <literal>ARRAY</literal> is not supported except when used to
          create a multi-valued index in one of these statements, in
          which case it is required. The column being indexed must be a
          column of type <literal>JSON</literal>.
          (<literal role="func">CONVERT()</literal> does
          <emphasis>not</emphasis> support multi-valued index creation
          or the <literal>ARRAY</literal> keyword.) The
          <replaceable>type</replaceable> following the
          <literal>AS</literal> keyword may be any of the types
          supported by <literal>CAST()</literal>, with the exception of
          <literal>BINARY</literal> and <literal>JSON</literal>, which
          are not supported for this purpose.
          <xref linkend="create-index-multi-valued" />, provides syntax
          information and examples, as well as other relevant
          information.
<literal role="func">CAST()</literal> is standard SQL syntax.

The <literal role="func">CONVERT()</literal> function takes an
          expression of any type and produces a result value of the
          specified type.

Discussion of
          <literal role="func">CONVERT(<replaceable>expr</replaceable>,
          <replaceable>type</replaceable>)</literal> syntax here also
          applies to
          <literal role="func">CAST(<replaceable>expr</replaceable> AS
          <replaceable>type</replaceable>)</literal>, which is
          equivalent.

<literal role="func">CONVERT(... USING ...)</literal> is
          standard SQL syntax. The non-<literal>USING</literal> form of
          <literal role="func">CONVERT()</literal> is ODBC syntax.

<literal role="func">CONVERT()</literal> with
          <literal>USING</literal> converts data between different
          character sets. In MySQL, transcoding names are the same as
          the corresponding character set names. For example, this
          statement converts the string <literal>'abc'</literal> in the
          default character set to the corresponding string in the
          <literal>utf8</literal> character set:

description.programlisting:
>
SELECT CONVERT('abc' USING utf8);

description.para:
<literal role="func">CONVERT()</literal> without
          <literal>USING</literal> and
          <literal role="func">CAST()</literal> take an expression and a
          <replaceable>type</replaceable> value specifying the result
          type. These <replaceable>type</replaceable> values are
          permitted:

itemizedlist.para: <literal>BINARY[(<replaceable>N</replaceable>)]</literal>

Produces a string with the
              <literal role="type">BINARY</literal> data type. See
              <xref linkend="binary-varbinary" /> for a description of
              how this affects comparisons. If the optional length
              <replaceable>N</replaceable> is given,
              <literal>BINARY(<replaceable>N</replaceable>)</literal>
              causes the cast to use no more than
              <replaceable>N</replaceable> bytes of the argument. Values
              shorter than <replaceable>N</replaceable> bytes are padded
              with <literal>0x00</literal> bytes to a length of
              <replaceable>N</replaceable>.

<literal>CHAR[(<replaceable>N</replaceable>)]
              [<replaceable>charset_info</replaceable>]</literal>

Produces a string with the
              <literal role="type">CHAR</literal> data type. If the
              optional length <replaceable>N</replaceable> is given,
              <literal>CHAR(<replaceable>N</replaceable>)</literal>
              causes the cast to use no more than
              <replaceable>N</replaceable> characters of the argument.
              No padding occurs for values shorter than
              <replaceable>N</replaceable> characters.

With no <replaceable>charset_info</replaceable> clause,
              <literal>CHAR</literal> produces a string with the default
              character set. To specify the character set explicitly,
              these <replaceable>charset_info</replaceable> values are
              permitted:

<literal>CHARACTER SET
                  <replaceable>charset_name</replaceable></literal>:
                  Produces a string with the given character set.

<literal>ASCII</literal>: Shorthand for
                  <literal>CHARACTER SET latin1</literal>.

<literal>UNICODE</literal>: Shorthand for
                  <literal>CHARACTER SET ucs2</literal>.

In all cases, the string has the default collation for the
              character set.
<literal>DATE</literal>
Produces a <literal role="type">DATE</literal> value.
<literal>DATETIME</literal>
Produces a <literal role="type">DATETIME</literal> value.
<literal>DECIMAL[(<replaceable>M</replaceable>[,<replaceable>D</replaceable>])]</literal>

Produces a <literal role="type">DECIMAL</literal> value.
              If the optional <replaceable>M</replaceable> and
              <replaceable>D</replaceable> values are given, they
              specify the maximum number of digits (the precision) and
              the number of digits following the decimal point (the
              scale).
<literal>DOUBLE</literal>

Produces a <literal role="type">DOUBLE</literal> result.
              Added in MySQL 8.0.17.
FLOAT[(<replaceable>P</replaceable>)]

If the precision <replaceable>P</replaceable> is not
              specified, produces a result of type
              <literal role="type">FLOAT</literal>. If
              <replaceable>P</replaceable> is provided and 0 <= <
              <replaceable>P</replaceable> <= 24, the result is of
              type <literal>FLOAT</literal>. If 25 <=
              <replaceable>P</replaceable> <= 53, the result is of
              type <literal role="type">DOUBLE</literal>. If
              <replaceable>P</replaceable> < 0 or
              <replaceable>P</replaceable> > 53, an error is
              returned. Added in MySQL 8.0.17.
<literal>JSON</literal>

Produces a <literal role="type">JSON</literal> value. For
              details on the rules for conversion of values between
              <literal role="type">JSON</literal> and other types, see
              <xref linkend="json-comparison" />.
<literal>NCHAR[(<replaceable>N</replaceable>)]</literal>

Like <literal>CHAR</literal>, but produces a string with
              the national character set. See
              <xref linkend="charset-national" />.

Unlike <literal>CHAR</literal>, <literal>NCHAR</literal>
              does not permit trailing character set information to be
              specified.
<literal>REAL</literal>

Produces a result of type
              <literal role="type">REAL</literal>. This is actually
              <literal>FLOAT</literal> if
              <literal role="sql_mode">REAL_AS_FLOAT</literal> SQL mode
              is enabled; otherwise the result is of type
              <literal>DOUBLE</literal>.
<literal>SIGNED [INTEGER]</literal>
Produces a signed integer value.
<literal>TIME</literal>
Produces a <literal role="type">TIME</literal> value.
<literal>UNSIGNED [INTEGER]</literal>
Produces an unsigned integer value.

description.para:
<literal role="func">ExtractValue()</literal> takes two string
          arguments, a fragment of XML markup
          <replaceable>xml_frag</replaceable> and an XPath expression
          <replaceable>xpath_expr</replaceable> (also known as a
          <emphasis role="firstterm">locator</emphasis>); it returns the
          text (<literal>CDATA</literal>) of the first text node which
          is a child of the element or elements matched by the XPath
          expression.

Using this function is the equivalent of performing a match
          using the <replaceable>xpath_expr</replaceable> after
          appending <literal>/text()</literal>. In other words,
          <literal role="func">ExtractValue('<a><b>Sakila</b></a>',
          '/a/b')</literal> and
          <literal role="func">ExtractValue('<a><b>Sakila</b></a>',
          '/a/b/text()')</literal> produce the same result.

If multiple matches are found, the content of the first child
          text node of each matching element is returned (in the order
          matched) as a single, space-delimited string.

If no matching text node is found for the expression
          (including the implicit <literal>/text()</literal>)mdashfor
          whatever reason, as long as
          <replaceable>xpath_expr</replaceable> is valid, and
          <replaceable>xml_frag</replaceable> consists of elements which
          are properly nested and closedmdashan empty string is
          returned. No distinction is made between a match on an empty
          element and no match at all. This is by design.

If you need to determine whether no matching element was found
          in <replaceable>xml_frag</replaceable> or such an element was
          found but contained no child text nodes, you should test the
          result of an expression that uses the XPath
          <literal>count()</literal> function. For example, both of
          these statements return an empty string, as shown here:

However, you can determine whether there was actually a
          matching element using the following:

This function replaces a single portion of a given fragment of
          XML markup <replaceable>xml_target</replaceable> with a new
          XML fragment <replaceable>new_xml</replaceable>, and then
          returns the changed XML. The portion of
          <replaceable>xml_target</replaceable> that is replaced matches
          an XPath expression <replaceable>xpath_expr</replaceable>
          supplied by the user.

If no expression matching
          <replaceable>xpath_expr</replaceable> is found, or if multiple
          matches are found, the function returns the original
          <replaceable>xml_target</replaceable> XML fragment. All three
          arguments should be strings.

This function decrypts data using the official AES (Advanced
          Encryption Standard) algorithm. For more information, see the
          description of <literal role="func">AES_ENCRYPT()</literal>.

The optional initialization vector argument,
          <replaceable>init_vector</replaceable>. Statements that use
          <literal role="func">AES_DECRYPT()</literal> are unsafe for
          statement-based replication.

<literal role="func">AES_ENCRYPT()</literal> and
          <literal role="func">AES_DECRYPT()</literal> implement
          encryption and decryption of data using the official AES
          (Advanced Encryption Standard) algorithm, previously known as
          <quote>Rijndael.</quote> The AES standard permits various key
          lengths. By default these functions implement AES with a
          128-bit key length. Key lengths of 196 or 256 bits can be
          used, as described later. The key length is a trade off
          between performance and security.

<literal role="func">AES_ENCRYPT()</literal> encrypts the
          string <replaceable>str</replaceable> using the key string
          <replaceable>key_str</replaceable> and returns a binary string
          containing the encrypted output.
          <literal role="func">AES_DECRYPT()</literal> decrypts the
          encrypted string <replaceable>crypt_str</replaceable> using
          the key string <replaceable>key_str</replaceable> and returns
          the original plaintext string. If either function argument is
          <literal>NULL</literal>, the function returns
          <literal>NULL</literal>.

The <replaceable>str</replaceable> and
          <replaceable>crypt_str</replaceable> arguments can be any
          length, and padding is automatically added to
          <replaceable>str</replaceable> so it is a multiple of a block
          as required by block-based algorithms such as AES. This
          padding is automatically removed by the
          <literal role="func">AES_DECRYPT()</literal> function. The
          length of <replaceable>crypt_str</replaceable> can be
          calculated using this formula:

description.programlisting:
>
16 * (trunc(<replaceable>string_length</replaceable> / 16) + 1)

description.para:
For a key length of 128 bits, the most secure way to pass a
          key to the <replaceable>key_str</replaceable> argument is to
          create a truly random 128-bit value and pass it as a binary
          value. For example:

A passphrase can be used to generate an AES key by hashing the
          passphrase. For example:

Do not pass a password or passphrase directly to
          <replaceable>crypt_str</replaceable>, hash it first. Previous
          versions of this documentation suggested the former approach,
          but it is no longer recommended as the examples shown here are
          more secure.

If <literal role="func">AES_DECRYPT()</literal> detects
          invalid data or incorrect padding, it returns
          <literal>NULL</literal>. However, it is possible for
          <literal role="func">AES_DECRYPT()</literal> to return a
          non-<literal>NULL</literal> value (possibly garbage) if the
          input data or the key is invalid.

<literal role="func">AES_ENCRYPT()</literal> and
          <literal role="func">AES_DECRYPT()</literal> permit control of
          the block encryption mode and take an optional
          <replaceable>init_vector</replaceable> initialization vector
          argument:

itemizedlist.para:
The <literal role="sysvar">block_encryption_mode</literal>
              system variable controls the mode for block-based
              encryption algorithms. Its default value is
              <literal>aes-128-ecb</literal>, which signifies encryption
              using a key length of 128 bits and ECB mode. For a
              description of the permitted values of this variable, see
              <xref linkend="server-system-variables" />.

The optional <replaceable>init_vector</replaceable>
              argument provides an initialization vector for block
              encryption modes that require it.

description.para:
For modes that require the optional
          <replaceable>init_vector</replaceable> argument, it must be 16
          bytes or longer (bytes in excess of 16 are ignored). An error
          occurs if <replaceable>init_vector</replaceable> is missing.

For modes that do not require
          <replaceable>init_vector</replaceable>, it is ignored and a
          warning is generated if it is specified.

A random string of bytes to use for the initialization vector
          can be produced by calling
          <literal role="func">RANDOM_BYTES(16)</literal>. For
          encryption modes that require an initialization vector, the
          same vector must be used for encryption and decryption.

          Otherwise, the return value is always <literal>NULL</literal>.
          The compressed string can be uncompressed with
          <literal role="func">UNCOMPRESS()</literal>.

Calculates an MD5 128-bit checksum for the string. The value
          is returned as a string of 32 hexadecimal digits, or
          <literal>NULL</literal> if the argument was
          <literal>NULL</literal>. The return value can, for example, be
          used as a hash key. See the notes at the beginning of this

The return value is a string in the connection character set.

If FIPS mode is enabled,
          <function role="func">MD5()</function> returns

This function returns a binary string of
          <replaceable>len</replaceable> random bytes generated using
          the random number generator of the SSL library. Permitted
          values of <replaceable>len</replaceable> range from 1 to 1024.
          For values outside that range,
          <literal role="func">RANDOM_BYTES()</literal> generates a
          warning and returns <literal>NULL</literal>.

<literal role="func">RANDOM_BYTES()</literal> can be used to
          provide the initialization vector for the
          <literal role="func">AES_DECRYPT()</literal> and
          <literal role="func">AES_ENCRYPT()</literal> functions. For
          use in that context, <replaceable>len</replaceable> must be at
          least 16. Larger values are permitted, but bytes in excess of
          16 are ignored.

<literal role="func">RANDOM_BYTES()</literal> generates a
          random value, which makes its result nondeterministic.
          Consequently, statements that use this function are unsafe for
          statement-based replication.

Calculates an SHA-1 160-bit checksum for the string, as
          described in RFC 3174 (Secure Hash Algorithm). The value is
          returned as a string of 40 hexadecimal digits, or
          <literal>NULL</literal> if the argument was
          <literal>NULL</literal>. One of the possible uses for this
          function is as a hash key. See the notes at the beginning of

The return value is a string in the connection character set.

          of 224, 256, 384, 512, or 0 (which is equivalent to 256). If
          either argument is <literal>NULL</literal> or the hash length
          is not one of the permitted values, the return value is
          <literal>NULL</literal>. Otherwise, the function result is a
          hash value containing the desired number of bits. See the
          notes at the beginning of this section about storing hash
          values efficiently.
The return value is a string in the connection character set.

Tries to obtain a lock with a name given by the string
          <replaceable>str</replaceable>, using a timeout of
          <replaceable>timeout</replaceable> seconds. A negative
          <replaceable>timeout</replaceable> value means infinite
          timeout. The lock is exclusive. While held by one session,
          other sessions cannot obtain a lock of the same name.

Returns <literal>1</literal> if the lock was obtained
          successfully, <literal>0</literal> if the attempt timed out
          (for example, because another client has previously locked the
          name), or <literal>NULL</literal> if an error occurred (such
          as running out of memory or the thread was killed with
          <command>mysqladmin kill</command>).

A lock obtained with <literal role="func">GET_LOCK()</literal>
          is released explicitly by executing
          <literal role="func">RELEASE_LOCK()</literal> or implicitly
          when your session terminates (either normally or abnormally).
          Locks obtained with <literal role="func">GET_LOCK()</literal>
          are not released when transactions commit or roll back.

<literal role="func">GET_LOCK()</literal> is implemented using
          the metadata locking (MDL) subsystem. Multiple simultaneous
          locks can be acquired and
          <literal role="func">GET_LOCK()</literal> does not release any
          existing locks. For example, suppose that you execute these
          statements:

The second <literal role="func">GET_LOCK()</literal> acquires
          a second lock and both
          <literal role="func">RELEASE_LOCK()</literal> calls return 1
          (success).

It is even possible for a given session to acquire multiple
          locks for the same name. Other sessions cannot acquire a lock
          with that name until the acquiring session releases all its
          locks for the name.

Uniquely named locks acquired with
          <literal role="func">GET_LOCK()</literal> appear in the
          Performance Schema <literal role="ps">metadata_locks</literal>
          table. The <literal>OBJECT_TYPE</literal> column says
          <literal>USER LEVEL LOCK</literal> and the
          <literal>OBJECT_NAME</literal> column indicates the lock name.
          In the case that multiple locks are acquired for the
          <emphasis>same</emphasis> name, only the first lock for the
          name registers a row in the
          <literal role="ps">metadata_locks</literal> table. Subsequent
          locks for the name increment a counter in the lock but do not
          acquire additional metadata locks. The
          <literal role="ps">metadata_locks</literal> row for the lock
          is deleted when the last lock instance on the name is
          released.

The capability of acquiring multiple locks means there is the
          possibility of deadlock among clients. When this happens, the
          server chooses a caller and terminates its lock-acquisition
          request with an
          <literal role="error">ER_USER_LOCK_DEADLOCK</literal> error.
          This error does not cause transactions to roll back.

MySQL enforces a maximum length on lock names of 64
          characters.

<literal role="func">GET_LOCK()</literal> can be used to
          implement application locks or to simulate record locks. Names
          are locked on a server-wide basis. If a name has been locked
          within one session, <literal role="func">GET_LOCK()</literal>
          blocks any request by another session for a lock with the same
          name. This enables clients that agree on a given lock name to
          use the name to perform cooperative advisory locking. But be
          aware that it also enables a client that is not among the set
          of cooperating clients to lock a name, either inadvertently or
          deliberately, and thus prevent any of the cooperating clients
          from locking that name. One way to reduce the likelihood of
          this is to use lock names that are database-specific or
          application-specific. For example, use lock names of the form
          <replaceable>db_name.str</replaceable> or
          <replaceable>app_name.str</replaceable>.

Checks whether the lock named <replaceable>str</replaceable>
          is free to use (that is, not locked). Returns
          <literal>1</literal> if the lock is free (no one is using the
          lock), <literal>0</literal> if the lock is in use, and
          <literal>NULL</literal> if an error occurs (such as an

Checks whether the lock named <replaceable>str</replaceable>
          is in use (that is, locked). If so, it returns the connection

          Otherwise, it returns <literal>NULL</literal>.

Releases all named locks held by the current session and
          returns the number of locks released (0 if there were none)

Releases the lock named by the string
          <replaceable>str</replaceable> that was obtained with
          <literal role="func">GET_LOCK()</literal>. Returns
          <literal>1</literal> if the lock was released,
          <literal>0</literal> if the lock was not established by this
          thread (in which case the lock is not released), and
          <literal>NULL</literal> if the named lock did not exist. The
          lock does not exist if it was never obtained by a call to
          <literal role="func">GET_LOCK()</literal> or if it has
          previously been released.

The <literal role="stmt">DO</literal> statement is convenient
          to use with <literal role="func">RELEASE_LOCK()</literal>. See

With no argument,
          <literal role="func">LAST_INSERT_ID()</literal> returns a
          <literal>BIGINT UNSIGNED</literal> (64-bit) value representing
          the first automatically generated value successfully inserted
          for an <literal>AUTO_INCREMENT</literal> column as a result of
          the most recently executed
          <literal role="stmt">INSERT</literal> statement. The value of
          <literal role="func">LAST_INSERT_ID()</literal> remains
          unchanged if no rows are successfully inserted.

With an argument,
          <literal role="func">LAST_INSERT_ID()</literal> returns an
          unsigned integer.

For example, after inserting a row that generates an
          <literal>AUTO_INCREMENT</literal> value, you can get the value
          like this:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SELECT LAST_INSERT_ID();</userinput>
        -> 195

description.para:
The currently executing statement does not affect the value of
          <literal role="func">LAST_INSERT_ID()</literal>. Suppose that
          you generate an <literal>AUTO_INCREMENT</literal> value with
          one statement, and then refer to
          <literal role="func">LAST_INSERT_ID()</literal> in a
          multiple-row <literal role="stmt">INSERT</literal> statement
          that inserts rows into a table with its own
          <literal>AUTO_INCREMENT</literal> column. The value of
          <literal role="func">LAST_INSERT_ID()</literal> will remain
          stable in the second statement; its value for the second and
          later rows is not affected by the earlier row insertions.
          (However, if you mix references to
          <literal role="func">LAST_INSERT_ID()</literal> and
          <literal role="func">LAST_INSERT_ID(<replaceable>expr</replaceable>)</literal>,
          the effect is undefined.)

If the previous statement returned an error, the value of
          <literal role="func">LAST_INSERT_ID()</literal> is undefined.
          For transactional tables, if the statement is rolled back due
          to an error, the value of
          <literal role="func">LAST_INSERT_ID()</literal> is left
          undefined. For manual
          <literal condition="commit" role="stmt">ROLLBACK</literal>,
          the value of <literal role="func">LAST_INSERT_ID()</literal>
          is not restored to that before the transaction; it remains as
          it was at the point of the
          <literal condition="commit" role="stmt">ROLLBACK</literal>.

Within the body of a stored routine (procedure or function) or
          a trigger, the value of
          <literal role="func">LAST_INSERT_ID()</literal> changes the
          same way as for statements executed outside the body of these
          kinds of objects. The effect of a stored routine or trigger
          upon the value of
          <literal role="func">LAST_INSERT_ID()</literal> that is seen
          by following statements depends on the kind of routine:

itemizedlist.para:
If a stored procedure executes statements that change the
              value of <literal role="func">LAST_INSERT_ID()</literal>,
              the changed value is seen by statements that follow the
              procedure call.

For stored functions and triggers that change the value,
              the value is restored when the function or trigger ends,
              so following statements will not see a changed value.

<literal>ROW_COUNT()</literal> returns a value as follows:

itemizedlist.para:
DDL statements: 0. This applies to statements such as
              <literal role="stmt">CREATE TABLE</literal> or
              <literal role="stmt">DROP TABLE</literal>.

DML statements other than
              <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal>: The number of
              affected rows. This applies to statements such as
              <literal role="stmt">UPDATE</literal>,
              <literal role="stmt">INSERT</literal>, or
              <literal role="stmt">DELETE</literal> (as before), but now
              also to statements such as <literal role="stmt">ALTER
              TABLE</literal> and <literal role="stmt">LOAD
              DATA</literal>.

<literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal>: -1 if the statement
              returns a result set, or the number of rows
              <quote>affected</quote> if it does not. For example, for
              <literal>SELECT * FROM t1</literal>,
              <literal role="func">ROW_COUNT()</literal> returns -1. For
              <literal>SELECT * FROM t1 INTO OUTFILE
              '<replaceable>file_name</replaceable>'</literal>,
              <literal role="func">ROW_COUNT()</literal> returns the
              number of rows written to the file.
<literal role="stmt">SIGNAL</literal> statements: 0.

description.para:
For <literal role="stmt">UPDATE</literal> statements, the
          affected-rows value by default is the number of rows actually
          changed. If you specify the
          <literal>CLIENT_FOUND_ROWS</literal> flag to
          <literal role="cfunc">mysql_real_connect()</literal> when
          connecting to <command>mysqld</command>, the affected-rows
          value is the number of rows <quote>found</quote>; that is,
          matched by the <literal>WHERE</literal> clause.

For <literal role="stmt">REPLACE</literal> statements, the
          affected-rows value is 2 if the new row replaced an old row,
          because in this case, one row was inserted after the duplicate
          was deleted.

For
          <literal condition="insert-on-duplicate" role="stmt">INSERT
          ... ON DUPLICATE KEY UPDATE</literal> statements, the
          affected-rows value per row is 1 if the row is inserted as a
          new row, 2 if an existing row is updated, and 0 if an existing
          row is set to its current values. If you specify the
          <literal>CLIENT_FOUND_ROWS</literal> flag, the affected-rows
          value is 1 (not 0) if an existing row is set to its current
          values.

The <literal role="func">ROW_COUNT()</literal> value is
          similar to the value from the
          <literal role="cfunc">mysql_affected_rows()</literal> C API
          function and the row count that the <command>mysql</command>
          client displays following statement execution.

Given two sets of global transaction identifiers

Wait until the server has applied all of the transactions
          whose global transaction identifiers are contained in
          <replaceable>gtid_set</replaceable>; that is, until the
          condition GTID_SUBSET(<replaceable>gtid_subset</replaceable>,
          <literal>@@GLOBAL.gtid_executed</literal>) holds. See

If a timeout is specified, and
          <replaceable>timeout</replaceable> seconds elapse before all
          of the transactions in the GTID set have been applied, the
          function stops waiting. <replaceable>timeout</replaceable> is
          optional, and the default timeout is 0 seconds, in which case
          the function always waits until all of the transactions in the
          GTID set have been applied.

<literal>WAIT_FOR_EXECUTED_GTID_SET()</literal> monitors all
          the GTIDs that are applied on the server, including
          transactions that arrive from all replication channels and
          user clients. It does not take into account whether
          replication channels have been started or stopped.
For more information, see <xref linkend="replication-gtids" />.

          works regardless of the replication channel or user client
          through which the specified transactions arrive on the server.

<literal role="func">CUME_DIST()</literal>
            <replaceable>over_clause</replaceable>

Returns the cumulative distribution of a value within a
            group of values; that is, the percentage of partition values
            less than or equal to the value in the current row. This
            represents the number of rows preceding or peer with the
            current row in the window ordering of the window partition
            divided by the total number of rows in the window partition.
            Return values range from 0 to 1.

This function should be used with <literal>ORDER
            BY</literal> to sort partition rows into the desired order.
            Without <literal>ORDER BY</literal>, all rows are peers and
            have value
            <replaceable>N</replaceable>/<replaceable>N</replaceable> =
            1, where <replaceable>N</replaceable> is the partition size.

<replaceable>over_clause</replaceable> is as described in
            <xref linkend="window-functions-usage" />.

<literal role="func">DENSE_RANK()</literal>
            <replaceable>over_clause</replaceable>

Returns the rank of the current row within its partition,
            without gaps. Peers are considered ties and receive the same
            rank. This function assigns consecutive ranks to peer
            groups; the result is that groups of size greater than one
            do not produce noncontiguous rank numbers. For an example,
            see the <literal role="func">RANK()</literal> function
            description.

This function should be used with <literal>ORDER
            BY</literal> to sort partition rows into the desired order.
            Without <literal>ORDER BY</literal>, all rows are peers.

<replaceable>over_clause</replaceable> is as described in
            <xref linkend="window-functions-usage" />.

<literal role="func">FIRST_VALUE(<replaceable>expr</replaceable>)</literal>
            [<replaceable>null_treatment</replaceable>]
            <replaceable>over_clause</replaceable>

Returns the value of <replaceable>expr</replaceable> from
            the first row of the window frame.

<replaceable>over_clause</replaceable> is as described in
            <xref linkend="window-functions-usage" />.
            <replaceable>null_treatment</replaceable> is as described in
            the section introduction.

<literal role="func">LAG(<replaceable>expr</replaceable> [,
            <replaceable>N</replaceable>[,
            <replaceable>default</replaceable>]])</literal>
            [<replaceable>null_treatment</replaceable>]
            <replaceable>over_clause</replaceable>

Returns the value of <replaceable>expr</replaceable> from
            the row that lags (precedes) the current row by
            <replaceable>N</replaceable> rows within its partition. If
            there is no such row, the return value is
            <replaceable>default</replaceable>. For example, if
            <replaceable>N</replaceable> is 3, the return value is
            <replaceable>default</replaceable> for the first two rows.
            If <replaceable>N</replaceable> or
            <replaceable>default</replaceable> are missing, the defaults
            are 1 and <literal>NULL</literal>, respectively.

<replaceable>N</replaceable> must be a literal nonnegative
            integer. If <replaceable>N</replaceable> is 0,
            <replaceable>expr</replaceable> is evaluated for the current
            row.

<replaceable>over_clause</replaceable> is as described in
            <xref linkend="window-functions-usage" />.
            <replaceable>null_treatment</replaceable> is as described in
            the section introduction.

<literal role="func">LAST_VALUE(<replaceable>expr</replaceable>)</literal>
            [<replaceable>null_treatment</replaceable>]
            <replaceable>over_clause</replaceable>

Returns the value of <replaceable>expr</replaceable> from
            the last row of the window frame.

<replaceable>over_clause</replaceable> is as described in
            <xref linkend="window-functions-usage" />.
            <replaceable>null_treatment</replaceable> is as described in
            the section introduction.

For an example, see the
            <literal role="func">FIRST_VALUE()</literal> function
            description.

<literal role="func">LEAD(<replaceable>expr</replaceable> [,
            <replaceable>N</replaceable>[,
            <replaceable>default</replaceable>]])</literal>
            [<replaceable>null_treatment</replaceable>]
            <replaceable>over_clause</replaceable>

Returns the value of <replaceable>expr</replaceable> from
            the row that leads (follows) the current row by
            <replaceable>N</replaceable> rows within its partition. If
            there is no such row, the return value is
            <replaceable>default</replaceable>. For example, if
            <replaceable>N</replaceable> is 3, the return value is
            <replaceable>default</replaceable> for the last two rows. If
            <replaceable>N</replaceable> or
            <replaceable>default</replaceable> are missing, the defaults
            are 1 and <literal>NULL</literal>, respectively.

<replaceable>N</replaceable> must be a literal nonnegative
            integer. If <replaceable>N</replaceable> is 0,
            <replaceable>expr</replaceable> is evaluated for the current
            row.

<replaceable>over_clause</replaceable> is as described in
            <xref linkend="window-functions-usage" />.
            <replaceable>null_treatment</replaceable> is as described in
            the section introduction.

For an example, see the <literal role="func">LAG()</literal>
            function description.

<literal role="func">NTH_VALUE(<replaceable>expr</replaceable>,
            <replaceable>N</replaceable>)</literal>
            [<replaceable>from_first_last</replaceable>]
            [<replaceable>null_treatment</replaceable>]
            <replaceable>over_clause</replaceable>

Returns the value of <replaceable>expr</replaceable> from
            the <replaceable>N</replaceable>-th row of the window frame.
            If there is no such row, the return value is
            <literal>NULL</literal>.

<replaceable>N</replaceable> must be a literal positive
            integer.

<replaceable>from_first_last</replaceable> is part of the
            SQL standard, but the MySQL implementation permits only
            <literal>FROM FIRST</literal> (which is also the default).
            This means that calculations begin at the first row of the
            window. <literal>FROM LAST</literal> is parsed, but produces
            an error. To obtain the same effect as <literal>FROM
            LAST</literal> (begin calculations at the last row of the
            window), use <literal>ORDER BY</literal> to sort in reverse
            order.

<replaceable>over_clause</replaceable> is as described in
            <xref linkend="window-functions-usage" />.
            <replaceable>null_treatment</replaceable> is as described in
            the section introduction.

For an example, see the
            <literal role="func">FIRST_VALUE()</literal> function
            description.

<literal role="func">NTILE(<replaceable>N</replaceable>)</literal>
            <replaceable>over_clause</replaceable>

Divides a partition into <replaceable>N</replaceable> groups
            (buckets), assigns each row in the partition its bucket
            number, and returns the bucket number of the current row
            within its partition. For example, if
            <replaceable>N</replaceable> is 4,
            <literal>NTILE()</literal> divides rows into four buckets.
            If <replaceable>N</replaceable> is 100,
            <literal>NTILE()</literal> divides rows into 100 buckets.

<replaceable>N</replaceable> must be a literal positive
            integer. Bucket number return values range from 1 to
            <replaceable>N</replaceable>.

This function should be used with <literal>ORDER
            BY</literal> to sort partition rows into the desired order.

<replaceable>over_clause</replaceable> is as described in
            <xref linkend="window-functions-usage" />.

<literal role="func">PERCENT_RANK()</literal>
            <replaceable>over_clause</replaceable>

Returns the percentage of partition values less than the
            value in the current row, excluding the highest value.
            Return values range from 0 to 1 and represent the row
            relative rank, calculated as the result of this formula,
            where <replaceable>rank</replaceable> is the row rank and
            <replaceable>rows</replaceable> is the number of partition
            rows:

description.programlisting:
>
(<replaceable>rank</replaceable> - 1) / (<replaceable>rows</replaceable> - 1)

description.para:
This function should be used with <literal>ORDER
            BY</literal> to sort partition rows into the desired order.
            Without <literal>ORDER BY</literal>, all rows are peers.

<replaceable>over_clause</replaceable> is as described in
            <xref linkend="window-functions-usage" />.

For an example, see the
            <literal role="func">CUME_DIST()</literal> function
            description.

<literal role="func">RANK()</literal>
            <replaceable>over_clause</replaceable>

Returns the rank of the current row within its partition,
            with gaps. Peers are considered ties and receive the same
            rank. This function does not assign consecutive ranks to
            peer groups if groups of size greater than one exist; the
            result is noncontiguous rank numbers.

This function should be used with <literal>ORDER
            BY</literal> to sort partition rows into the desired order.
            Without <literal>ORDER BY</literal>, all rows are peers.

<replaceable>over_clause</replaceable> is as described in
            <xref linkend="window-functions-usage" />.

<literal role="func">ROW_NUMBER()</literal>
            <replaceable>over_clause</replaceable>

Returns the number of the current row within its partition.
            Rows numbers range from 1 to the number of partition rows.

<literal>ORDER BY</literal> affects the order in which rows
            are numbered. Without <literal>ORDER BY</literal>, row
            numbering is nondeterministic.

<literal role="func">ROW_NUMBER()</literal> assigns peers
            different row numbers. To assign peers the same value, use
            <literal role="func">RANK()</literal> or
            <literal role="func">DENSE_RANK()</literal>. For an example,
            see the <literal role="func">RANK()</literal> function
            description.

<replaceable>over_clause</replaceable> is as described in
            <xref linkend="window-functions-usage" />.
<literal role="func">FORMAT_BYTES(<replaceable>count</replaceable>)</literal>

Given a numeric byte count, converts it to human-readable
          format and returns a string consisting of a value and a units
          indicator. The string contains the number of bytes rounded to
          2 decimal places and a minimum of 3 significant digits.
          Numbers less than 1024 bytes are represented as whole numbers
          and are not rounded.
<literal role="func">FORMAT_PICO_TIME(<replaceable>time_val</replaceable>)</literal>

Given a numeric Performance Schema latency or wait time in
          picoseconds, converts it to human-readable format and returns
          a string consisting of a value and a units indicator. The
          string contains the decimal time rounded to 2 decimal places
          and a minimum of 3 significant digits. Times under 1
          nanosecond are represented as whole numbers and are not
          rounded.
<literal role="func">PS_CURRENT_THREAD_ID()</literal>

Returns a <literal>BIGINT UNSIGNED</literal> value
          representing the Performance Schema thread ID assigned to the
          current connection.

The thread ID return value is a value of the type given in the
          <literal>THREAD_ID</literal> column of Performance Schema
          tables.

Performance Schema configuration affects
          <literal role="func">PS_CURRENT_THREAD_ID()</literal> the same
          way as for <literal role="func">PS_THREAD_ID()</literal>. For
          details, see the description of that function.
<literal role="func">PS_THREAD_ID(<replaceable>connection_id</replaceable>)</literal>

Given a connection ID, returns a <literal>BIGINT
          UNSIGNED</literal> value representing the Performance Schema
          thread ID assigned to the connection ID, or
          <literal>NULL</literal> if no thread ID exists for the
          connection ID. The latter can occur for threads that are not
          instrumented.

The connection ID argument is a value of the type given in the
          <literal>PROCESSLIST_ID</literal> column of the Performance
          Schema <literal role="ps">threads</literal> table or the
          <literal>Id</literal> column of <literal role="stmt">SHOW
          PROCESSLIST</literal> output.

The thread ID return value is a value of the type given in the
          <literal>THREAD_ID</literal> column of Performance Schema
          tables.

Performance Schema configuration affects
          <literal role="func">PS_THREAD_ID()</literal> operation as
          follows. (These remarks also apply to
          <literal role="func">PS_CURRENT_THREAD_ID()</literal>.)

itemizedlist.para:
Disabling the <literal>thread_instrumentation</literal>
              consumer disables statistics from being collected and
              aggregated at the thread level, but has no effect on
              <literal role="func">PS_THREAD_ID()</literal>.

If
              <literal role="sysvar">performance_schema_max_thread_instances</literal>
              is not 0, the Performance Schema allocates memory for
              thread statistics and assigns an internal ID to each
              thread for which instance memory is available. If there
              are threads for which instance memory is not available,
              <literal role="func">PS_THREAD_ID()</literal> returns
              <literal>NULL</literal>; in this case,
              <literal role="statvar">Performance_schema_thread_instances_lost</literal>
              will be nonzero.

If
              <literal role="sysvar">performance_schema_max_thread_instances</literal>
              is 0, the Performance Schema allocates no thread memory
              and <literal role="func">PS_THREAD_ID()</literal> returns
              <literal>NULL</literal>.

If the Performance Schema itself is disabled,
              <literal role="func">PS_THREAD_ID()</literal> produces an
              error.
