Cursor declarations must appear before handler declarations and
        after variable and condition declarations.

A stored program may contain multiple cursor declarations, but
        each cursor declared in a given block must have a unique name.
        For an example, see <xref linkend="cursors" />.

For information available through
        <literal role="stmt">SHOW</literal> statements, it is possible
        in many cases to obtain equivalent information by using a cursor
        with an <literal>INFORMATION_SCHEMA</literal> table.

This statement fetches the next row for the
        <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> statement associated with
        the specified cursor (which must be open), and advances the
        cursor pointer. If a row exists, the fetched columns are stored
        in the named variables. The number of columns retrieved by the
        <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> statement must match the
        number of output variables specified in the
        <literal role="stmt">FETCH</literal> statement.

If no more rows are available, a No Data condition occurs with
        SQLSTATE value <literal>'02000'</literal>. To detect this
        condition, you can set up a handler for it (or for a
        <literal>NOT FOUND</literal> condition). For an example, see
        <xref linkend="cursors" />.

Be aware that another operation, such as a
        <literal>SELECT</literal> or another <literal>FETCH</literal>,
        may also cause the handler to execute by raising the same
        condition. If it is necessary to distinguish which operation
        raised the condition, place the operation within its own
        <literal condition="begin-end" role="stmt">BEGIN ...
        END</literal> block so that it can be associated with its own
        handler.

This statement opens a previously declared cursor. For an
        example, see <xref linkend="cursors" />.

The <literal condition="declare-condition" role="stmt">DECLARE
        ... CONDITION</literal> statement declares a named error
        condition, associating a name with a condition that needs
        specific handling. The name can be referred to in a subsequent
        <literal condition="declare-handler" role="stmt">DECLARE ...
        HANDLER</literal> statement (see
        <xref linkend="declare-handler" />).

Condition declarations must appear before cursor or handler
        declarations.

The <replaceable>condition_value</replaceable> for
        <literal condition="declare-condition" role="stmt">DECLARE ...
        CONDITION</literal> indicates the specific condition or class of
        conditions to associate with the condition name. It can take the
        following forms:

itemizedlist.para:
<replaceable>mysql_error_code</replaceable>: An integer
            literal indicating a MySQL error code.

Do not use MySQL error code 0 because that indicates success
            rather than an error condition. For a list of MySQL error
            codes, see <xref linkend="server-error-reference" />.

SQLSTATE [VALUE] <replaceable>sqlstate_value</replaceable>:
            A 5-character string literal indicating an SQLSTATE value.

Do not use SQLSTATE values that begin with
            <literal>'00'</literal> because those indicate success
            rather than an error condition. For a list of SQLSTATE
            values, see <xref linkend="server-error-reference" />.

description.para:
Condition names referred to in
        <literal role="stmt">SIGNAL</literal> or use
        <literal role="stmt">RESIGNAL</literal> statements must be
        associated with SQLSTATE values, not MySQL error codes.

The <literal condition="declare-handler" role="stmt">DECLARE ...
        HANDLER</literal> statement specifies a handler that deals with
        one or more conditions. If one of these conditions occurs, the
        specified <replaceable>statement</replaceable> executes.
        <replaceable>statement</replaceable> can be a simple statement
        such as <literal>SET <replaceable>var_name</replaceable> =
        <replaceable>value</replaceable></literal>, or a compound
        statement written using <literal>BEGIN</literal> and
        <literal>END</literal> (see <xref linkend="begin-end" />).

Handler declarations must appear after variable or condition
        declarations.

The <replaceable>handler_action</replaceable> value indicates
        what action the handler takes after execution of the handler
        statement:

itemizedlist.para:
<literal>CONTINUE</literal>: Execution of the current
            program continues.

<literal>EXIT</literal>: Execution terminates for the
            <literal condition="begin-end" role="stmt">BEGIN ...
            END</literal> compound statement in which the handler is
            declared. This is true even if the condition occurs in an
            inner block.
<literal>UNDO</literal>: Not supported.

description.para:
The <replaceable>condition_value</replaceable> for
        <literal condition="declare-handler" role="stmt">DECLARE ...
        HANDLER</literal> indicates the specific condition or class of
        conditions that activates the handler. It can take the following
        forms:

itemizedlist.para:
<replaceable>mysql_error_code</replaceable>: An integer
            literal indicating a MySQL error code, such as 1051 to
            specify <quote>unknown table</quote>:

itemizedlist.programlisting:
>
DECLARE CONTINUE HANDLER FOR 1051
  BEGIN
    -- body of handler
  END;

itemizedlist.para:
Do not use MySQL error code 0 because that indicates success
            rather than an error condition. For a list of MySQL error
            codes, see <xref linkend="server-error-reference" />.

SQLSTATE [VALUE] <replaceable>sqlstate_value</replaceable>:
            A 5-character string literal indicating an SQLSTATE value,
            such as <literal>'42S01'</literal> to specify <quote>unknown
            table</quote>:

itemizedlist.programlisting:
>
DECLARE CONTINUE HANDLER FOR SQLSTATE '42S02'
  BEGIN
    -- body of handler
  END;

itemizedlist.para:
Do not use SQLSTATE values that begin with
            <literal>'00'</literal> because those indicate success
            rather than an error condition. For a list of SQLSTATE
            values, see <xref linkend="server-error-reference" />.

<replaceable>condition_name</replaceable>: A condition name
            previously specified with
            <literal condition="declare-condition" role="stmt">DECLARE
            ... CONDITION</literal>. A condition name can be associated
            with a MySQL error code or SQLSTATE value. See
            <xref linkend="declare-condition" />.

<literal>SQLWARNING</literal>: Shorthand for the class of
            SQLSTATE values that begin with <literal>'01'</literal>.

itemizedlist.programlisting:
>
DECLARE CONTINUE HANDLER FOR SQLWARNING
  BEGIN
    -- body of handler
  END;

itemizedlist.para:
<literal>NOT FOUND</literal>: Shorthand for the class of
            SQLSTATE values that begin with <literal>'02'</literal>.
            This is relevant within the context of cursors and is used
            to control what happens when a cursor reaches the end of a
            data set. If no more rows are available, a No Data condition
            occurs with SQLSTATE value <literal>'02000'</literal>. To
            detect this condition, you can set up a handler for it or
            for a <literal>NOT FOUND</literal> condition.

itemizedlist.programlisting:
>
DECLARE CONTINUE HANDLER FOR NOT FOUND
  BEGIN
    -- body of handler
  END;

itemizedlist.para:
For another example, see <xref linkend="cursors" />. The
            <literal>NOT FOUND</literal> condition also occurs for
            <literal>SELECT ... INTO
            <replaceable>var_list</replaceable></literal> statements
            that retrieve no rows.

<literal>SQLEXCEPTION</literal>: Shorthand for the class of
            SQLSTATE values that do not begin with
            <literal>'00'</literal>, <literal>'01'</literal>, or
            <literal>'02'</literal>.

itemizedlist.programlisting:
>
DECLARE CONTINUE HANDLER FOR SQLEXCEPTION
  BEGIN
    -- body of handler
  END;

description.para:
For information about how the server chooses handlers when a
        condition occurs, see <xref linkend="handler-scope" />.

If a condition occurs for which no handler has been declared,
        the action taken depends on the condition class:

itemizedlist.para:
For <literal>SQLEXCEPTION</literal> conditions, the stored
            program terminates at the statement that raised the
            condition, as if there were an <literal>EXIT</literal>
            handler. If the program was called by another stored
            program, the calling program handles the condition using the
            handler selection rules applied to its own handlers.

For <literal>SQLWARNING</literal> conditions, the program
            continues executing, as if there were a
            <literal>CONTINUE</literal> handler.

For <literal>NOT FOUND</literal> conditions, if the
            condition was raised normally, the action is
            <literal>CONTINUE</literal>. If it was raised by
            <literal role="stmt">SIGNAL</literal> or
            <literal role="stmt">RESIGNAL</literal>, the action is
            <literal>EXIT</literal>.

syntax.programlisting:
>
DECLARE <replaceable>handler_action</replaceable> HANDLER
    FOR <replaceable>condition_value</replaceable> [, <replaceable>condition_value</replaceable>] ...
    <replaceable>statement</replaceable>

<replaceable>handler_action</replaceable>: {
    CONTINUE
  | EXIT
  | UNDO
}

<replaceable>condition_value</replaceable>: {
    <replaceable>mysql_error_code</replaceable>
  | SQLSTATE [VALUE] <replaceable>sqlstate_value</replaceable>
  | <replaceable>condition_name</replaceable>
  | SQLWARNING
  | NOT FOUND
  | SQLEXCEPTION
}

description.para:
SQL statements produce diagnostic information that populates the
        diagnostics area. The <literal role="stmt">GET
        DIAGNOSTICS</literal> statement enables applications to inspect
        this information. (You can also use <literal role="stmt">SHOW
        WARNINGS</literal> or <literal role="stmt">SHOW ERRORS</literal>
        to see conditions or errors.)

No special privileges are required to execute
        <literal role="stmt">GET DIAGNOSTICS</literal>.

The keyword <literal>CURRENT</literal> means to retrieve
        information from the current diagnostics area. The keyword
        <literal>STACKED</literal> means to retrieve information from
        the second diagnostics area, which is available only if the
        current context is a condition handler. If neither keyword is
        given, the default is to use the current diagnostics area.

The <literal role="stmt">GET DIAGNOSTICS</literal> statement is
        typically used in a handler within a stored program. It is a
        MySQL extension that
        <literal condition="get-diagnostics" role="stmt">GET [CURRENT]
        DIAGNOSTICS</literal> is permitted outside handler context to
        check the execution of any SQL statement. For example, if you
        invoke the <command>mysql</command> client program, you can
        enter these statements at the prompt:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>DROP TABLE test.no_such_table;</userinput>
ERROR 1051 (42S02): Unknown table 'test.no_such_table'
mysql> <userinput>GET DIAGNOSTICS CONDITION 1</userinput>
         <userinput>@p1 = RETURNED_SQLSTATE, @p2 = MESSAGE_TEXT;</userinput>
mysql> <userinput>SELECT @p1, @p2;</userinput>
+-------+------------------------------------+
| @p1   | @p2                                |
+-------+------------------------------------+
| 42S02 | Unknown table 'test.no_such_table' |
+-------+------------------------------------+

description.para:
This extension applies only to the current diagnostics area. It
        does not apply to the second diagnostics area because
        <literal>GET STACKED DIAGNOSTICS</literal> is permitted only if
        the current context is a condition handler. If that is not the
        case, a <literal>GET STACKED DIAGNOSTICS when handler not
        active</literal> error occurs.

For a description of the diagnostics area, see
        <xref linkend="diagnostics-area" />. Briefly, it contains two
        kinds of information:

itemizedlist.para:
Statement information, such as the number of conditions that
            occurred or the affected-rows count.

Condition information, such as the error code and message.
            If a statement raises multiple conditions, this part of the
            diagnostics area has a condition area for each one. If a
            statement raises no conditions, this part of the diagnostics
            area is empty.

description.para:
For a statement that produces three conditions, the diagnostics
        area contains statement and condition information like this:

description.programlisting:
>
Statement information:
  row count
  ... other statement information items ...
Condition area list:
  Condition area 1:
    error code for condition 1
    error message for condition 1
    ... other condition information items ...
  Condition area 2:
    error code for condition 2:
    error message for condition 2
    ... other condition information items ...
  Condition area 3:
    error code for condition 3
    error message for condition 3
    ... other condition information items ...

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">GET DIAGNOSTICS</literal> can obtain either
        statement or condition information, but not both in the same
        statement:

itemizedlist.para:
To obtain statement information, retrieve the desired
            statement items into target variables. This instance of
            <literal role="stmt">GET DIAGNOSTICS</literal> assigns the
            number of available conditions and the rows-affected count
            to the user variables <literal>@p1</literal> and
            <literal>@p2</literal>:

To obtain condition information, specify the condition
            number and retrieve the desired condition items into target
            variables. This instance of <literal role="stmt">GET
            DIAGNOSTICS</literal> assigns the SQLSTATE value and error
            message to the user variables <literal>@p3</literal> and
            <literal>@p4</literal>:

description.para:
The retrieval list specifies one or more
        <literal><replaceable>target</replaceable> =
        <replaceable>item_name</replaceable></literal> assignments,
        separated by commas. Each assignment names a target variable and
        either a
        <replaceable>statement_information_item_name</replaceable> or
        <replaceable>condition_information_item_name</replaceable>
        designator, depending on whether the statement retrieves
        statement or condition information.

Valid <replaceable>target</replaceable> designators for storing
        item information can be stored procedure or function parameters,
        stored program local variables declared with
        <literal role="stmt">DECLARE</literal>, or user-defined
        variables.

Valid <replaceable>condition_number</replaceable> designators
        can be stored procedure or function parameters, stored program
        local variables declared with
        <literal role="stmt">DECLARE</literal>, user-defined variables,
        system variables, or literals. A character literal may include a
        <replaceable>_charset</replaceable> introducer. A warning occurs
        if the condition number is not in the range from 1 to the number
        of condition areas that have information. In this case, the
        warning is added to the diagnostics area without clearing it.

When a condition occurs, MySQL does not populate all condition
        items recognized by <literal role="stmt">GET
        DIAGNOSTICS</literal>. For example:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>GET DIAGNOSTICS CONDITION 1</userinput>
         <userinput>@p5 = SCHEMA_NAME, @p6 = TABLE_NAME;</userinput>
mysql> <userinput>SELECT @p5, @p6;</userinput>
+------+------+
| @p5  | @p6  |
+------+------+
|      |      |
+------+------+

description.para:
In standard SQL, if there are multiple conditions, the first
        condition relates to the <literal>SQLSTATE</literal> value
        returned for the previous SQL statement. In MySQL, this is not
        guaranteed. To get the main error, you cannot do this:

description.programlisting:
>
GET DIAGNOSTICS CONDITION 1 @errno = MYSQL_ERRNO;

description.para:
Instead, retrieve the condition count first, then use it to
        specify which condition number to inspect:

For information about permissible statement and condition
        information items, and which ones are populated when a condition
        occurs, see
        <xref linkend="diagnostics-area-information-items" />.

Here is an example that uses <literal role="stmt">GET
        DIAGNOSTICS</literal> and an exception handler in stored
        procedure context to assess the outcome of an insert operation.
        If the insert was successful, the procedure uses
        <literal role="stmt">GET DIAGNOSTICS</literal> to get the
        rows-affected count. This shows that you can use
        <literal role="stmt">GET DIAGNOSTICS</literal> multiple times to
        retrieve information about a statement as long as the current
        diagnostics area has not been cleared.

Suppose that <literal>t1.int_col</literal> is an integer column
        that is declared as <literal>NOT NULL</literal>. The procedure
        produces these results when invoked to insert
        non-<literal>NULL</literal> and <literal>NULL</literal> values,
        respectively:

syntax.programlisting:
>
GET [CURRENT | STACKED] DIAGNOSTICS
{
    <replaceable>statement_information_item</replaceable>
    [, <replaceable>statement_information_item</replaceable>] ...
  | CONDITION <replaceable>condition_number</replaceable>
    <replaceable>condition_information_item</replaceable>
    [, <replaceable>condition_information_item</replaceable>] ...
}

<replaceable>statement_information_item</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>target</replaceable> = <replaceable>statement_information_item_name</replaceable>

<replaceable>condition_information_item</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>target</replaceable> = <replaceable>condition_information_item_name</replaceable>

<replaceable>statement_information_item_name</replaceable>:
    NUMBER
  | ROW_COUNT

<replaceable>condition_information_item_name</replaceable>: {
    CLASS_ORIGIN
  | SUBCLASS_ORIGIN
  | RETURNED_SQLSTATE
  | MESSAGE_TEXT
  | MYSQL_ERRNO
  | CONSTRAINT_CATALOG
  | CONSTRAINT_SCHEMA
  | CONSTRAINT_NAME
  | CATALOG_NAME
  | SCHEMA_NAME
  | TABLE_NAME
  | COLUMN_NAME
  | CURSOR_NAME
}

<replaceable>condition_number</replaceable>, <replaceable>target</replaceable>:
    (see following discussion)

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">RESIGNAL</literal> passes on the error
        condition information that is available during execution of a
        condition handler within a compound statement inside a stored
        procedure or function, trigger, or event.
        <literal role="stmt">RESIGNAL</literal> may change some or all
        information before passing it on.
        <literal role="stmt">RESIGNAL</literal> is related to
        <literal role="stmt">SIGNAL</literal>, but instead of
        originating a condition as <literal role="stmt">SIGNAL</literal>
        does, <literal role="stmt">RESIGNAL</literal> relays existing
        condition information, possibly after modifying it.

<literal role="stmt">RESIGNAL</literal> makes it possible to
        both handle an error and return the error information.
        Otherwise, by executing an SQL statement within the handler,
        information that caused the handler's activation is destroyed.
        <literal role="stmt">RESIGNAL</literal> also can make some
        procedures shorter if a given handler can handle part of a
        situation, then pass the condition <quote>up the line</quote> to
        another handler.

No privileges are required to execute the
        <literal role="stmt">RESIGNAL</literal> statement.

All forms of <literal role="stmt">RESIGNAL</literal> require
        that the current context be a condition handler. Otherwise,
        <literal role="stmt">RESIGNAL</literal> is illegal and a
        <literal>RESIGNAL when handler not active</literal> error
        occurs.

To retrieve information from the diagnostics area, use the
        <literal role="stmt">GET DIAGNOSTICS</literal> statement (see
        <xref linkend="get-diagnostics" />). For information about the
        diagnostics area, see <xref linkend="diagnostics-area" />.

syntax.programlisting:
>
RESIGNAL [<replaceable>condition_value</replaceable>]
    [SET <replaceable>signal_information_item</replaceable>
    [, <replaceable>signal_information_item</replaceable>] ...]

<replaceable>condition_value</replaceable>: {
    SQLSTATE [VALUE] <replaceable>sqlstate_value</replaceable>
  | <replaceable>condition_name</replaceable>
}

<replaceable>signal_information_item</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>condition_information_item_name</replaceable> = <replaceable>simple_value_specification</replaceable>

<replaceable>condition_information_item_name</replaceable>: {
    CLASS_ORIGIN
  | SUBCLASS_ORIGIN
  | MESSAGE_TEXT
  | MYSQL_ERRNO
  | CONSTRAINT_CATALOG
  | CONSTRAINT_SCHEMA
  | CONSTRAINT_NAME
  | CATALOG_NAME
  | SCHEMA_NAME
  | TABLE_NAME
  | COLUMN_NAME
  | CURSOR_NAME
}

<replaceable>condition_name</replaceable>, <replaceable>simple_value_specification</replaceable>:
    (see following discussion)

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">SIGNAL</literal> is the way to
        <quote>return</quote> an error.
        <literal role="stmt">SIGNAL</literal> provides error information
        to a handler, to an outer portion of the application, or to the
        client. Also, it provides control over the error's
        characteristics (error number, <literal>SQLSTATE</literal>
        value, message). Without <literal role="stmt">SIGNAL</literal>,
        it is necessary to resort to workarounds such as deliberately
        referring to a nonexistent table to cause a routine to return an
        error.

No privileges are required to execute the
        <literal role="stmt">SIGNAL</literal> statement.

To retrieve information from the diagnostics area, use the
        <literal role="stmt">GET DIAGNOSTICS</literal> statement (see
        <xref linkend="get-diagnostics" />). For information about the
        diagnostics area, see <xref linkend="diagnostics-area" />.

syntax.programlisting:
>
SIGNAL <replaceable>condition_value</replaceable>
    [SET <replaceable>signal_information_item</replaceable>
    [, <replaceable>signal_information_item</replaceable>] ...]

<replaceable>condition_value</replaceable>: {
    SQLSTATE [VALUE] <replaceable>sqlstate_value</replaceable>
  | <replaceable>condition_name</replaceable>
}

<replaceable>signal_information_item</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>condition_information_item_name</replaceable> = <replaceable>simple_value_specification</replaceable>

<replaceable>condition_information_item_name</replaceable>: {
    CLASS_ORIGIN
  | SUBCLASS_ORIGIN
  | MESSAGE_TEXT
  | MYSQL_ERRNO
  | CONSTRAINT_CATALOG
  | CONSTRAINT_SCHEMA
  | CONSTRAINT_NAME
  | CATALOG_NAME
  | SCHEMA_NAME
  | TABLE_NAME
  | COLUMN_NAME
  | CURSOR_NAME
}

<replaceable>condition_name</replaceable>, <replaceable>simple_value_specification</replaceable>:
    (see following discussion)

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">ALTER DATABASE</literal> enables you to
      change the overall characteristics of a database. These
      characteristics are stored in the data dictionary. To use
      <literal role="stmt">ALTER DATABASE</literal>, you need the
      <literal role="priv">ALTER</literal> privilege on the database.
      <literal condition="alter-database" role="stmt">ALTER
      SCHEMA</literal> is a synonym for <literal role="stmt">ALTER
      DATABASE</literal>.

The database name can be omitted from the first syntax, in which
      case the statement applies to the default database.

The <literal>CHARACTER SET</literal> clause changes the default
      database character set. The <literal>COLLATE</literal> clause
      changes the default database collation. <xref linkend="charset" />,
      discusses character set and collation names.

You can see what character sets and collations are available
      using, respectively, the <literal role="stmt">SHOW CHARACTER
      SET</literal> and <literal role="stmt">SHOW COLLATION</literal>
      statements. See <xref linkend="show-character-set" />, and
      <xref linkend="show-collation" />, for more information.

If you change the default character set or collation for a
      database, stored routines that use the database defaults must be
      dropped and recreated so that they use the new defaults. (In a
      stored routine, variables with character data types use the
      database defaults if the character set or collation are not
      specified explicitly. See <xref linkend="create-procedure" />.)

The <literal>DEFAULT ENCRYPTION</literal> clause, introduced in
      MySQL 8.0.16, defines the default database encryption, which is
      inherited by tables created in the database. Changing the default
      encryption of the database does not alter the encryption of
      existing tables associated with the schema. Only newly-created
      tables inherit the default database encryption. An <literal>ALTER
      DATABASE</literal> statement executed without a <literal>DEFAULT
      ENCRYPTION</literal> clause retains the existing default database
      encryption. If the
      <literal role="sysvar">table_encryption_privilege_check</literal>
      variable is enabled, the
      <literal role="priv">TABLE_ENCRYPTION_ADMIN</literal> privilege is
      required to specify a default encryption setting that differs from
      the <literal role="sysvar">default_table_encryption</literal>
      setting. For more information, see
      <xref linkend="innodb-schema-tablespace-encryption-default" />.

syntax.programlisting:
>
ALTER {DATABASE | SCHEMA} [<replaceable>db_name</replaceable>]
    <replaceable>alter_specification</replaceable> ...

<replaceable>alter_specification</replaceable>:
    [DEFAULT] CHARACTER SET [=] <replaceable>charset_name</replaceable>
  | [DEFAULT] COLLATE [=] <replaceable>collation_name</replaceable>
  | DEFAULT ENCRYPTION [=] {'Y' | 'N'}

description.para:
The <literal role="stmt">ALTER EVENT</literal> statement changes
      one or more of the characteristics of an existing event without
      the need to drop and recreate it. The syntax for each of the
      <literal>DEFINER</literal>, <literal>ON SCHEDULE</literal>,
      <literal>ON COMPLETION</literal>, <literal>COMMENT</literal>,
      <literal>ENABLE</literal> / <literal>DISABLE</literal>, and
      <literal role="stmt">DO</literal> clauses is exactly the same as
      when used with <literal role="stmt">CREATE EVENT</literal>. (See
      <xref linkend="create-event" />.)

Any user can alter an event defined on a database for which that
      user has the <literal role="priv">EVENT</literal> privilege. When
      a user executes a successful <literal role="stmt">ALTER
      EVENT</literal> statement, that user becomes the definer for the
      affected event.

<literal role="stmt">ALTER EVENT</literal> works only with an
      existing event:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>ALTER EVENT no_such_event </userinput>
     >     <userinput>ON SCHEDULE </userinput>
     >       <userinput>EVERY '2:3' DAY_HOUR;</userinput>
<errortext>ERROR 1517 (HY000): Unknown event 'no_such_event'</errortext>

syntax.programlisting:
>
ALTER
    [DEFINER = <replaceable>user</replaceable>]
    EVENT <replaceable>event_name</replaceable>
    [ON SCHEDULE <replaceable>schedule</replaceable>]
    [ON COMPLETION [NOT] PRESERVE]
    [RENAME TO <replaceable>new_event_name</replaceable>]
    [ENABLE | DISABLE | DISABLE ON SLAVE]
    [COMMENT '<replaceable>string</replaceable>']
    [DO <replaceable>event_body</replaceable>]

description.para:
This statement can be used to change the characteristics of a
      stored function. More than one change may be specified in an
      <literal role="stmt">ALTER FUNCTION</literal> statement. However,
      you cannot change the parameters or body of a stored function
      using this statement; to make such changes, you must drop and
      re-create the function using <literal role="stmt">DROP
      FUNCTION</literal> and <literal role="stmt">CREATE
      FUNCTION</literal>.

You must have the <literal role="priv">ALTER ROUTINE</literal>
      privilege for the function. (That privilege is granted
      automatically to the function creator.) If binary logging is
      enabled, the <literal role="stmt">ALTER FUNCTION</literal>
      statement might also require the
      <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege, as described in
      <xref linkend="stored-programs-logging" />.

syntax.programlisting:
>
ALTER FUNCTION <replaceable>func_name</replaceable> [<replaceable>characteristic</replaceable> ...]

<replaceable>characteristic</replaceable>:
    COMMENT '<replaceable>string</replaceable>'
  | LANGUAGE SQL
  | { CONTAINS SQL | NO SQL | READS SQL DATA | MODIFIES SQL DATA }
  | SQL SECURITY { DEFINER | INVOKER }

description.para:
<literal>ALTER INSTANCE</literal> defines actions applicable to a
      MySQL server instance. The statement supports these actions:

itemizedlist.para: <literal>ALTER INSTANCE ROTATE INNODB MASTER KEY</literal>

This action rotates the master encryption key used for
          <literal>InnoDB</literal> tablespace encryption. Key rotation
          requires the
          <literal role="priv">ENCRYPTION_KEY_ADMIN</literal> or
          <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege. To perform
          this action, a keyring plugin must be installed and
          configured. For instructions, see <xref linkend="keyring" />.

<literal>ALTER INSTANCE ROTATE INNODB MASTER KEY</literal>
          supports concurrent DML. However, it cannot be run
          concurrently with
          <literal condition="create-table" role="stmt">CREATE TABLE ...
          ENCRYPTION</literal> or
          <literal condition="alter-table" role="stmt">ALTER TABLE ...
          ENCRYPTION</literal> operations, and locks are taken to
          prevent conflicts that could arise from concurrent execution
          of these statements. If one of the conflicting statements is
          running, it must complete before another can proceed.

<literal>ALTER INSTANCE ROTATE INNODB MASTER KEY</literal>
          statements are written to the binary log so that they can be
          executed on replicated servers.

For additional <literal>ALTER INSTANCE ROTATE INNODB MASTER
          KEY</literal> usage information, see
          <xref linkend="innodb-data-encryption" />.
<literal>ALTER INSTANCE ROTATE BINLOG MASTER KEY</literal>

This action rotates the binary log master key used for binary
          log encryption. Key rotation for the binary log master key
          requires the
          <literal role="priv">BINLOG_ENCRYPTION_ADMIN</literal> or
          <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege. The statement
          cannot be used if the
          <literal role="sysvar">binlog_encryption</literal> system
          variable is set to <literal>OFF</literal>. To perform this
          action, a keyring plugin must be installed and configured. For
          instructions, see <xref linkend="keyring" />.

<literal>ALTER INSTANCE ROTATE BINLOG MASTER KEY</literal>
          actions are not written to the binary log and are not executed
          on replication slaves. Binary log master key rotation can
          therefore be carried out in replication environments including
          a mix of MySQL versions. To schedule regular rotation of the
          binary log master key on all applicable master and slave
          servers, you can enable the MySQL Event Scheduler on each
          server and issue the <literal>ALTER INSTANCE ROTATE BINLOG
          MASTER KEY</literal> statement using a
          <literal role="stmt">CREATE EVENT</literal> statement. If you
          rotate the binary log master key because you suspect that the
          current or any of the previous binary log master keys might
          have been compromised, issue the statement on every applicable
          master and slave server, which enables you to verify immediate
          compliance.

For additional <literal>ALTER INSTANCE ROTATE BINLOG MASTER
          KEY</literal> usage information, including what to do if the
          process does not complete correctly or is interrupted by an
          unexpected server halt, see
          <xref linkend="replication-binlog-encryption" />.
<literal>ALTER INSTANCE RELOAD TLS</literal>

This action reconfigures the SSL context from the current
          values of the system variables that define the context. It
          also updates the status variables that reflect the active
          context values. This action requires the
          <literal role="priv">CONNECTION_ADMIN</literal> privilege.

By default, the <literal>RELOAD TLS</literal> action rolls
          back with an error and has no effect if the configuration
          values do not permit creation of a new SSL context. The
          previous context values continue to be used for new
          connections.

If the optional <literal>NO ROLLBACK ON ERROR</literal> clause
          is given and a new context cannot be created, rollback does
          not occur. Instead, a warning is generated and SSL is disabled
          for new connections.

<literal>ALTER INSTANCE RELOAD TLS</literal> statements are
          not written to the binary log (and thus are not replicated).
          SSL configuration is local and depends on local files not
          necessarily present on all servers involved.

For additional information about reconfiguring the SSL
          context, including which system and status variables are
          context-related, see
          <xref linkend="using-encrypted-connections-server-side-runtime-configuration" />.

syntax.programlisting:
>
ALTER INSTANCE <replaceable>instance_action</replaceable>

<replaceable>instance_action</replaceable>: {
    ROTATE INNODB MASTER KEY
  | ROTATE BINLOG MASTER KEY
  | RELOAD TLS [NO ROLLBACK ON ERROR]
}

description.para:
This statement adds an <literal>UNDO</literal> file named
      '<replaceable>file_name</replaceable>' to an existing log file
      group <replaceable>logfile_group</replaceable>. An
      <literal role="stmt">ALTER LOGFILE GROUP</literal> statement has
      one and only one <literal>ADD UNDOFILE</literal> clause. No
      <literal>DROP UNDOFILE</literal> clause is currently supported.

The optional <literal>INITIAL_SIZE</literal> parameter sets the
      <literal>UNDO</literal> file's initial size in bytes; if not
      specified, the initial size defaults to 134217728 (128 MB). You
      may optionally follow <replaceable>size</replaceable> with a
      one-letter abbreviation for an order of magnitude, similar to
      those used in <filename>my.cnf</filename>. Generally, this is one
      of the letters <literal>M</literal> (megabytes) or
      <literal>G</literal> (gigabytes). (Bug #13116514, Bug #16104705,
      Bug #62858)

On 32-bit systems, the maximum supported value for
      <literal>INITIAL_SIZE</literal> is 4294967296 (4 GB). (Bug #29186)

The minimum allowed value for <literal>INITIAL_SIZE</literal> is
      1048576 (1 MB). (Bug #29574)

The <literal>ENGINE</literal> parameter (required) determines the
      storage engine which is used by this log file group, with
      <replaceable>engine_name</replaceable> being the name of the
      storage engine. Currently, the only accepted values for
      <replaceable>engine_name</replaceable> are
      <quote><literal role="se">NDBCLUSTER</literal></quote> and
      <quote><literal role="se">NDB</literal></quote>. The two values
      are equivalent.

syntax.programlisting:
>
ALTER LOGFILE GROUP <replaceable>logfile_group</replaceable>
    ADD UNDOFILE '<replaceable>file_name</replaceable>'
    [INITIAL_SIZE [=] <replaceable>size</replaceable>]
    [WAIT]
    ENGINE [=] <replaceable>engine_name</replaceable>

description.para:
This statement can be used to change the characteristics of a
      stored procedure. More than one change may be specified in an
      <literal role="stmt">ALTER PROCEDURE</literal> statement. However,
      you cannot change the parameters or body of a stored procedure
      using this statement; to make such changes, you must drop and
      re-create the procedure using <literal role="stmt">DROP
      PROCEDURE</literal> and <literal role="stmt">CREATE
      PROCEDURE</literal>.

You must have the <literal role="priv">ALTER ROUTINE</literal>
      privilege for the procedure. By default, that privilege is granted
      automatically to the procedure creator. This behavior can be
      changed by disabling the
      <literal role="sysvar">automatic_sp_privileges</literal> system
      variable. See <xref linkend="stored-routines-privileges" />.

syntax.programlisting:
>
ALTER PROCEDURE <replaceable>proc_name</replaceable> [<replaceable>characteristic</replaceable> ...]

<replaceable>characteristic</replaceable>:
    COMMENT '<replaceable>string</replaceable>'
  | LANGUAGE SQL
  | { CONTAINS SQL | NO SQL | READS SQL DATA | MODIFIES SQL DATA }
  | SQL SECURITY { DEFINER | INVOKER }

description.para:
Alters the server information for
      <literal><replaceable>server_name</replaceable></literal>,
      adjusting any of the options permitted in the
      <literal role="stmt">CREATE SERVER</literal> statement. The
      corresponding fields in the <literal>mysql.servers</literal> table
      are updated accordingly. This statement requires the
      <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege.

<literal role="stmt">ALTER TABLE</literal> changes the structure
      of a table. For example, you can add or delete columns, create or
      destroy indexes, change the type of existing columns, or rename
      columns or the table itself. You can also change characteristics
      such as the storage engine used for the table or the table
      comment.

itemizedlist.para:
To use <literal role="stmt">ALTER TABLE</literal>, you need
          <literal role="priv">ALTER</literal>,
          <literal role="priv">CREATE</literal>, and
          <literal role="priv">INSERT</literal> privileges for the
          table. Renaming a table requires
          <literal role="priv">ALTER</literal> and
          <literal role="priv">DROP</literal> on the old table,
          <literal role="priv">ALTER</literal>,
          <literal role="priv">CREATE</literal>, and
          <literal role="priv">INSERT</literal> on the new table.

Following the table name, specify the alterations to be made.
          If none are given, <literal role="stmt">ALTER TABLE</literal>
          does nothing.

The syntax for many of the permissible alterations is similar
          to clauses of the <literal role="stmt">CREATE TABLE</literal>
          statement. <replaceable>column_definition</replaceable>
          clauses use the same syntax for <literal>ADD</literal> and
          <literal>CHANGE</literal> as for <literal role="stmt">CREATE
          TABLE</literal>. For more information, see
          <xref linkend="create-table" />.

The word <literal>COLUMN</literal> is optional and can be
          omitted, except for <literal>RENAME COLUMN</literal> (to
          distinguish a column-renaming operation from the
          <literal>RENAME</literal> table-renaming operation).

Multiple <literal>ADD</literal>, <literal>ALTER</literal>,
          <literal>DROP</literal>, and <literal>CHANGE</literal> clauses
          are permitted in a single <literal role="stmt">ALTER
          TABLE</literal> statement, separated by commas. This is a
          MySQL extension to standard SQL, which permits only one of
          each clause per <literal role="stmt">ALTER TABLE</literal>
          statement. For example, to drop multiple columns in a single
          statement, do this:

itemizedlist.programlisting:
>
ALTER TABLE t2 DROP COLUMN c, DROP COLUMN d;

itemizedlist.para:
If a storage engine does not support an attempted
          <literal role="stmt">ALTER TABLE</literal> operation, a
          warning may result. Such warnings can be displayed with
          <literal role="stmt">SHOW WARNINGS</literal>. See
          <xref linkend="show-warnings" />. For information on
          troubleshooting <literal role="stmt">ALTER TABLE</literal>,
          see <xref linkend="alter-table-problems" />.

For information about generated columns, see
          <xref linkend="alter-table-generated-columns" />.

For usage examples, see
          <xref linkend="alter-table-examples" />.

<literal>InnoDB</literal> in MySQL 8.0.17 and later supports
          addition of multi-valued indexes on JSON columns using a
          <replaceable>key_part</replaceable> specification can take the
          form <literal>(CAST <replaceable>json_path</replaceable> AS
          <replaceable>type</replaceable> ARRAY)</literal>. See
          <xref linkend="create-index-multi-valued" />, for detailed
          information regarding multi-valued index creation and usage
          of, as well as restrictions and limitations on multi-valued
          indexes.

With the <literal role="cfunc">mysql_info()</literal> C API
          function, you can find out how many rows were copied by
          <literal role="stmt">ALTER TABLE</literal>. See
          <xref linkend="mysql-info" />.

syntax.programlisting:
>
ALTER TABLE <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>
    [<replaceable>alter_specification</replaceable> [, <replaceable>alter_specification</replaceable>] ...]
    [<replaceable>partition_options</replaceable>]

<replaceable>alter_specification</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>table_options</replaceable>
  | ADD [COLUMN] <replaceable>col_name</replaceable> <replaceable>column_definition</replaceable>
        [FIRST | AFTER <replaceable>col_name</replaceable>]
  | ADD [COLUMN] (<replaceable>col_name</replaceable> <replaceable>column_definition</replaceable>,...)
  | ADD {INDEX|KEY} [<replaceable>index_name</replaceable>]
        [<replaceable>index_type</replaceable>] (<replaceable>key_part</replaceable>,...) [<replaceable>index_option</replaceable>] ...
  | ADD {FULLTEXT|SPATIAL} [INDEX|KEY] [<replaceable>index_name</replaceable>]
        (<replaceable>key_part</replaceable>,...) [<replaceable>index_option</replaceable>] ...
  | ADD [CONSTRAINT [<replaceable>symbol</replaceable>]] PRIMARY KEY
        [<replaceable>index_type</replaceable>] (<replaceable>key_part</replaceable>,...)
        [<replaceable>index_option</replaceable>] ...
  | ADD [CONSTRAINT [<replaceable>symbol</replaceable>]] UNIQUE [INDEX|KEY]
        [<replaceable>index_name</replaceable>] [<replaceable>index_type</replaceable>] (<replaceable>key_part</replaceable>,...)
        [<replaceable>index_option</replaceable>] ...
  | ADD [CONSTRAINT [<replaceable>symbol</replaceable>]] FOREIGN KEY
        [<replaceable>index_name</replaceable>] (<replaceable>col_name</replaceable>,...)
        <replaceable>reference_definition</replaceable>
  | ADD [CONSTRAINT [<replaceable>symbol</replaceable>]] CHECK (<replaceable>expr</replaceable>) [[NOT] ENFORCED]
  | DROP {CHECK|CONSTRAINT} <replaceable>symbol</replaceable>
  | ALTER {CHECK|CONSTRAINT} <replaceable>symbol</replaceable> [NOT] ENFORCED
  | ALGORITHM [=] {DEFAULT|INSTANT|INPLACE|COPY}
  | ALTER [COLUMN] <replaceable>col_name</replaceable>
        {SET DEFAULT {<replaceable>literal</replaceable> | (<replaceable>expr</replaceable>)} | DROP DEFAULT}
  | ALTER INDEX <replaceable>index_name</replaceable> {VISIBLE | INVISIBLE}
  | CHANGE [COLUMN] <replaceable>old_col_name</replaceable> <replaceable>new_col_name</replaceable> <replaceable>column_definition</replaceable>
        [FIRST|AFTER <replaceable>col_name</replaceable>]
  | [DEFAULT] CHARACTER SET [=] <replaceable>charset_name</replaceable> [COLLATE [=] <replaceable>collation_name</replaceable>]
  | CONVERT TO CHARACTER SET <replaceable>charset_name</replaceable> [COLLATE <replaceable>collation_name</replaceable>]
  | {DISABLE|ENABLE} KEYS
  | {DISCARD|IMPORT} TABLESPACE
  | DROP [COLUMN] <replaceable>col_name</replaceable>
  | DROP {INDEX|KEY} <replaceable>index_name</replaceable>
  | DROP PRIMARY KEY
  | DROP FOREIGN KEY <replaceable>fk_symbol</replaceable>
  | FORCE
  | LOCK [=] {DEFAULT|NONE|SHARED|EXCLUSIVE}
  | MODIFY [COLUMN] <replaceable>col_name</replaceable> <replaceable>column_definition</replaceable>
        [FIRST | AFTER <replaceable>col_name</replaceable>]
  | ORDER BY <replaceable>col_name</replaceable> [, <replaceable>col_name</replaceable>] ...
  | RENAME COLUMN <replaceable>old_col_name</replaceable> TO <replaceable>new_col_name</replaceable>
  | RENAME {INDEX|KEY} <replaceable>old_index_name</replaceable> TO <replaceable>new_index_name</replaceable>
  | RENAME [TO|AS] <replaceable>new_tbl_name</replaceable>
  | {WITHOUT|WITH} VALIDATION

<replaceable>partition_options</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>partition_option</replaceable> [<replaceable>partition_option</replaceable>] ...

<replaceable>partition_option</replaceable>:
    ADD PARTITION (<replaceable>partition_definition</replaceable>)
  | DROP PARTITION <replaceable>partition_names</replaceable>
  | DISCARD PARTITION {<replaceable>partition_names</replaceable> | ALL} TABLESPACE
  | IMPORT PARTITION {<replaceable>partition_names</replaceable> | ALL} TABLESPACE
  | TRUNCATE PARTITION {<replaceable>partition_names</replaceable> | ALL}
  | COALESCE PARTITION <replaceable>number</replaceable>
  | REORGANIZE PARTITION <replaceable>partition_names</replaceable> INTO (<replaceable>partition_definitions</replaceable>)
  | EXCHANGE PARTITION <replaceable>partition_name</replaceable> WITH TABLE <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> [{WITH|WITHOUT} VALIDATION]
  | ANALYZE PARTITION {<replaceable>partition_names</replaceable> | ALL}
  | CHECK PARTITION {<replaceable>partition_names</replaceable> | ALL}
  | OPTIMIZE PARTITION {<replaceable>partition_names</replaceable> | ALL}
  | REBUILD PARTITION {<replaceable>partition_names</replaceable> | ALL}
  | REPAIR PARTITION {<replaceable>partition_names</replaceable> | ALL}
  | REMOVE PARTITIONING

<replaceable>key_part</replaceable>: {<replaceable>col_name</replaceable> [(<replaceable>length</replaceable>)] | (<replaceable>expr</replaceable>)} [ASC | DESC]

<replaceable>index_type</replaceable>:
    USING {BTREE | HASH}

<replaceable>index_option</replaceable>:
    KEY_BLOCK_SIZE [=] <replaceable>value</replaceable>
  | <replaceable>index_type</replaceable>
  | WITH PARSER <replaceable>parser_name</replaceable>
  | COMMENT '<replaceable>string</replaceable>'
  | {VISIBLE | INVISIBLE}

<replaceable>table_options</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>table_option</replaceable> [[,] <replaceable>table_option</replaceable>] ...

<replaceable>table_option</replaceable>:
    AUTO_INCREMENT [=] <replaceable>value</replaceable>
  | AVG_ROW_LENGTH [=] <replaceable>value</replaceable>
  | [DEFAULT] CHARACTER SET [=] <replaceable>charset_name</replaceable>
  | CHECKSUM [=] {0 | 1}
  | [DEFAULT] COLLATE [=] <replaceable>collation_name</replaceable>
  | COMMENT [=] '<replaceable>string</replaceable>'
  | COMPRESSION [=] {'ZLIB'|'LZ4'|'NONE'}
  | CONNECTION [=] '<replaceable>connect_string</replaceable>'
  | {DATA|INDEX} DIRECTORY [=] '<replaceable>absolute path to directory</replaceable>'
  | DELAY_KEY_WRITE [=] {0 | 1}
  | ENCRYPTION [=] {'Y' | 'N'}
  | ENGINE [=] <replaceable>engine_name</replaceable>
  | INSERT_METHOD [=] { NO | FIRST | LAST }
  | KEY_BLOCK_SIZE [=] <replaceable>value</replaceable>
  | MAX_ROWS [=] <replaceable>value</replaceable>
  | MIN_ROWS [=] <replaceable>value</replaceable>
  | PACK_KEYS [=] {0 | 1 | DEFAULT}
  | PASSWORD [=] '<replaceable>string</replaceable>'
  | ROW_FORMAT [=] {DEFAULT|DYNAMIC|FIXED|COMPRESSED|REDUNDANT|COMPACT}
  | STATS_AUTO_RECALC [=] {DEFAULT|0|1}
  | STATS_PERSISTENT [=] {DEFAULT|0|1}
  | STATS_SAMPLE_PAGES [=] <replaceable>value</replaceable>
  | TABLESPACE <replaceable>tablespace_name</replaceable> [STORAGE {DISK|MEMORY}]
  | UNION [=] (<replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>[,<replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>]...)

<replaceable>partition_options</replaceable>:
    (see <literal role="stmt">CREATE TABLE</literal> options)

description.para:
This statement is used with <literal>NDB</literal> and
      <literal>InnoDB</literal> tablespaces. It can be used to add a new
      data file to, or to drop a data file from an
      <literal>NDB</literal> tablespace. It can also be used to rename
      an NDB Cluster Disk Data tablespace, rename an
      <literal>InnoDB</literal> general tablespace, encrypt an
      <literal>InnoDB</literal> general tablespace, or mark an
      <literal>InnoDB</literal> undo tablespace as active or inactive.

The <literal>UNDO</literal> keyword, introduced in MySQL 8.0.14,
      is used with the <literal>SET {ACTIVE|INACTIVE}</literal> clause
      to mark an <literal>InnoDB</literal> undo tablespace as active or
      inactive. For more information, see
      <xref linkend="innodb-undo-tablespaces" />.

The <literal>ADD DATAFILE</literal> variant enables you to specify
      an initial size for an <literal>NDB</literal> Disk Data tablespace
      using an <literal>INITIAL_SIZE</literal> clause, where
      <replaceable>size</replaceable> is measured in bytes; the default
      value is 134217728 (128 MB). You may optionally follow
      <replaceable>size</replaceable> with a one-letter abbreviation for
      an order of magnitude, similar to those used in
      <filename>my.cnf</filename>. Generally, this is one of the letters
      <literal>M</literal> (megabytes) or <literal>G</literal>
      (gigabytes).

On 32-bit systems, the maximum supported value for
      <literal>INITIAL_SIZE</literal> is 4294967296 (4 GB). (Bug #29186)

<literal>INITIAL_SIZE</literal> is rounded, explicitly, as for
      <literal role="stmt">CREATE TABLESPACE</literal>.

Once a data file has been created, its size cannot be changed;
      however, you can add more data files to an NDB tablespace using
      additional <literal>ALTER TABLESPACE ... ADD DATAFILE</literal>
      statements.

When <literal>ALTER TABLESPACE ... ADD DATAFILE</literal> is used
      with <literal>ENGINE = NDB</literal>, a data file is created on
      each Cluster data node, but only one row is generated in the
      <literal role="is">INFORMATION_SCHEMA.FILES</literal> table. See
      the description of this table, as well as
      <xref linkend="mysql-cluster-disk-data-objects" />, for more
      information. <literal>ADD DATAFILE</literal> is not supported with
      <literal>InnoDB</literal> tablespaces.

Using <literal>DROP DATAFILE</literal> with
      <literal role="stmt">ALTER TABLESPACE</literal> drops the data
      file '<replaceable>file_name</replaceable>' from an NDB
      tablespace. You cannot drop a data file from a tablespace which is
      in use by any table; in other words, the data file must be empty
      (no extents used). See
      <xref linkend="mysql-cluster-disk-data-objects" />. In addition,
      any data file to be dropped must previously have been added to the
      tablespace with <literal role="stmt">CREATE TABLESPACE</literal>
      or <literal role="stmt">ALTER TABLESPACE</literal>. <literal>DROP
      DATAFILE</literal> is not supported with <literal>InnoDB</literal>
      tablespaces.

<literal>WAIT</literal> is parsed but otherwise ignored. It is
      intended for future expansion.

The <literal>ENGINE</literal> clause, which specifies the storage
      engine used by the tablespace, is deprecated and will be removed
      in a future release. The tablespace storage engine is known by the
      data dictionary, making the <literal>ENGINE</literal> clause
      obsolete. If the storage engine is specified, it must match the
      tablespace storage engine defined in the data dictionary. The only
      values for <replaceable>engine_name</replaceable> compatible with
      <literal role="se">NDB</literal> tablespaces are
      <literal>NDB</literal> and <literal>NDBCLUSTER</literal>.

<literal>RENAME TO</literal> operations are implicitly performed
      in <literal role="sysvar">autocommit</literal> mode, regardless of
      the <literal role="sysvar">autocommit</literal> setting.

A <literal>RENAME TO</literal> operation cannot be performed while
      <literal role="stmt">LOCK TABLES</literal> or
      <literal condition="flush" role="stmt">FLUSH TABLES WITH READ
      LOCK</literal> is in effect for tables that reside in the
      tablespace.

Exclusive <link linkend="glos_metadata_lock">metadata locks</link>
      are taken on tables that reside in a general tablespace while the
      tablespace is renamed, which prevents concurrent DDL. Concurrent
      DML is supported.

The <literal role="priv">CREATE TABLESPACE</literal> privilege is
      required to rename an <literal>InnoDB</literal> general
      tablespace.

The <literal>ENCRYPTION</literal> clause enables or disables
      page-level data encryption for an <literal>InnoDB</literal>
      general tablespace or the <literal>mysql</literal> system
      tablespace. Encryption support for general tablespaces was
      introduced in MySQL 8.0.13. Encryption support for the
      <literal>mysql</literal> system tablespace was introduced in MySQL
      8.0.16.

A keyring plugin must be installed and configured before
      encryption can be enabled.

As of MySQL 8.0.16, if the
      <literal role="sysvar">table_encryption_privilege_check</literal>
      variable is enabled, the
      <literal role="priv">TABLE_ENCRYPTION_ADMIN</literal> privilege is
      required to alter a general tablespace with an
      <literal>ENCRYPTION</literal> clause setting that differs from the
      <literal role="sysvar">default_table_encryption</literal> setting.

Enabling encryption for a general tablespace fails if any table in
      the tablespace belongs to a schema defined with
      <literal condition="create-database" role="stmt">DEFAULT
      ENCRYPTION='N'</literal>. Similarly, disabling encryption fails if
      any table in the general tablespace belongs to a schema defined
      with <literal condition="create-database" role="stmt">DEFAULT
      ENCRYPTION='Y'</literal>. The
      <literal condition="create-database" role="stmt">DEFAULT
      ENCRYPTION</literal> schema option was introduced in MySQL 8.0.16.

If an <literal role="stmt">ALTER TABLESPACE</literal> statement
      executed on a general tablespace does not include an
      <literal>ENCRYPTION</literal> clause, the tablespace retains its
      current encryption status, regardless of the
      <literal role="sysvar">default_table_encryption</literal> setting.

When a general tablespace or the <literal>mysql</literal> system
      tablespace is encrypted, all tables residing in the tablespace are
      encrypted. Likewise, a table created in an encrypted tablespace is
      encrypted.

The <literal>INPLACE</literal> algorithm is used when altering the
      <literal>ENCRYPTION</literal> attribute of a general tablespace or
      the <literal>mysql</literal> system tablespace. The
      <literal>INPLACE</literal> algorithm permits concurrent DML on
      tables that reside in the tablespace. Concurrent DDL is blocked.

For more information, see
      <xref linkend="innodb-data-encryption" />.

syntax.programlisting:
>
ALTER [UNDO] TABLESPACE <replaceable>tablespace_name</replaceable>
  <emphasis>NDB only:</emphasis>  
    {ADD|DROP} DATAFILE '<replaceable>file_name</replaceable>'
    [INITIAL_SIZE [=] size]
    [WAIT]
  <emphasis>InnoDB and NDB:</emphasis>
    [RENAME TO <replaceable>tablespace_name</replaceable>] 
  <emphasis>InnoDB only:</emphasis>
    [SET {ACTIVE|INACTIVE}]
    [ENCRYPTION [=] {'Y' | 'N'}]
  <emphasis>InnoDB and NDB:</emphasis>
    [ENGINE [=] <replaceable>engine_name</replaceable>]

description.para:
This statement changes the definition of a view, which must exist.
      The syntax is similar to that for <literal role="stmt">CREATE
      VIEW</literal> see <xref linkend="create-view" />). This statement
      requires the <literal role="priv">CREATE VIEW</literal> and
      <literal role="priv">DROP</literal> privileges for the view, and
      some privilege for each column referred to in the
      <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> statement.
      <literal role="stmt">ALTER VIEW</literal> is permitted only to the
      definer or users with the
      <literal role="priv">SET_USER_ID</literal> or
      <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege.

syntax.programlisting:
>
ALTER
    [ALGORITHM = {UNDEFINED | MERGE | TEMPTABLE}]
    [DEFINER = <replaceable>user</replaceable>]
    [SQL SECURITY { DEFINER | INVOKER }]
    VIEW <replaceable>view_name</replaceable> [(<replaceable>column_list</replaceable>)]
    AS <replaceable>select_statement</replaceable>
    [WITH [CASCADED | LOCAL] CHECK OPTION]

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">CREATE DATABASE</literal> creates a database
      with the given name. To use this statement, you need the
      <literal role="priv">CREATE</literal> privilege for the database.
      <literal condition="create-database" role="stmt">CREATE
      SCHEMA</literal> is a synonym for <literal role="stmt">CREATE
      DATABASE</literal>.

syntax.programlisting:
>
CREATE {DATABASE | SCHEMA} [IF NOT EXISTS] <replaceable>db_name</replaceable>
    [<replaceable>create_specification</replaceable>] ...

<replaceable>create_specification</replaceable>:
    [DEFAULT] CHARACTER SET [=] <replaceable>charset_name</replaceable>
  | [DEFAULT] COLLATE [=] <replaceable>collation_name</replaceable>
  | DEFAULT ENCRYPTION [=] {'Y' | 'N'}

description.para:
This statement creates and schedules a new event. The event will
      not run unless the Event Scheduler is enabled. For information
      about checking Event Scheduler status and enabling it if
      necessary, see <xref linkend="events-configuration" />.

<literal role="stmt">CREATE EVENT</literal> requires the
      <literal role="priv">EVENT</literal> privilege for the schema in
      which the event is to be created. If the
      <literal>DEFINER</literal> clause is present, the privileges
      required depend on the <replaceable>user</replaceable> value, as
      discussed in <xref linkend="stored-objects-security" />.

The minimum requirements for a valid <literal role="stmt">CREATE
      EVENT</literal> statement are as follows:

itemizedlist.para:
The keywords <literal role="stmt">CREATE EVENT</literal> plus
          an event name, which uniquely identifies the event in a
          database schema.

An <literal>ON SCHEDULE</literal> clause, which determines
          when and how often the event executes.

A <literal role="stmt">DO</literal> clause, which contains the
          SQL statement to be executed by an event.

description.para:
This is an example of a minimal <literal role="stmt">CREATE
      EVENT</literal> statement:

description.programlisting:
>
CREATE EVENT myevent
    ON SCHEDULE AT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP + INTERVAL 1 HOUR
    DO
      UPDATE myschema.mytable SET mycol = mycol + 1;

description.para:
The previous statement creates an event named
      <literal>myevent</literal>. This event executes oncemdashone
      hour following its creationmdashby running an SQL statement that
      increments the value of the <literal>myschema.mytable</literal>
      table's <literal>mycol</literal> column by 1.

The <replaceable>event_name</replaceable> must be a valid MySQL
      identifier with a maximum length of 64 characters. Event names are
      not case-sensitive, so you cannot have two events named
      <literal>myevent</literal> and <literal>MyEvent</literal> in the
      same schema. In general, the rules governing event names are the
      same as those for names of stored routines. See
      <xref linkend="identifiers" />.

An event is associated with a schema. If no schema is indicated as
      part of <replaceable>event_name</replaceable>, the default
      (current) schema is assumed. To create an event in a specific
      schema, qualify the event name with a schema using
      <literal><replaceable>schema_name</replaceable>.<replaceable>event_name</replaceable></literal>
      syntax.

syntax.programlisting:
>
CREATE
    [DEFINER = <replaceable>user</replaceable>]
    EVENT
    [IF NOT EXISTS]
    <replaceable>event_name</replaceable>
    ON SCHEDULE <replaceable>schedule</replaceable>
    [ON COMPLETION [NOT] PRESERVE]
    [ENABLE | DISABLE | DISABLE ON SLAVE]
    [COMMENT '<replaceable>string</replaceable>']
    DO <replaceable>event_body</replaceable>;

<replaceable>schedule</replaceable>:
    AT <replaceable>timestamp</replaceable> [+ INTERVAL <replaceable>interval</replaceable>] ...
  | EVERY <replaceable>interval</replaceable>
    [STARTS <replaceable>timestamp</replaceable> [+ INTERVAL <replaceable>interval</replaceable>] ...]
    [ENDS <replaceable>timestamp</replaceable> [+ INTERVAL <replaceable>interval</replaceable>] ...]

<replaceable>interval</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>quantity</replaceable> {YEAR | QUARTER | MONTH | DAY | HOUR | MINUTE |
              WEEK | SECOND | YEAR_MONTH | DAY_HOUR | DAY_MINUTE |
              DAY_SECOND | HOUR_MINUTE | HOUR_SECOND | MINUTE_SECOND}

description.para:
Normally, you create all indexes on a table at the time the table
      itself is created with <literal role="stmt">CREATE
      TABLE</literal>. See <xref linkend="create-table" />. This
      guideline is especially important for
      <literal role="se">InnoDB</literal> tables, where the primary key
      determines the physical layout of rows in the data file.
      <literal role="stmt">CREATE INDEX</literal> enables you to add
      indexes to existing tables.

<literal role="stmt">CREATE INDEX</literal> is mapped to an
      <literal role="stmt">ALTER TABLE</literal> statement to create
      indexes. See <xref linkend="alter-table" />.
      <literal role="stmt">CREATE INDEX</literal> cannot be used to
      create a <literal>PRIMARY KEY</literal>; use
      <literal role="stmt">ALTER TABLE</literal> instead. For more
      information about indexes, see <xref linkend="mysql-indexes" />.

syntax.programlisting:
>
CREATE [UNIQUE | FULLTEXT | SPATIAL] INDEX <replaceable>index_name</replaceable>
    [<replaceable>index_type</replaceable>]
    ON <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> (<replaceable>key_part</replaceable>,...)
    [<replaceable>index_option</replaceable>]
    [<replaceable>algorithm_option</replaceable> | <replaceable>lock_option</replaceable>] ...

<replaceable>key_part</replaceable>: {<replaceable>col_name</replaceable> [(<replaceable>length</replaceable>)] | (<replaceable>expr</replaceable>)} [ASC | DESC]

<replaceable>index_option</replaceable>:
    KEY_BLOCK_SIZE [=] <replaceable>value</replaceable>
  | <replaceable>index_type</replaceable>
  | WITH PARSER <replaceable>parser_name</replaceable>
  | COMMENT '<replaceable>string</replaceable>'
  | {VISIBLE | INVISIBLE}

<replaceable>index_type</replaceable>:
    USING {BTREE | HASH}

<replaceable>algorithm_option</replaceable>:
    ALGORITHM [=] {DEFAULT | INPLACE | COPY}

<replaceable>lock_option</replaceable>:
    LOCK [=] {DEFAULT | NONE | SHARED | EXCLUSIVE}

description.para:
This statement creates a new log file group named
      <replaceable>logfile_group</replaceable> having a single
      <literal>UNDO</literal> file named
      '<replaceable>undo_file</replaceable>'. A
      <literal role="stmt">CREATE LOGFILE GROUP</literal> statement has
      one and only one <literal>ADD UNDOFILE</literal> clause. For rules
      covering the naming of log file groups, see
      <xref linkend="identifiers" />.

There can be only one log file group per NDB Cluster instance at
      any given time.

The optional <literal>INITIAL_SIZE</literal> parameter sets the
      <literal>UNDO</literal> file's initial size; if not specified, it
      defaults to <literal>128M</literal> (128 megabytes). The optional
      <literal>UNDO_BUFFER_SIZE</literal> parameter sets the size used
      by the <literal>UNDO</literal> buffer for the log file group; The
      default value for <literal>UNDO_BUFFER_SIZE</literal> is
      <literal>8M</literal> (eight megabytes); this value cannot exceed
      the amount of system memory available. Both of these parameters
      are specified in bytes. You may optionally follow either or both
      of these with a one-letter abbreviation for an order of magnitude,
      similar to those used in <filename>my.cnf</filename>. Generally,
      this is one of the letters <literal>M</literal> (for megabytes)
      or <literal>G</literal> (for gigabytes).

Memory used for <literal>UNDO_BUFFER_SIZE</literal> comes from the
      global pool whose size is determined by the value of the
      <literal role="ndbparam:ndbd">SharedGlobalMemory</literal> data
      node configuration parameter. This includes any default value
      implied for this option by the setting of the
      <literal role="ndbparam:ndbd">InitialLogFileGroup</literal> data
      node configuration parameter.

The maximum permitted for <literal>UNDO_BUFFER_SIZE</literal> is
      629145600 (600 MB).

On 32-bit systems, the maximum supported value for
      <literal>INITIAL_SIZE</literal> is 4294967296 (4 GB). (Bug #29186)

The minimum allowed value for <literal>INITIAL_SIZE</literal> is
      1048576 (1 MB).

The <literal>ENGINE</literal> option determines the storage engine
      to be used by this log file group, with
      <replaceable>engine_name</replaceable> being the name of the
      storage engine. In MySQL current-series, this must be
      <literal role="se">NDB</literal> (or
      <literal role="se">NDBCLUSTER</literal>). If
      <literal>ENGINE</literal> is not set, MySQL tries to use the
      engine specified by the
      <literal role="sysvar">default_storage_engine</literal> server
      system variable (formerly
      <literal role="sysvar">storage_engine</literal>). In any case, if
      the engine is not specified as <literal role="se">NDB</literal> or
      <literal role="se">NDBCLUSTER</literal>, the <literal>CREATE
      LOGFILE GROUP</literal> statement appears to succeed but actually
      fails to create the log file group, as shown here:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>CREATE LOGFILE GROUP lg1</userinput>
    ->     <userinput>ADD UNDOFILE 'undo.dat' INITIAL_SIZE = 10M;</userinput>
Query OK, 0 rows affected, 1 warning (0.00 sec)

mysql> <userinput>SHOW WARNINGS;</userinput>
+-------+------+------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Level | Code | Message                                                                                        |
+-------+------+------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Error | 1478 | <errortext>Table storage engine 'InnoDB' does not support the create option 'TABLESPACE or LOGFILE GROUP'</errortext> |
+-------+------+------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
1 row in set (0.00 sec)

mysql> <userinput>DROP LOGFILE GROUP lg1 ENGINE = NDB;</userinput>            
<errortext>ERROR 1529 (HY000): Failed to drop LOGFILE GROUP</errortext>

mysql> <userinput>CREATE LOGFILE GROUP lg1</userinput>
    ->     <userinput>ADD UNDOFILE 'undo.dat' INITIAL_SIZE = 10M</userinput>
    ->     <userinput>ENGINE = NDB;</userinput>
Query OK, 0 rows affected (2.97 sec)

description.para:
The fact that the <literal>CREATE LOGFILE GROUP</literal>
      statement does not actually return an error when a
      non-<literal>NDB</literal> storage engine is named, but rather
      appears to succeed, is a known issue which we hope to address in a
      future release of NDB Cluster.

<replaceable>REDO_BUFFER_SIZE</replaceable>,
      <literal>NODEGROUP</literal>, <literal>WAIT</literal>, and
      <literal>COMMENT</literal> are parsed but ignored, and so have no
      effect in MySQL current-series. These options are intended for
      future expansion.

When used with <literal>ENGINE [=] NDB</literal>, a log file group
      and associated <literal>UNDO</literal> log file are created on
      each Cluster data node. You can verify that the
      <literal>UNDO</literal> files were created and obtain information
      about them by querying the
      <literal role="is">INFORMATION_SCHEMA.FILES</literal> table. For
      example:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SELECT LOGFILE_GROUP_NAME, LOGFILE_GROUP_NUMBER, EXTRA</userinput>
    -> <userinput>FROM INFORMATION_SCHEMA.FILES</userinput>
    -> <userinput>WHERE FILE_NAME = 'undo_10.dat';</userinput>
+--------------------+----------------------+----------------+
| LOGFILE_GROUP_NAME | LOGFILE_GROUP_NUMBER | EXTRA          |
+--------------------+----------------------+----------------+
| lg_3               |                   11 | CLUSTER_NODE=3 |
| lg_3               |                   11 | CLUSTER_NODE=4 |
+--------------------+----------------------+----------------+
2 rows in set (0.06 sec)

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">CREATE LOGFILE GROUP</literal> is useful only
      with Disk Data storage for NDB Cluster. See
      <xref linkend="mysql-cluster-disk-data" />.

syntax.programlisting:
>
CREATE LOGFILE GROUP <replaceable>logfile_group</replaceable>
    ADD UNDOFILE '<replaceable>undo_file</replaceable>'
    [INITIAL_SIZE [=] <replaceable>initial_size</replaceable>]
    [UNDO_BUFFER_SIZE [=] <replaceable>undo_buffer_size</replaceable>]
    [REDO_BUFFER_SIZE [=] <replaceable>redo_buffer_size</replaceable>]
    [NODEGROUP [=] <replaceable>nodegroup_id</replaceable>]
    [WAIT]
    [COMMENT [=] '<replaceable>string</replaceable>']
    ENGINE [=] <replaceable>engine_name</replaceable>

description.para:
These statements create stored routines. By default, a routine is
      associated with the default database. To associate the routine
      explicitly with a given database, specify the name as
      <replaceable>db_name.sp_name</replaceable> when you create it.

The <literal role="stmt">CREATE FUNCTION</literal> statement is
      also used in MySQL to support UDFs (user-defined functions). See
      <xref linkend="adding-functions" />. A UDF can be regarded as an
      external stored function. Stored functions share their namespace
      with UDFs. See <xref linkend="function-resolution" />, for the
      rules describing how the server interprets references to different
      kinds of functions.

To invoke a stored procedure, use the
      <literal role="stmt">CALL</literal> statement (see
      <xref linkend="call" />). To invoke a stored function, refer to it
      in an expression. The function returns a value during expression
      evaluation.

<literal role="stmt">CREATE PROCEDURE</literal> and
      <literal role="stmt">CREATE FUNCTION</literal> require the
      <literal role="priv">CREATE ROUTINE</literal> privilege. If the
      <literal>DEFINER</literal> clause is present, the privileges
      required depend on the <replaceable>user</replaceable> value, as
      discussed in <xref linkend="stored-objects-security" />. If binary
      logging is enabled, <literal role="stmt">CREATE FUNCTION</literal>
      might require the <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege,
      as discussed in <xref linkend="stored-programs-logging" />.

By default, MySQL automatically grants the
      <literal role="priv">ALTER ROUTINE</literal> and
      <literal role="priv">EXECUTE</literal> privileges to the routine
      creator. This behavior can be changed by disabling the
      <literal role="sysvar">automatic_sp_privileges</literal> system
      variable. See <xref linkend="stored-routines-privileges" />.

The <literal>DEFINER</literal> and <literal>SQL SECURITY</literal>
      clauses specify the security context to be used when checking
      access privileges at routine execution time, as described later in
      this section.

If the routine name is the same as the name of a built-in SQL
      function, a syntax error occurs unless you use a space between the
      name and the following parenthesis when defining the routine or
      invoking it later. For this reason, avoid using the names of
      existing SQL functions for your own stored routines.

The <literal role="sqlmode">IGNORE_SPACE</literal> SQL mode
      applies to built-in functions, not to stored routines. It is
      always permissible to have spaces after a stored routine name,
      regardless of whether
      <literal role="sqlmode">IGNORE_SPACE</literal> is enabled.

The parameter list enclosed within parentheses must always be
      present. If there are no parameters, an empty parameter list of
      <literal>()</literal> should be used. Parameter names are not case
      sensitive.

Each parameter is an <literal>IN</literal> parameter by default.
      To specify otherwise for a parameter, use the keyword
      <literal>OUT</literal> or <literal>INOUT</literal> before the
      parameter name.

An <literal>IN</literal> parameter passes a value into a
      procedure. The procedure might modify the value, but the
      modification is not visible to the caller when the procedure
      returns. An <literal>OUT</literal> parameter passes a value from
      the procedure back to the caller. Its initial value is
      <literal>NULL</literal> within the procedure, and its value is
      visible to the caller when the procedure returns. An
      <literal>INOUT</literal> parameter is initialized by the caller,
      can be modified by the procedure, and any change made by the
      procedure is visible to the caller when the procedure returns.

For each <literal>OUT</literal> or <literal>INOUT</literal>
      parameter, pass a user-defined variable in the
      <literal role="stmt">CALL</literal> statement that invokes the
      procedure so that you can obtain its value when the procedure
      returns. If you are calling the procedure from within another
      stored procedure or function, you can also pass a routine
      parameter or local routine variable as an <literal>OUT</literal>
      or <literal>INOUT</literal> parameter. If you are calling the
      procedure from within a trigger, you can also pass
      <literal>NEW.<replaceable>col_name</replaceable></literal> as an
      <literal>OUT</literal> or <literal>INOUT</literal> parameter.

For information about the effect of unhandled conditions on
      procedure parameters, see
      <xref linkend="conditions-and-parameters" />.

Routine parameters cannot be referenced in statements prepared
      within the routine; see
      <xref linkend="stored-program-restrictions" />.

The following example shows a simple stored procedure that uses an
      <literal>OUT</literal> parameter:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>delimiter //</userinput>

mysql> <userinput>CREATE PROCEDURE simpleproc (OUT param1 INT)</userinput>
    -> <userinput>BEGIN</userinput>
    ->   <userinput>SELECT COUNT(*) INTO param1 FROM t;</userinput>
    -> <userinput>END//</userinput>
Query OK, 0 rows affected (0.00 sec)

mysql> <userinput>delimiter ;</userinput>

mysql> <userinput>CALL simpleproc(@a);</userinput>
Query OK, 0 rows affected (0.00 sec)

mysql> <userinput>SELECT @a;</userinput>
+------+
| @a   |
+------+
| 3    |
+------+
1 row in set (0.00 sec)

description.para:
The example uses the <command>mysql</command> client
      <literal>delimiter</literal> command to change the statement
      delimiter from <literal>;</literal> to <literal>//</literal> while
      the procedure is being defined. This enables the
      <literal>;</literal> delimiter used in the procedure body to be
      passed through to the server rather than being interpreted by
      <command>mysql</command> itself. See
      <xref linkend="stored-programs-defining" />.

The <literal>RETURNS</literal> clause may be specified only for a
      <literal>FUNCTION</literal>, for which it is mandatory. It
      indicates the return type of the function, and the function body
      must contain a <literal>RETURN
      <replaceable>value</replaceable></literal> statement. If the
      <literal role="stmt">RETURN</literal> statement returns a value of
      a different type, the value is coerced to the proper type. For
      example, if a function specifies an
      <literal role="type">ENUM</literal> or
      <literal role="type">SET</literal> value in the
      <literal>RETURNS</literal> clause, but the
      <literal role="stmt">RETURN</literal> statement returns an
      integer, the value returned from the function is the string for
      the corresponding <literal role="type">ENUM</literal> member of
      set of <literal role="type">SET</literal> members.

The following example function takes a parameter, performs an
      operation using an SQL function, and returns the result. In this
      case, it is unnecessary to use <literal>delimiter</literal>
      because the function definition contains no internal
      <literal>;</literal> statement delimiters:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>CREATE FUNCTION hello (s CHAR(20))</userinput>
mysql> <userinput>RETURNS CHAR(50) DETERMINISTIC</userinput>
    -> <userinput>RETURN CONCAT('Hello, ',s,'!');</userinput>
Query OK, 0 rows affected (0.00 sec)

mysql> <userinput>SELECT hello('world');</userinput>
+----------------+
| hello('world') |
+----------------+
| Hello, world!  |
+----------------+
1 row in set (0.00 sec)

description.para:
Parameter types and function return types can be declared to use
      any valid data type. The <literal>COLLATE</literal> attribute can
      be used if preceded by a <literal>CHARACTER SET</literal>
      specification.

The <replaceable>routine_body</replaceable> consists of a valid
      SQL routine statement. This can be a simple statement such as
      <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> or
      <literal role="stmt">INSERT</literal>, or a compound statement
      written using <literal>BEGIN</literal> and <literal>END</literal>.
      Compound statements can contain declarations, loops, and other
      control structure statements. The syntax for these statements is
      described in <xref linkend="sql-compound-statements" />. In
      practice, stored functions tend to use compound statements, unless
      the body consists of a single
      <literal role="stmt">RETURN</literal> statement.

MySQL permits routines to contain DDL statements, such as
      <literal>CREATE</literal> and <literal>DROP</literal>. MySQL also
      permits stored procedures (but not stored functions) to contain
      SQL transaction statements such as
      <literal role="stmt">COMMIT</literal>. Stored functions may not
      contain statements that perform explicit or implicit commit or
      rollback. Support for these statements is not required by the SQL
      standard, which states that each DBMS vendor may decide whether to
      permit them.

Statements that return a result set can be used within a stored
      procedure but not within a stored function. This prohibition
