description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>ALTER TABLESPACE myts</userinput>
    ->     <userinput>DROP DATAFILE 'mydata-1.dat'</userinput>
    ->     <userinput>ENGINE=NDB;</userinput>

mysql> <userinput>DROP TABLESPACE myts;</userinput>

description.para:
This statement drops a trigger. The schema (database) name is
      optional. If the schema is omitted, the trigger is dropped from
      the default schema. <literal role="stmt">DROP TRIGGER</literal>
      requires the <literal role="priv">TRIGGER</literal> privilege for
      the table associated with the trigger.

Use <literal>IF EXISTS</literal> to prevent an error from
      occurring for a trigger that does not exist. A
      <literal>NOTE</literal> is generated for a nonexistent trigger
      when using <literal>IF EXISTS</literal>. See
      <xref linkend="show-warnings" />.
Triggers for a table are also dropped if you drop the table.

<literal role="stmt">DROP VIEW</literal> removes one or more
      views. You must have the <literal role="priv">DROP</literal>
      privilege for each view.

If any views named in the argument list do not exist, the
      statement fails with an error indicating by name which nonexisting
      views it was unable to drop, and no changes are made.

The <literal>IF EXISTS</literal> clause prevents an error from
      occurring for views that don't exist. When this clause is given, a
      <literal>NOTE</literal> is generated for each nonexistent view.
      See <xref linkend="show-warnings" />.

<literal>RESTRICT</literal> and <literal>CASCADE</literal>, if
      given, are parsed and ignored.

<literal role="stmt">RENAME TABLE</literal> renames one or more
      tables. You must have <literal role="priv">ALTER</literal> and
      <literal role="priv">DROP</literal> privileges for the original
      table, and <literal role="priv">CREATE</literal> and
      <literal role="priv">INSERT</literal> privileges for the new
      table.

For example, to rename a table named <literal>old_table</literal>
      to <literal>new_table</literal>, use this statement:

description.programlisting:
>
RENAME TABLE old_table TO new_table;

description.para:
That statement is equivalent to the following
      <literal role="stmt">ALTER TABLE</literal> statement:

description.programlisting:
>
ALTER TABLE old_table RENAME new_table;

description.para:
<literal>RENAME TABLE</literal>, unlike <literal role="stmt">ALTER
      TABLE</literal>, can rename multiple tables within a single
      statement:

description.programlisting:
>
RENAME TABLE old_table1 TO new_table1,
             old_table2 TO new_table2,
             old_table3 TO new_table3;

description.para:
Renaming operations are performed left to right. Thus, to swap two
      table names, do this (assuming that a table with the intermediary
      name <literal>tmp_table</literal> does not already exist):

description.programlisting:
>
RENAME TABLE old_table TO tmp_table,
             new_table TO old_table,
             tmp_table TO new_table;

description.para:
Metadata locks on tables are acquired in name order, which in some
      cases can make a difference in operation outcome when multiple
      transactions execute concurrently. See
      <xref linkend="metadata-locking" />.

As of MySQL 8.0.13, you can rename tables locked with a
      <literal role="stmt">LOCK TABLES</literal> statement, provided
      that they are locked with a <literal>WRITE</literal> lock or are
      the product of renaming <literal>WRITE</literal>-locked tables
      from earlier steps in a multiple-table rename operation. For
      example, this is permitted:
This is not permitted:

Prior to MySQL 8.0.13, to execute <literal>RENAME TABLE</literal>,
      there must be no tables locked with <literal>LOCK
      TABLES</literal>.

With the transaction table locking conditions satisfied, the
      rename operation is done atomically; no other session can access
      any of the tables while the rename is in progress.

If any errors occur during a <literal>RENAME TABLE</literal>, the
      statement fails and no changes are made.

You can use <literal>RENAME TABLE</literal> to move a table from
      one database to another:

description.programlisting:
>
RENAME TABLE <replaceable>current_db.tbl_name</replaceable> TO <replaceable>other_db.tbl_name;</replaceable>

description.para:
Using this method to move all tables from one database to a
      different one in effect renames the database (an operation for
      which MySQL has no single statement), except that the original
      database continues to exist, albeit with no tables.

Like <literal>RENAME TABLE</literal>, <literal>ALTER TABLE ...
      RENAME</literal> can also be used to move a table to a different
      database. Regardless of the statement used, if the rename
      operation would move the table to a database located on a
      different file system, the success of the outcome is platform
      specific and depends on the underlying operating system calls used
      to move table files.

If a table has triggers, attempts to rename the table into a
      different database fail with a <errortext>Trigger in wrong
      schema</errortext>
      (<literal role="error">ER_TRG_IN_WRONG_SCHEMA</literal>) error.

An unencrypted table can be moved to an encryption-enabled
      database and vice versa. However, if the
      <literal role="sysvar">table_encryption_privilege_check</literal>
      variable is enabled, the
      <literal role="priv">TABLE_ENCRYPTION_ADMIN</literal> privilege is
      required if the table encryption setting differs from the default
      database encryption.

To rename <literal>TEMPORARY</literal> tables, <literal>RENAME
      TABLE</literal> does not work. Use <literal role="stmt">ALTER
      TABLE</literal> instead.

<literal>RENAME TABLE</literal> works for views, except that views
      cannot be renamed into a different database.

Any privileges granted specifically for a renamed table or view
      are not migrated to the new name. They must be changed manually.

<literal>RENAME TABLE <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> TO
      <replaceable>new_tbl_name</replaceable></literal> changes
      internally generated foreign key constraint names and user-defined
      foreign key constraint names that begin with the string
      <quote><replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>_ibfk_</quote> to
      reflect the new table name. <literal>InnoDB</literal> interprets
      foreign key constraint names that begin with the string
      <quote><replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>_ibfk_</quote> as
      internally generated names.

Foreign key constraint names that point to the renamed table are
      automatically updated unless there is a conflict, in which case
      the statement fails with an error. A conflict occurs if the
      renamed constraint name already exists. In such cases, you must
      drop and re-create the foreign keys for them to function properly.

<literal>RENAME TABLE <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> TO
      <replaceable>new_tbl_name</replaceable></literal> changes
      internally generated and user-defined <literal>CHECK</literal>
      constraint names that begin with the string
      <quote><replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>_chk_</quote> to reflect
      the new table name. MySQL interprets <literal>CHECK</literal>
      constraint names that begin with the string
      <quote><replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>_chk_</quote> as
      internally generated names. Example:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SHOW CREATE TABLE t1\G</userinput>
*************************** 1. row ***************************
       Table: t1
Create Table: CREATE TABLE `t1` (
  `i1` int(11) DEFAULT NULL,
  `i2` int(11) DEFAULT NULL,
  CONSTRAINT `t1_chk_1` CHECK ((`i1` > 0)),
  CONSTRAINT `t1_chk_2` CHECK ((`i2` < 0))
) ENGINE=InnoDB DEFAULT CHARSET=utf8mb4 COLLATE=utf8mb4_0900_ai_ci
1 row in set (0.02 sec)

mysql> <userinput>RENAME TABLE t1 TO t3;</userinput>
Query OK, 0 rows affected (0.03 sec)

mysql> <userinput>SHOW CREATE TABLE t3\G</userinput>
*************************** 1. row ***************************
       Table: t3
Create Table: CREATE TABLE `t3` (
  `i1` int(11) DEFAULT NULL,
  `i2` int(11) DEFAULT NULL,
  CONSTRAINT `t3_chk_1` CHECK ((`i1` > 0)),
  CONSTRAINT `t3_chk_2` CHECK ((`i2` < 0))
) ENGINE=InnoDB DEFAULT CHARSET=utf8mb4 COLLATE=utf8mb4_0900_ai_ci
1 row in set (0.01 sec)

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">TRUNCATE TABLE</literal> empties a table
      completely. It requires the <literal role="priv">DROP</literal>
      privilege. Logically, <literal role="stmt">TRUNCATE
      TABLE</literal> is similar to a
      <literal role="stmt">DELETE</literal> statement that deletes all
      rows, or a sequence of <literal role="stmt">DROP TABLE</literal>
      and <literal role="stmt">CREATE TABLE</literal> statements.

To achieve high performance, <literal role="stmt">TRUNCATE
      TABLE</literal> bypasses the DML method of deleting data. Thus, it
      does not cause <literal>ON DELETE</literal> triggers to fire, it
      cannot be performed for <literal>InnoDB</literal> tables with
      parent-child foreign key relationships, and it cannot be rolled
      back like a DML operation. However, <literal>TRUNCATE
      TABLE</literal> operations on tables that use an atomic
      DDL-supported storage engine are either fully committed or rolled
      back if the server halts during their operation. For more
      information, see <xref linkend="atomic-ddl" />.

Although <literal role="stmt">TRUNCATE TABLE</literal> is similar
      to <literal role="stmt">DELETE</literal>, it is classified as a
      DDL statement rather than a DML statement. It differs from
      <literal role="stmt">DELETE</literal> in the following ways:

itemizedlist.para:
Truncate operations drop and re-create the table, which is
          much faster than deleting rows one by one, particularly for
          large tables.

Truncate operations cause an implicit commit, and so cannot be
          rolled back. See <xref linkend="implicit-commit" />.

Truncation operations cannot be performed if the session holds
          an active table lock.

<literal role="stmt">TRUNCATE TABLE</literal> fails for an
          <literal>InnoDB</literal> table or
          <literal role="se">NDB</literal> table if there are any
          <literal>FOREIGN KEY</literal> constraints from other tables
          that reference the table. Foreign key constraints between
          columns of the same table are permitted.

Truncation operations do not return a meaningful value for the
          number of deleted rows. The usual result is <quote>0 rows
          affected,</quote> which should be interpreted as <quote>no
          information.</quote>

As long as the table definition is valid, the table can be
          re-created as an empty table with
          <literal role="stmt">TRUNCATE TABLE</literal>, even if the
          data or index files have become corrupted.

Any <literal>AUTO_INCREMENT</literal> value is reset to its
          start value. This is true even for <literal>MyISAM</literal>
          and <literal>InnoDB</literal>, which normally do not reuse
          sequence values.

When used with partitioned tables,
          <literal role="stmt">TRUNCATE TABLE</literal> preserves the
          partitioning; that is, the data and index files are dropped
          and re-created, while the partition definitions are
          unaffected.

The <literal role="stmt">TRUNCATE TABLE</literal> statement
          does not invoke <literal>ON DELETE</literal> triggers.

Truncating a corrupted <literal>InnoDB</literal> table is
          supported.

description.para:
The <literal role="stmt">CALL</literal> statement invokes a stored
      procedure that was defined previously with
      <literal role="stmt">CREATE PROCEDURE</literal>.

Stored procedures that take no arguments can be invoked without
      parentheses. That is, <literal>CALL p()</literal> and
      <literal>CALL p</literal> are equivalent.

<literal role="stmt">CALL</literal> can pass back values to its
      caller using parameters that are declared as
      <literal>OUT</literal> or <literal>INOUT</literal> parameters.
      When the procedure returns, a client program can also obtain the
      number of rows affected for the final statement executed within
      the routine: At the SQL level, call the
      <literal role="func">ROW_COUNT()</literal> function; from the C
      API, call the
      <literal role="cfunc">mysql_affected_rows()</literal> function.

For information about the effect of unhandled conditions on
      procedure parameters, see
      <xref linkend="conditions-and-parameters" />.

You need the <literal role="priv">DELETE</literal> privilege on a
      table to delete rows from it. You need only the
      <literal role="priv">SELECT</literal> privilege for any columns
      that are only read, such as those named in the
      <literal>WHERE</literal> clause.

When you do not need to know the number of deleted rows, the
      <literal role="stmt">TRUNCATE TABLE</literal> statement is a
      faster way to empty a table than a
      <literal role="stmt">DELETE</literal> statement with no
      <literal>WHERE</literal> clause. Unlike
      <literal role="stmt">DELETE</literal>,
      <literal role="stmt">TRUNCATE TABLE</literal> cannot be used
      within a transaction or if you have a lock on the table. See
      <xref linkend="truncate-table" /> and
      <xref linkend="lock-tables" />.

The speed of delete operations may also be affected by factors
      discussed in <xref linkend="delete-optimization" />.

To ensure that a given <literal role="stmt">DELETE</literal>
      statement does not take too much time, the MySQL-specific
      <literal>LIMIT <replaceable>row_count</replaceable></literal>
      clause for <literal role="stmt">DELETE</literal> specifies the
      maximum number of rows to be deleted. If the number of rows to
      delete is larger than the limit, repeat the
      <literal>DELETE</literal> statement until the number of affected
      rows is less than the <literal>LIMIT</literal> value.

You cannot delete from a table and select from the same table in a
      subquery.

<literal>DELETE</literal> supports explicit partition selection
      using the <literal>PARTITION</literal> option, which takes a list
      of the comma-separated names of one or more partitions or
      subpartitions (or both) from which to select rows to be dropped.
      Partitions not included in the list are ignored. Given a
      partitioned table <literal>t</literal> with a partition named
      <literal>p0</literal>, executing the statement <literal>DELETE
      FROM t PARTITION (p0)</literal> has the same effect on the table
      as executing <literal condition="alter-table" role="stmt">ALTER
      TABLE t TRUNCATE PARTITION (p0)</literal>; in both cases, all rows
      in partition <literal>p0</literal> are dropped.

<literal>PARTITION</literal> can be used along with a
      <literal>WHERE</literal> condition, in which case the condition is
      tested only on rows in the listed partitions. For example,
      <literal>DELETE FROM t PARTITION (p0) WHERE c < 5</literal>
      deletes rows only from partition <literal>p0</literal> for which
      the condition <literal>c < 5</literal> is true; rows in any
      other partitions are not checked and thus not affected by the
      <literal>DELETE</literal>.

The <literal>PARTITION</literal> option can also be used in
      multiple-table <literal>DELETE</literal> statements. You can use
      up to one such option per table named in the
      <literal>FROM</literal> option.

For more information and examples, see
      <xref linkend="partitioning-selection" />.

syntax.para:
<literal role="stmt">DELETE</literal> is a DML statement that
      removes rows from a table.

A <literal role="stmt">DELETE</literal> statement can start with a
      <literal role="stmt">WITH</literal> clause to define common table
      expressions accessible within the
      <literal role="stmt">DELETE</literal>. See <xref linkend="with" />.

The <literal>DELETE</literal> statement deletes rows from
      <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> and returns the number of
      deleted rows. To check the number of deleted rows, call the
      <literal role="func">ROW_COUNT()</literal> function described in
      <xref linkend="information-functions" />.

The conditions in the optional <literal>WHERE</literal> clause
      identify which rows to delete. With no <literal>WHERE</literal>
      clause, all rows are deleted.

<replaceable>where_condition</replaceable> is an expression that
      evaluates to true for each row to be deleted. It is specified as
      described in <xref linkend="select" />.

If the <literal>ORDER BY</literal> clause is specified, the rows
      are deleted in the order that is specified. The
      <literal>LIMIT</literal> clause places a limit on the number of
      rows that can be deleted. These clauses apply to single-table
      deletes, but not multi-table deletes.

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">DO</literal> executes the expressions but
      does not return any results. In most respects,
      <literal role="stmt">DO</literal> is shorthand for <literal>SELECT
      <replaceable>expr</replaceable>, ...</literal>, but has the
      advantage that it is slightly faster when you do not care about
      the result.

<literal role="stmt">DO</literal> is useful primarily with
      functions that have side effects, such as
      <literal role="func">RELEASE_LOCK()</literal>.

Example: This <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> statement
      pauses, but also produces a result set:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SELECT SLEEP(5);</userinput>
+----------+
| SLEEP(5) |
+----------+
|        0 |
+----------+
1 row in set (5.02 sec)

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">DO</literal>, on the other hand, pauses
      without producing a result set.:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>DO SLEEP(5);</userinput>
Query OK, 0 rows affected (4.99 sec)

description.para:
This could be useful, for example in a stored function or trigger,
      which prohibit statements that produce result sets.

<literal role="stmt">DO</literal> only executes expressions. It
      cannot be used in all cases where <literal>SELECT</literal> can be
      used. For example, <literal>DO id FROM t1</literal> is invalid
      because it references a table.

The <literal>HANDLER</literal> statement provides direct access to
      table storage engine interfaces. It is available for
      <literal>InnoDB</literal> and <literal>MyISAM</literal> tables.

syntax.programlisting:
>
HANDLER <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> OPEN [ [AS] <replaceable>alias</replaceable>]

HANDLER <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> READ <replaceable>index_name</replaceable> { = | <= | >= | < | > } (<replaceable>value1</replaceable>,<replaceable>value2</replaceable>,...)
    [ WHERE <replaceable>where_condition</replaceable> ] [LIMIT ... ]
HANDLER <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> READ <replaceable>index_name</replaceable> { FIRST | NEXT | PREV | LAST }
    [ WHERE <replaceable>where_condition</replaceable> ] [LIMIT ... ]
HANDLER <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> READ { FIRST | NEXT }
    [ WHERE <replaceable>where_condition</replaceable> ] [LIMIT ... ]

HANDLER <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> CLOSE

description.para:
The <literal role="stmt">IMPORT TABLE</literal> statement imports
      <literal>MyISAM</literal> tables based on information contained in
      <filename>.sdi</filename> (serialized dictionary information)
      metadata files. <literal role="stmt">IMPORT TABLE</literal>
      requires the <literal role="priv">FILE</literal> privilege to read
      the <filename>.sdi</filename> and table content files, and the
      <literal role="priv">CREATE</literal> privilege for the table to
      be created.

Tables can be exported from one server using
      <command>mysqldump</command> to write a file of SQL statements and
      imported into another server using <command>mysql</command> to
      process the dump file. <literal role="stmt">IMPORT TABLE</literal>
      provides a faster alternative using the <quote>raw</quote> table
      files.

Prior to import, the files that provide the table content must be
      placed in the appropriate schema directory for the import server,
      and the <filename>.sdi</filename> file must be located in a
      directory accessible to the server. For example, the
      <filename>.sdi</filename> file can be placed in the directory
      named by the <literal role="sysvar">secure_file_priv</literal>
      system variable, or (if
      <literal role="sysvar">secure_file_priv</literal> is empty) in a
      directory under the server data directory.

The following example describes how to export
      <literal>MyISAM</literal> tables named
      <literal>employees</literal> and <literal>managers</literal> from
      the <literal>hr</literal> schema of one server and import them
      into the <literal>hr</literal> schema of another server. The
      example uses these assumptions (to perform a similar operation on
      your own system, modify the path names as appropriate):

itemizedlist.para:
For the export server,
          <replaceable>export_basedir</replaceable> represents its base
          directory, and its data directory is
          <filename><replaceable>export_basedir</replaceable>/data</filename>.

For the import server,
          <replaceable>import_basedir</replaceable> represents its base
          directory, and its data directory is
          <filename><replaceable>import_basedir</replaceable>/data</filename>.

Table files are exported from the export server into the
          <filename>/tmp/export</filename> directory and this directory
          is secure (not accessible to other users).

The import server uses <filename>/tmp/mysql-files</filename>
          as the directory named by its
          <literal role="sysvar">secure_file_priv</literal> system
          variable.

description.para: To export tables from the export server, use this procedure:
To import tables into the import server, use this procedure:

The <filename>.sdi</filename> file need not be placed in the
      import server directory named by the
      <literal role="sysvar">secure_file_priv</literal> system variable
      if that variable is empty; it can be in any directory accessible
      to the server, including the schema directory for the imported
      table. If the <filename>.sdi</filename> file is placed in that
      directory, however, it may be rewritten; the import operation
      creates a new <filename>.sdi</filename> file for the table, which
      will overwrite the old <filename>.sdi</filename> file if the
      operation uses the same file name for the new file.

Each <replaceable>sdi_file</replaceable> value must be a string
      literal that names the <filename>.sdi</filename> file for a table
      or is a pattern that matches <filename>.sdi</filename> files. If
      the string is a pattern, any leading directory path and the
      <filename>.sdi</filename> file name suffix must be given
      literally. Pattern characters are permitted only in the base name
      part of the file name:

itemizedlist.para: <literal>?</literal> matches any single character

<literal>*</literal> matches any sequence of characters,
          including no characters

description.para:
Using a pattern, the previous <literal role="stmt">IMPORT
      TABLE</literal> statement could have been written like this
      (assuming that the <filename>/tmp/mysql-files</filename> directory
      contains no other <filename>.sdi</filename> files matching the
      pattern):

description.programlisting:
>
IMPORT TABLE FROM '/tmp/mysql-files/*.sdi';

description.para:
To interpret the location of <filename>.sdi</filename> file path
      names, the server uses the same rules for
      <literal role="stmt">IMPORT TABLE</literal> as the server-side
      rules for <literal role="stmt">LOAD DATA</literal> (that is, the
      non-<literal>LOCAL</literal> rules). See
      <xref linkend="load-data" />, paying particular attention to the
      rules used to interpret relative path names.

<literal role="stmt">IMPORT TABLE</literal> fails if the
      <literal>.sdi</literal> or table files cannot be located. After
      importing a table, the server attempts to open it and reports as
      warnings any problems detected. To attempt a repair to correct any
      reported issues, use <literal role="stmt">REPAIR TABLE</literal>.

<literal role="stmt">IMPORT TABLE</literal> is not written to the
      binary log.

With <literal condition="insert-select" role="stmt">INSERT ...
        SELECT</literal>, you can quickly insert many rows into a table
        from the result of a <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal>
        statement, which can select from one or many tables. For
        example:

description.programlisting:
>
INSERT INTO tbl_temp2 (fld_id)
  SELECT tbl_temp1.fld_order_id
  FROM tbl_temp1 WHERE tbl_temp1.fld_order_id > 100;

syntax.programlisting:
>
INSERT [LOW_PRIORITY | HIGH_PRIORITY] [IGNORE]
    [INTO] <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>
    [PARTITION (<replaceable>partition_name</replaceable> [, <replaceable>partition_name</replaceable>] ...)]
    [(<replaceable>col_name</replaceable> [, <replaceable>col_name</replaceable>] ...)]
    SELECT ...
    [ON DUPLICATE KEY UPDATE <replaceable>assignment_list</replaceable>]

<replaceable>value</replaceable>:
    {<replaceable>expr</replaceable> | DEFAULT}

<replaceable>assignment</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>col_name</replaceable> = <replaceable>value</replaceable>

<replaceable>assignment_list</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>assignment</replaceable> [, <replaceable>assignment</replaceable>] ...

description.para:
The <literal>DELAYED</literal> option for the
        <literal role="stmt">INSERT</literal> statement is a MySQL
        extension to standard SQL. In previous versions of MySQL, it can
        be used for certain kinds of tables (such as
        <literal>MyISAM</literal>), such that when a client uses
        <literal role="stmt">INSERT DELAYED</literal>, it gets an okay
        from the server at once, and the row is queued to be inserted
        when the table is not in use by any other thread.

<literal>DELAYED</literal> inserts and replaces were deprecated
        in MySQL 5.6. In MySQL current-series,
        <literal>DELAYED</literal> is not supported. The server
        recognizes but ignores the <literal>DELAYED</literal> keyword,
        handles the insert as a nondelayed insert, and generates an
        <literal>ER_WARN_LEGACY_SYNTAX_CONVERTED</literal> warning
        (<quote>INSERT DELAYED is no longer supported. The statement was
        converted to INSERT</quote>). The <literal>DELAYED</literal>
        keyword is scheduled for removal in a future release.

<literal role="stmt">INSERT</literal> inserts new rows into an
      existing table. The <literal condition="insert" role="stmt">INSERT
      ... VALUES</literal> and
      <literal condition="insert" role="stmt">INSERT ... SET</literal>
      forms of the statement insert rows based on explicitly specified
      values. The <literal condition="insert-select" role="stmt">INSERT
      ... SELECT</literal> form inserts rows selected from another table
      or tables. <literal role="stmt">INSERT</literal> with an
      <literal>ON DUPLICATE KEY UPDATE</literal> clause enables existing
      rows to be updated if a row to be inserted would cause a duplicate
      value in a <literal>UNIQUE</literal> index or <literal>PRIMARY
      KEY</literal>.

For additional information about
      <literal condition="insert-select" role="stmt">INSERT ...
      SELECT</literal> and
      <literal condition="insert-on-duplicate" role="stmt">INSERT ... ON
      DUPLICATE KEY UPDATE</literal>, see
      <xref linkend="insert-select" />, and
      <xref linkend="insert-on-duplicate" />.

In MySQL current-series, the <literal>DELAYED</literal> keyword
      is accepted but ignored by the server. For the reasons for this,
      see <xref linkend="insert-delayed" />,

Inserting into a table requires the
      <literal role="priv">INSERT</literal> privilege for the table. If
      the <literal>ON DUPLICATE KEY UPDATE</literal> clause is used and
      a duplicate key causes an <literal role="stmt">UPDATE</literal> to
      be performed instead, the statement requires the
      <literal role="priv">UPDATE</literal> privilege for the columns to
      be updated. For columns that are read but not modified you need
      only the <literal role="priv">SELECT</literal> privilege (such as
      for a column referenced only on the right hand side of an
      <replaceable>col_name</replaceable>=<replaceable>expr</replaceable>
      assignment in an <literal>ON DUPLICATE KEY UPDATE</literal>
      clause).

When inserting into a partitioned table, you can control which
      partitions and subpartitions accept new rows. The
      <literal>PARTITION</literal> option takes a list of the
      comma-separated names of one or more partitions or subpartitions
      (or both) of the table. If any of the rows to be inserted by a
      given <literal role="stmt">INSERT</literal> statement do not match
      one of the partitions listed, the
      <literal role="stmt">INSERT</literal> statement fails with the
      error <errortext>Found a row not matching the given partition
      set</errortext>. For more information and examples, see
      <xref linkend="partitioning-selection" />.

syntax.programlisting:
>
INSERT [LOW_PRIORITY | DELAYED | HIGH_PRIORITY] [IGNORE]
    [INTO] <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>
    [PARTITION (<replaceable>partition_name</replaceable> [, <replaceable>partition_name</replaceable>] ...)]
    [(<replaceable>col_name</replaceable> [, <replaceable>col_name</replaceable>] ...)]
    {VALUES | VALUE} (<replaceable>value_list</replaceable>) [, (<replaceable>value_list</replaceable>)] ...
    [ON DUPLICATE KEY UPDATE <replaceable>assignment_list</replaceable>]

INSERT [LOW_PRIORITY | DELAYED | HIGH_PRIORITY] [IGNORE]
    [INTO] <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>
    [PARTITION (<replaceable>partition_name</replaceable> [, <replaceable>partition_name</replaceable>] ...)]
    SET <replaceable>assignment_list</replaceable>
    [ON DUPLICATE KEY UPDATE <replaceable>assignment_list</replaceable>]

INSERT [LOW_PRIORITY | HIGH_PRIORITY] [IGNORE]
    [INTO] <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>
    [PARTITION (<replaceable>partition_name</replaceable> [, <replaceable>partition_name</replaceable>] ...)]
    [(<replaceable>col_name</replaceable> [, <replaceable>col_name</replaceable>] ...)]
    SELECT ...
    [ON DUPLICATE KEY UPDATE <replaceable>assignment_list</replaceable>]

<replaceable>value</replaceable>:
    {<replaceable>expr</replaceable> | DEFAULT}

<replaceable>value_list</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>value</replaceable> [, <replaceable>value</replaceable>] ...

<replaceable>assignment</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>col_name</replaceable> = <replaceable>value</replaceable>

<replaceable>assignment_list</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>assignment</replaceable> [, <replaceable>assignment</replaceable>] ...

description.para:
The <literal role="stmt">LOAD DATA</literal> statement reads rows
      from a text file into a table at a very high speed.
      <literal role="stmt">LOAD DATA</literal> is the complement of
      <literal condition="select-into" role="stmt">SELECT ... INTO
      OUTFILE</literal>. (See <xref linkend="select-into" />.) To write
      data from a table to a file, use
      <literal condition="select-into" role="stmt">SELECT ... INTO
      OUTFILE</literal>. To read the file back into a table, use
      <literal role="stmt">LOAD DATA</literal>. The syntax of the
      <literal>FIELDS</literal> and <literal>LINES</literal> clauses is
      the same for both statements.

You can also load data files by using the
      <command>mysqlimport</command> utility; see
      <xref linkend="mysqlimport" />. <command>mysqlimport</command>
      operates by sending a <literal role="stmt">LOAD DATA</literal>
      statement to the server.

For more information about the efficiency of
      <literal role="stmt">INSERT</literal> versus
      <literal role="stmt">LOAD DATA</literal> and speeding up
      <literal role="stmt">LOAD DATA</literal>, see
      <xref linkend="insert-optimization" />.

syntax.programlisting:
>
LOAD DATA
    [LOW_PRIORITY | CONCURRENT] [LOCAL]
    INFILE '<replaceable>file_name</replaceable>'
    [REPLACE | IGNORE]
    INTO TABLE <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>
    [PARTITION (<replaceable>partition_name</replaceable> [, <replaceable>partition_name</replaceable>] ...)]
    [CHARACTER SET <replaceable>charset_name</replaceable>]
    [{FIELDS | COLUMNS}
        [TERMINATED BY '<replaceable>string</replaceable>']
        [[OPTIONALLY] ENCLOSED BY '<replaceable>char</replaceable>']
        [ESCAPED BY '<replaceable>char</replaceable>']
    ]
    [LINES
        [STARTING BY '<replaceable>string</replaceable>']
        [TERMINATED BY '<replaceable>string</replaceable>']
    ]
    [IGNORE <replaceable>number</replaceable> {LINES | ROWS}]
    [(<replaceable>col_name_or_user_var</replaceable>
        [, <replaceable>col_name_or_user_var</replaceable>] ...)]
    [SET <replaceable>col_name</replaceable>={<replaceable>expr</replaceable> | DEFAULT},
        [, <replaceable>col_name</replaceable>={<replaceable>expr</replaceable> | DEFAULT}] ...]

description.para:
The <literal role="stmt">LOAD XML</literal> statement reads data
      from an XML file into a table. The
      <replaceable>file_name</replaceable> must be given as a literal
      string. The <replaceable>tagname</replaceable> in the optional
      <literal>ROWS IDENTIFIED BY</literal> clause must also be given as
      a literal string, and must be surrounded by angle brackets
      (<literal><</literal> and <literal>></literal>).

<literal role="stmt">LOAD XML</literal> acts as the complement of
      running the <command>mysql</command> client in XML output mode
      (that is, starting the client with the
      <option role="mysql">--xml</option> option). To write data from a
      table to an XML file, you can invoke the <command>mysql</command>
      client with the <option role="mysql">--xml</option> and
      <option condition="execute" role="mysql">-e</option> options from
      the system shell, as shown here:

description.programlisting:
>
shell> <userinput>mysql --xml -e 'SELECT * FROM mydb.mytable' > file.xml</userinput>

description.para:
To read the file back into a table, use <literal role="stmt">LOAD
      XML</literal>. By default, the <literal><row></literal>
      element is considered to be the equivalent of a database table
      row; this can be changed using the <literal>ROWS IDENTIFIED
      BY</literal> clause.
This statement supports three different XML formats:

itemizedlist.para:
Column names as attributes and column values as attribute
          values:

Column names as tags and column values as the content of these
          tags:

Column names are the <literal>name</literal> attributes of
          <literal><field></literal> tags, and values are the
          contents of these tags:

This is the format used by other MySQL tools, such as
          <command>mysqldump</command>.

description.para:
All three formats can be used in the same XML file; the import
      routine automatically detects the format for each row and
      interprets it correctly. Tags are matched based on the tag or
      attribute name and the column name.

The following clauses work essentially the same way for
      <literal role="stmt">LOAD XML</literal> as they do for
      <literal role="stmt">LOAD DATA</literal>:

itemizedlist.para:
<literal>LOW_PRIORITY</literal> or
          <literal>CONCURRENT</literal>
<literal>LOCAL</literal>
<literal>REPLACE</literal> or <literal>IGNORE</literal>
<literal>CHARACTER SET</literal>
<literal>SET</literal>

description.para:
See <xref linkend="load-data" />, for more information about these
      clauses.

<literal>(<replaceable>field_name_or_user_var</replaceable>,
      ...)</literal> is a list of one or more comma-separated XML fields
      or user variables. The name of a user variable used for this
      purpose must match the name of a field from the XML file, prefixed
      with <literal>@</literal>. You can use field names to select only
      desired fields. User variables can be employed to store the
      corresponding field values for subsequent re-use.

The <literal>IGNORE <replaceable>number</replaceable>
      LINES</literal> or <literal>IGNORE
      <replaceable>number</replaceable> ROWS</literal> clause causes the
      first <replaceable>number</replaceable> rows in the XML file to be
      skipped. It is analogous to the <literal role="stmt">LOAD
      DATA</literal> statement's <literal>IGNORE ... LINES</literal>
      clause.

syntax.programlisting:
>
LOAD XML
    [LOW_PRIORITY | CONCURRENT] [LOCAL]
    INFILE '<replaceable>file_name</replaceable>'
    [REPLACE | IGNORE]
    INTO TABLE [<replaceable>db_name</replaceable>.]<replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>
    [CHARACTER SET <replaceable>charset_name</replaceable>]
    [ROWS IDENTIFIED BY '<<replaceable>tagname</replaceable>>']
    [IGNORE <replaceable>number</replaceable> {LINES | ROWS}]
    [(<replaceable>field_name_or_user_var</replaceable>
        [, <replaceable>field_name_or_user_var</replaceable>] ...)]
    [SET <replaceable>col_name</replaceable>={<replaceable>expr</replaceable> | DEFAULT},
        [, <replaceable>col_name</replaceable>={<replaceable>expr</replaceable> | DEFAULT}] ...]

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">REPLACE</literal> works exactly like
      <literal role="stmt">INSERT</literal>, except that if an old row
      in the table has the same value as a new row for a
      <literal>PRIMARY KEY</literal> or a <literal>UNIQUE</literal>
      index, the old row is deleted before the new row is inserted. See
      <xref linkend="insert" />.

<literal role="stmt">REPLACE</literal> is a MySQL extension to the
      SQL standard. It either inserts, or <emphasis>deletes</emphasis>
      and inserts. For another MySQL extension to standard
      SQLmdashthat either inserts or
      <emphasis>updates</emphasis>mdashsee
      <xref linkend="insert-on-duplicate" />.

<literal>DELAYED</literal> inserts and replaces were deprecated in
      MySQL 5.6. In MySQL current-series, <literal>DELAYED</literal>
      is not supported. The server recognizes but ignores the
      <literal>DELAYED</literal> keyword, handles the replace as a
      nondelayed replace, and generates an
      <literal>ER_WARN_LEGACY_SYNTAX_CONVERTED</literal> warning.
      (<quote>REPLACE DELAYED is no longer supported. The statement was
      converted to REPLACE.</quote>) The <literal>DELAYED</literal>
      keyword will be removed in a future release.

Values for all columns are taken from the values specified in the
      <literal role="stmt">REPLACE</literal> statement. Any missing
      columns are set to their default values, just as happens for
      <literal role="stmt">INSERT</literal>. You cannot refer to values
      from the current row and use them in the new row. If you use an
      assignment such as <literal>SET
      <replaceable>col_name</replaceable> =
      <replaceable>col_name</replaceable> + 1</literal>, the reference
      to the column name on the right hand side is treated as
      <literal role="func">DEFAULT(<replaceable>col_name</replaceable>)</literal>,
      so the assignment is equivalent to <literal>SET
      <replaceable>col_name</replaceable> =
      DEFAULT(<replaceable>col_name</replaceable>) + 1</literal>.

To use <literal role="stmt">REPLACE</literal>, you must have both
      the <literal role="priv">INSERT</literal> and
      <literal role="priv">DELETE</literal> privileges for the table.

If a generated column is replaced explicitly, the only permitted
      value is <literal>DEFAULT</literal>. For information about
      generated columns, see
      <xref linkend="create-table-generated-columns" />.

<literal>REPLACE</literal> supports explicit partition selection
      using the <literal>PARTITION</literal> keyword with a list of
      comma-separated names of partitions, subpartitions, or both. As
      with <literal role="stmt">INSERT</literal>, if it is not possible
      to insert the new row into any of these partitions or
      subpartitions, the <literal>REPLACE</literal> statement fails with
      the error <errortext>Found a row not matching the given partition
      set</errortext>. For more information and examples, see
      <xref linkend="partitioning-selection" />.

syntax.programlisting:
>
REPLACE [LOW_PRIORITY | DELAYED]
    [INTO] <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>
    [PARTITION (<replaceable>partition_name</replaceable> [, <replaceable>partition_name</replaceable>] ...)]
    [(<replaceable>col_name</replaceable> [, <replaceable>col_name</replaceable>] ...)]
    {VALUES | VALUE} (<replaceable>value_list</replaceable>) [, (<replaceable>value_list</replaceable>)] ...

REPLACE [LOW_PRIORITY | DELAYED]
    [INTO] <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>
    [PARTITION (<replaceable>partition_name</replaceable> [, <replaceable>partition_name</replaceable>] ...)]
    SET <replaceable>assignment_list</replaceable>

REPLACE [LOW_PRIORITY | DELAYED]
    [INTO] <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>
    [PARTITION (<replaceable>partition_name</replaceable> [, <replaceable>partition_name</replaceable>] ...)]
    [(<replaceable>col_name</replaceable> [, <replaceable>col_name</replaceable>] ...)]
    SELECT ...

<replaceable>value</replaceable>:
    {<replaceable>expr</replaceable> | DEFAULT}

<replaceable>value_list</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>value</replaceable> [, <replaceable>value</replaceable>] ...

<replaceable>assignment</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>col_name</replaceable> = <replaceable>value</replaceable>

<replaceable>assignment_list</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>assignment</replaceable> [, <replaceable>assignment</replaceable>] ...

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> is used to retrieve rows
      selected from one or more tables, and can include
      <literal role="stmt">UNION</literal> statements and subqueries.
      See <xref linkend="union" />, and <xref linkend="subqueries" />. A
      <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> statement can start with a
      <literal role="stmt">WITH</literal> clause to define common table
      expressions accessible within the
      <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal>. See <xref linkend="with" />.

The most commonly used clauses of
      <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> statements are these:

itemizedlist.para:
Each <replaceable>select_expr</replaceable> indicates a column
          that you want to retrieve. There must be at least one
          <replaceable>select_expr</replaceable>.

<replaceable>table_references</replaceable> indicates the
          table or tables from which to retrieve rows. Its syntax is
          described in <xref linkend="join" />.

<literal>SELECT</literal> supports explicit partition
          selection using the <literal>PARTITION</literal> with a list
          of partitions or subpartitions (or both) following the name of
          the table in a <replaceable>table_reference</replaceable> (see
          <xref linkend="join" />). In this case, rows are selected only
          from the partitions listed, and any other partitions of the
          table are ignored. For more information and examples, see
          <xref linkend="partitioning-selection" />.

<literal>SELECT ... PARTITION</literal> from tables using
          storage engines such as <literal role="se">MyISAM</literal>
          that perform table-level locks (and thus partition locks) lock
          only the partitions or subpartitions named by the
          <literal>PARTITION</literal> option.

For more information, see
          <xref linkend="partitioning-limitations-locking" />.

The <literal>WHERE</literal> clause, if given, indicates the
          condition or conditions that rows must satisfy to be selected.
          <replaceable>where_condition</replaceable> is an expression
          that evaluates to true for each row to be selected. The
          statement selects all rows if there is no
          <literal>WHERE</literal> clause.

In the <literal>WHERE</literal> expression, you can use any of
          the functions and operators that MySQL supports, except for
          aggregate (summary) functions. See
          <xref linkend="expressions" />, and
          <xref linkend="functions" />.

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> can also be used to retrieve
      rows computed without reference to any table.

syntax.programlisting:
>
SELECT
    [ALL | DISTINCT | DISTINCTROW ]
      [HIGH_PRIORITY]
      [STRAIGHT_JOIN]
      [SQL_SMALL_RESULT] [SQL_BIG_RESULT] [SQL_BUFFER_RESULT]
      [SQL_NO_CACHE] [SQL_CALC_FOUND_ROWS]
    <replaceable>select_expr</replaceable> [, <replaceable>select_expr</replaceable> ...]
    [FROM <replaceable>table_references</replaceable>
      [PARTITION <replaceable>partition_list</replaceable>]
    [WHERE <replaceable>where_condition</replaceable>]
    [GROUP BY {<replaceable>col_name</replaceable> | <replaceable>expr</replaceable> | <replaceable>position</replaceable>}, ... [WITH ROLLUP]]
    [HAVING <replaceable>where_condition</replaceable>]
    [WINDOW <replaceable>window_name</replaceable> AS (<replaceable>window_spec</replaceable>)
        [, <replaceable>window_name</replaceable> AS (<replaceable>window_spec</replaceable>)] ...]
    [ORDER BY {<replaceable>col_name</replaceable> | <replaceable>expr</replaceable> | <replaceable>position</replaceable>}
      [ASC | DESC], ... [WITH ROLLUP]]
    [LIMIT {[<replaceable>offset</replaceable>,] <replaceable>row_count</replaceable> | <replaceable>row_count</replaceable> OFFSET <replaceable>offset</replaceable>}]
    [INTO OUTFILE '<replaceable>file_name</replaceable>'
        [CHARACTER SET <replaceable>charset_name</replaceable>]
        <replaceable>export_options</replaceable>
      | INTO DUMPFILE '<replaceable>file_name</replaceable>'
      | INTO <replaceable>var_name</replaceable> [, <replaceable>var_name</replaceable>]]
    [FOR {UPDATE | SHARE} [OF <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> [, <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>] ...] [NOWAIT | SKIP LOCKED] 
      | LOCK IN SHARE MODE]]

description.para:
MySQL supports the following <literal>JOIN</literal> syntax for
        the <replaceable>table_references</replaceable> part of
        <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> statements and
        multiple-table <literal role="stmt">DELETE</literal> and
        <literal role="stmt">UPDATE</literal> statements:

description.programlisting:
>
<replaceable>table_references:</replaceable>
    <replaceable>escaped_table_reference</replaceable> [, <replaceable>escaped_table_reference</replaceable>] ...

<replaceable>escaped_table_reference</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>table_reference</replaceable>
  | { OJ <replaceable>table_reference</replaceable> }

<replaceable>table_reference</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>table_factor</replaceable>
  | <replaceable>joined_table</replaceable>

<replaceable>table_factor</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> [PARTITION (<replaceable>partition_names</replaceable>)]
        [[AS] <replaceable>alias</replaceable>] [<replaceable>index_hint_list</replaceable>]
  | <replaceable>table_subquery</replaceable> [AS] <replaceable>alias</replaceable> [(<replaceable>col_list</replaceable>)]
  | ( <replaceable>table_references</replaceable> )

<replaceable>joined_table</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>table_reference</replaceable> {[INNER | CROSS] JOIN | STRAIGHT_JOIN} <replaceable>table_factor</replaceable> [<replaceable>join_specification</replaceable>]
  | <replaceable>table_reference</replaceable> {LEFT|RIGHT} [OUTER] JOIN <replaceable>table_reference</replaceable> <replaceable>join_specification</replaceable>
  | <replaceable>table_reference</replaceable> NATURAL [INNER | {LEFT|RIGHT} [OUTER]] JOIN <replaceable>table_factor</replaceable>

<replaceable>join_specification</replaceable>:
    ON <replaceable>search_condition</replaceable>
  | USING (<replaceable>join_column_list</replaceable>)

<replaceable>join_column_list</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>column_name</replaceable> [, <replaceable>column_name</replaceable>] ...

<replaceable>index_hint_list</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>index_hint</replaceable> [, <replaceable>index_hint</replaceable>] ...

<replaceable>index_hint</replaceable>:
    USE {INDEX|KEY}
      [FOR {JOIN|ORDER BY|GROUP BY}] ([<replaceable>index_list</replaceable>])
  | {IGNORE|FORCE} {INDEX|KEY}
      [FOR {JOIN|ORDER BY|GROUP BY}] (<replaceable>index_list</replaceable>)

<replaceable>index_list</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>index_name</replaceable> [, <replaceable>index_name</replaceable>] ...

description.para: A table reference is also known as a join expression.

A table reference (when it refers to a partitioned table) may
        contain a <literal>PARTITION</literal> option, including a list
        of comma-separated partitions, subpartitions, or both. This
        option follows the name of the table and precedes any alias
        declaration. The effect of this option is that rows are selected
        only from the listed partitions or subpartitions. Any partitions
        or subpartitions not named in the list are ignored. For more
        information and examples, see
        <xref linkend="partitioning-selection" />.

The syntax of <replaceable>table_factor</replaceable> is
        extended in MySQL in comparison with standard SQL. The standard
        accepts only <replaceable>table_reference</replaceable>, not a
        list of them inside a pair of parentheses.

This is a conservative extension if each comma in a list of
        <replaceable>table_reference</replaceable> items is considered
        as equivalent to an inner join. For example:

description.programlisting:
>
SELECT * FROM t1 LEFT JOIN (t2, t3, t4)
                 ON (t2.a = t1.a AND t3.b = t1.b AND t4.c = t1.c)

description.para: is equivalent to:

description.programlisting:
>
SELECT * FROM t1 LEFT JOIN (t2 CROSS JOIN t3 CROSS JOIN t4)
                 ON (t2.a = t1.a AND t3.b = t1.b AND t4.c = t1.c)

description.para:
In MySQL, <literal>JOIN</literal>, <literal>CROSS
        JOIN</literal>, and <literal>INNER JOIN</literal> are syntactic
        equivalents (they can replace each other). In standard SQL, they
        are not equivalent. <literal>INNER JOIN</literal> is used with
        an <literal>ON</literal> clause, <literal>CROSS JOIN</literal>
        is used otherwise.

In general, parentheses can be ignored in join expressions
        containing only inner join operations. MySQL also supports
        nested joins. See <xref linkend="nested-join-optimization" />.

Index hints can be specified to affect how the MySQL optimizer
        makes use of indexes. For more information, see
        <xref linkend="index-hints" />. Optimizer hints and the
        <literal>optimizer_switch</literal> system variable are other
        ways to influence optimizer use of indexes. See
        <xref linkend="optimizer-hints" />, and
        <xref linkend="switchable-optimizations" />.

<literal role="stmt">UNION</literal> is used to combine the
        result from multiple <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal>
        statements into a single result set.

The column names from the first
        <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> statement are used as the
        column names for the results returned. Selected columns listed
        in corresponding positions of each
        <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> statement should have the
        same data type. (For example, the first column selected by the
        first statement should have the same type as the first column
        selected by the other statements.)

syntax.programlisting:
>
SELECT ...
UNION [ALL | DISTINCT] SELECT ...
[UNION [ALL | DISTINCT] SELECT ...]

description.para:
<indexterm>
        <primary>DUAL</primary>
      </indexterm>

      You are permitted to specify <literal>DUAL</literal> as a dummy
      table name in situations where no tables are referenced:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SELECT 1 + 1 FROM DUAL;</userinput>
        -> 2

description.para:
<literal>DUAL</literal> is purely for the convenience of people
      who require that all <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal>
      statements should have <literal>FROM</literal> and possibly other
      clauses. MySQL may ignore the clauses. MySQL does not require
      <literal>FROM DUAL</literal> if no tables are referenced.

syntax.programlisting:
>
SELECT
    [ALL | DISTINCT | DISTINCTROW ]
      [HIGH_PRIORITY]
      [STRAIGHT_JOIN]
      [SQL_SMALL_RESULT] [SQL_BIG_RESULT] [SQL_BUFFER_RESULT]
      [SQL_NO_CACHE] [SQL_CALC_FOUND_ROWS]
    <replaceable>select_expr</replaceable> [, <replaceable>select_expr</replaceable> ...]
    [FROM <replaceable>table_references</replaceable>
      [PARTITION <replaceable>partition_list</replaceable>]
    [WHERE <replaceable>where_condition</replaceable>]
    [GROUP BY {<replaceable>col_name</replaceable> | <replaceable>expr</replaceable> | <replaceable>position</replaceable>}, ... [WITH ROLLUP]]
    [HAVING <replaceable>where_condition</replaceable>]
    [WINDOW <replaceable>window_name</replaceable> AS (<replaceable>window_spec</replaceable>)
        [, <replaceable>window_name</replaceable> AS (<replaceable>window_spec</replaceable>)] ...]
    [ORDER BY {<replaceable>col_name</replaceable> | <replaceable>expr</replaceable> | <replaceable>position</replaceable>}
      [ASC | DESC], ... [WITH ROLLUP]]
    [LIMIT {[<replaceable>offset</replaceable>,] <replaceable>row_count</replaceable> | <replaceable>row_count</replaceable> OFFSET <replaceable>offset</replaceable>}]
    [INTO OUTFILE '<replaceable>file_name</replaceable>'
        [CHARACTER SET <replaceable>charset_name</replaceable>]
        <replaceable>export_options</replaceable>
      | INTO DUMPFILE '<replaceable>file_name</replaceable>'
      | INTO <replaceable>var_name</replaceable> [, <replaceable>var_name</replaceable>]]
    [FOR {UPDATE | SHARE} [OF <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> [, <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>] ...] [NOWAIT | SKIP LOCKED] 
      | LOCK IN SHARE MODE]]

description.para:
For the single-table syntax, the
      <literal role="stmt">UPDATE</literal> statement updates columns of
      existing rows in the named table with new values. The
      <literal>SET</literal> clause indicates which columns to modify
      and the values they should be given. Each value can be given as an
      expression, or the keyword <literal>DEFAULT</literal> to set a
      column explicitly to its default value. The
      <literal>WHERE</literal> clause, if given, specifies the
      conditions that identify which rows to update. With no
      <literal>WHERE</literal> clause, all rows are updated. If the
      <literal>ORDER BY</literal> clause is specified, the rows are
      updated in the order that is specified. The
      <literal>LIMIT</literal> clause places a limit on the number of
      rows that can be updated.

For the multiple-table syntax,
      <literal role="stmt">UPDATE</literal> updates rows in each table
      named in <replaceable>table_references</replaceable> that satisfy
      the conditions. Each matching row is updated once, even if it
      matches the conditions multiple times. For multiple-table syntax,
      <literal>ORDER BY</literal> and <literal>LIMIT</literal> cannot be
      used.

For partitioned tables, both the single-single and multiple-table
      forms of this statement support the use of a
      <literal>PARTITION</literal> option as part of a table reference.
      This option takes a list of one or more partitions or
      subpartitions (or both). Only the partitions (or subpartitions)
      listed are checked for matches, and a row that is not in any of
      these partitions or subpartitions is not updated, whether it
      satisfies the <replaceable>where_condition</replaceable> or not.

For more information and examples, see
      <xref linkend="partitioning-selection" />.

<replaceable>where_condition</replaceable> is an expression that
      evaluates to true for each row to be updated. For expression
      syntax, see <xref linkend="expressions" />.

<replaceable>table_references</replaceable> and
      <replaceable>where_condition</replaceable> are specified as
      described in <xref linkend="select" />.

You need the <literal role="priv">UPDATE</literal> privilege only
      for columns referenced in an <literal role="stmt">UPDATE</literal>
      that are actually updated. You need only the
      <literal role="priv">SELECT</literal> privilege for any columns
      that are read but not modified.

The <literal role="stmt">UPDATE</literal> statement supports the
      following modifiers:

itemizedlist.para:
With the <literal>LOW_PRIORITY</literal> modifier, execution
          of the <literal role="stmt">UPDATE</literal> is delayed until
          no other clients are reading from the table. This affects only
          storage engines that use only table-level locking (such as
          <literal>MyISAM</literal>, <literal>MEMORY</literal>, and
          <literal>MERGE</literal>).

With the <literal>IGNORE</literal> modifier, the update
          statement does not abort even if errors occur during the
          update. Rows for which duplicate-key conflicts occur on a
          unique key value are not updated. Rows updated to values that
          would cause data conversion errors are updated to the closest
          valid values instead. For more information, see
          <xref linkend="ignore-strict-comparison" />.

syntax.para:
<literal role="stmt">UPDATE</literal> is a DML statement that
      modifies rows in a table.

An <literal role="stmt">UPDATE</literal> statement can start with
      a <literal role="stmt">WITH</literal> clause to define common
      table expressions accessible within the
      <literal role="stmt">UPDATE</literal>. See <xref linkend="with" />.

description.para:
The <literal role="stmt">PREPARE</literal> statement prepares a
      SQL statement and assigns it a name,
      <replaceable>stmt_name</replaceable>, by which to refer to the
      statement later. The prepared statement is executed with
      <literal role="stmt">EXECUTE</literal> and released with
      <literal role="stmt">DEALLOCATE PREPARE</literal>. For examples,
      see <xref linkend="sql-prepared-statements" />.

Statement names are not case-sensitive.
      <replaceable>preparable_stmt</replaceable> is either a string
      literal or a user variable that contains the text of the SQL
      statement. The text must represent a single statement, not
      multiple statements. Within the statement, <literal>?</literal>
      characters can be used as parameter markers to indicate where data
      values are to be bound to the query later when you execute it. The
      <literal>?</literal> characters should not be enclosed within
      quotation marks, even if you intend to bind them to string values.
      Parameter markers can be used only where data values should
      appear, not for SQL keywords, identifiers, and so forth.

If a prepared statement with the given name already exists, it is
      deallocated implicitly before the new statement is prepared. This
      means that if the new statement contains an error and cannot be
      prepared, an error is returned and no statement with the given
      name exists.

The scope of a prepared statement is the session within which it
      is created, which as several implications:

itemizedlist.para:
A prepared statement created in one session is not available
          to other sessions.

When a session ends, whether normally or abnormally, its
          prepared statements no longer exist. If auto-reconnect is
          enabled, the client is not notified that the connection was
          lost. For this reason, clients may wish to disable
          auto-reconnect. See <xref linkend="c-api-auto-reconnect" />.

A prepared statement created within a stored program continues
          to exist after the program finishes executing and can be
          executed outside the program later.

A statement prepared in stored program context cannot refer to
          stored procedure or function parameters or local variables
          because they go out of scope when the program ends and would
          be unavailable were the statement to be executed later outside
          the program. As a workaround, refer instead to user-defined
          variables, which also have session scope; see
          <xref linkend="user-variables" />.

description.para:
After preparing a statement with
      <literal role="stmt">PREPARE</literal>, you execute it with an
      <literal role="stmt">EXECUTE</literal> statement that refers to
      the prepared statement name. If the prepared statement contains
      any parameter markers, you must supply a <literal>USING</literal>
      clause that lists user variables containing the values to be bound
      to the parameters. Parameter values can be supplied only by user
      variables, and the <literal>USING</literal> clause must name
      exactly as many variables as the number of parameter markers in
      the statement.

You can execute a given prepared statement multiple times, passing
      different variables to it or setting the variables to different
      values before each execution.

To deallocate a prepared statement produced with
      <literal role="stmt">PREPARE</literal>, use a
      <literal role="stmt">DEALLOCATE PREPARE</literal> statement that
      refers to the prepared statement name. Attempting to execute a
      prepared statement after deallocating it results in an error. If
      too many prepared statements are created and not deallocated by
      either the <literal>DEALLOCATE PREPARE</literal> statement or the
      end of the session, you might encounter the upper limit enforced
      by the <literal role="sysvar">max_prepared_stmt_count</literal>
      system variable.

The binary log is a set of files that contain information about
        data modifications made by the MySQL server. The log consists of
        a set of binary log files, plus an index file (see
        <xref linkend="binary-log" />).

The <literal role="stmt">PURGE BINARY LOGS</literal> statement
        deletes all the binary log files listed in the log index file
        prior to the specified log file name or date.
        <literal>BINARY</literal> and <literal>MASTER</literal> are
        synonyms. Deleted log files also are removed from the list
        recorded in the index file, so that the given log file becomes
        the first in the list.

<literal role="stmt">PURGE BINARY LOGS</literal> requires the
        <literal role="priv">BINLOG_ADMIN</literal> privilege. This
        statement has no effect if the server was not started with the
        <option role="mysqld">--log-bin</option> option to enable binary
        logging.

<literal role="stmt">RESET MASTER</literal> requires the
        <literal role="priv">RELOAD</literal> privilege.

For a server where binary logging is enabled
        (<literal role="sysvar">log_bin</literal> is
        <literal>ON</literal>), <literal>RESET MASTER</literal> deletes
        all existing binary log files and resets the binary log index
        file, resetting the server to its state before binary logging
        was started. A new empty binary log file is created so that
        binary logging can be restarted.

For a server where GTIDs are in use
        (<literal role="sysvar">gtid_mode</literal> is
        <literal>ON</literal>), issuing <literal>RESET MASTER</literal>
        resets the GTID execution history. The value of the
        <literal role="sysvar">gtid_purged</literal> system variable is
        set to an empty string (<literal>''</literal>), the global value
        (but not the session value) of the
        <literal role="sysvar">gtid_executed</literal> system variable
        is set to an empty string, and the
        <literal>mysql.gtid_executed</literal> table is cleared (see
        <xref linkend="replication-gtids-gtid-executed-table" />). If the
        GTID-enabled server has binary logging enabled,
        <literal role="stmt">RESET MASTER</literal> also resets the
        binary log as described above. Note that
        <literal role="stmt">RESET MASTER</literal> is the method to
        reset the GTID execution history even if the GTID-enabled server
        is a replication slave where binary logging is disabled;
        <literal role="stmt">RESET SLAVE</literal> has no effect on the
        GTID execution history. For more information on resetting the
        GTID execution history, see
        <xref linkend="replication-gtids-execution-history" />.

Issuing <literal>RESET MASTER</literal> without the optional
        <literal>TO</literal> clause deletes all binary log files listed
        in the index file, resets the binary log index file to be empty,
        and creates a new binary log file starting at
        <literal>1</literal>. Use the optional <literal>TO</literal>
        clause to start the binary log file index from a number other
        than <literal>1</literal> after the reset.

Using <literal>RESET MASTER</literal> with the
        <literal>TO</literal> clause to specify a binary log file index
        number to start from simplifies failover by providing a single
        statement alternative to the <literal role="stmt">FLUSH BINARY
        LOGS</literal> and
        <literal condition="purge-binary-logs" role="stmt">PURGE BINARY
        LOGS TO</literal> statements. Check that you are using a
        reasonable value for the index number. If you enter an incorrect
        value, you can correct this by issuing another
        <literal role="stmt">RESET MASTER</literal> statement with or
        without the <literal>TO</literal> clause. If you do not correct
        a value that is out of range, the server cannot be restarted.

The following example demonstrates <literal>TO</literal> clause
        usage:

The <literal role="sysvar">sql_log_bin</literal> variable
        controls whether logging to the binary log is enabled for the
        current session (assuming that the binary log itself is
        enabled). The default value is <literal>ON</literal>. To disable
        or enable binary logging for the current session, set the
        session <literal role="sysvar">sql_log_bin</literal> variable to
        <literal>OFF</literal> or <literal>ON</literal>.

Set this variable to <literal>OFF</literal> for a session to
        temporarily disable binary logging while making changes to the
        master you do not want replicated to the slave.

Setting the session value of this system variable is a
        restricted operation. The session user must have privileges
        sufficient to set restricted session variables. See
        <xref linkend="system-variable-privileges" />.

It is not possible to set the session value of
        <literal role="sysvar">sql_log_bin</literal> within a
        transaction or subquery.

<emphasis>Setting this variable to <literal>OFF</literal>
        prevents new GTIDs from being assigned to transactions in the
        binary log</emphasis>. If you are using GTIDs for replication,
        this means that even when binary logging is later enabled again,
        the GTIDs written into the log from this point do not account
        for any transactions that occurred in the meantime, so in effect
        those transactions are lost.

<command>mysqldump</command> adds a <literal>SET
        @@SESSION.sql_log_bin=0</literal> statement to a dump file from
        a server where GTIDs are in use, which disables binary logging
        while the dump file is being reloaded. The statement prevents
        new GTIDs from being generated and assigned to the transactions
        in the dump file as they are executed, so that the original
        GTIDs for the transactions are used.

<literal role="stmt">CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> changes the
        parameters that the slave server uses for connecting to the
        master server, for reading the master binary log, and reading
        the slave relay log. It also updates the contents of the master
        info and relay log info repositories (see
        <xref linkend="slave-logs" />). <literal role="stmt">CHANGE
        MASTER TO</literal> requires the
        <literal role="priv">REPLICATION_SLAVE_ADMIN</literal> or
        <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege.

You can issue <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> statements on
        a running slave without first stopping it, depending on the
        states of the slave SQL thread and slave I/O thread. The rules
        governing such use are provided later in this section.

When using a multithreaded slave (in other words
        <literal role="sysvar">slave_parallel_workers</literal> is
        greater than 0), stopping the slave can cause
        <quote>gaps</quote> in the sequence of transactions that have
        been executed from the relay log, regardless of whether the
        slave was stopped intentionally or otherwise. When such gaps
        exist, issuing <literal role="stmt">CHANGE MASTER TO</literal>
        fails. The solution in this situation is to issue
        <literal condition="start-slave" role="stmt">START SLAVE UNTIL
        SQL_AFTER_MTS_GAPS</literal> which ensures that the gaps are
        closed.

The optional <literal>FOR CHANNEL
        <replaceable>channel</replaceable></literal> clause enables you
        to name which replication channel the statement applies to.
        Providing a <literal>FOR CHANNEL
        <replaceable>channel</replaceable></literal> clause applies the
        <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> statement to a specific
        replication channel, and is used to add a new channel or modify
        an existing channel. For example, to add a new channel called
        channel2:

description.programlisting: >CHANGE MASTER TO MASTER_HOST=host1, MASTER_PORT=3002 FOR CHANNEL 'channel2'

description.para:
If no clause is named and no extra channels exist, the statement
        applies to the default channel.

When using multiple replication channels, if a <literal>CHANGE
        MASTER TO</literal> statement does not name a channel using a
        <literal>FOR CHANNEL
        <replaceable>channel</replaceable></literal> clause, an error
        occurs. See <xref linkend="replication-channels" /> for more
        information.

Options not specified retain their value, except as indicated in
        the following discussion. Thus, in most cases, there is no need
        to specify options that do not change.

<literal>MASTER_HOST</literal>, <literal>MASTER_USER</literal>,
        <literal>MASTER_PASSWORD</literal>, and
        <literal>MASTER_PORT</literal> provide information to the slave
        about how to connect to its master:

itemizedlist.para:
<literal>MASTER_HOST</literal> and
            <literal>MASTER_PORT</literal> are the host name (or IP
            address) of the master host and its TCP/IP port.

itemizedlist.note:
<para>
              Replication cannot use Unix socket files. You must be able
              to connect to the master MySQL server using TCP/IP.
            </para>

itemizedlist.para:
If you specify the <literal>MASTER_HOST</literal> or
            <literal>MASTER_PORT</literal> option, the slave assumes
            that the master server is different from before (even if the
            option value is the same as its current value.) In this
            case, the old values for the master binary log file name and
            position are considered no longer applicable, so if you do
            not specify <literal>MASTER_LOG_FILE</literal> and
            <literal>MASTER_LOG_POS</literal> in the statement,
            <literal>MASTER_LOG_FILE=''</literal> and
            <literal>MASTER_LOG_POS=4</literal> are silently appended to
            it.

Setting <literal>MASTER_HOST=''</literal> (that is, setting
            its value explicitly to an empty string) is
            <emphasis>not</emphasis> the same as not setting
            <literal>MASTER_HOST</literal> at all. Trying to set
            <literal>MASTER_HOST</literal> to an empty string fails with
            an error.

Values used for <literal>MASTER_HOST</literal> and other
            <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> options are checked for
            linefeed (<literal>\n</literal> or <literal>0x0A</literal>)
            characters; the presence of such characters in these values
            causes the statement to fail with
            <literal role="error">ER_MASTER_INFO</literal>. (Bug
            #11758581, Bug #50801)

<literal>MASTER_USER</literal> and
            <literal>MASTER_PASSWORD</literal> are the user name and
            password of the account to use for connecting to the master.

<literal>MASTER_USER</literal> cannot be made empty; setting
            <literal>MASTER_USER = ''</literal> or leaving it unset when
            setting a value for <literal>MASTER_PASSWORD</literal>
            causes an error (Bug #13427949).

The password used for a MySQL Replication slave account in a
            <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> statement is limited to
            32 characters in length; trying to use a password of more
            than 32 characters causes <literal>CHANGE MASTER
            TO</literal> to fail.

The text of a running <literal role="stmt">CHANGE MASTER
            TO</literal> statement, including values for
            <literal>MASTER_USER</literal> and
            <literal>MASTER_PASSWORD</literal>, can be seen in the
            output of a concurrent <literal role="stmt">SHOW
            PROCESSLIST</literal> statement. (The complete text of a
            <literal role="stmt">START SLAVE</literal> statement is also
            visible to <literal role="stmt">SHOW PROCESSLIST</literal>.)

description.para:
<literal>PRIVILEGE_CHECKS_USER</literal> (available as of MySQL
        8.0.18) names a user account that supplies a security context
        for the specified channel. <literal>NULL</literal>, which is the
        default, means no security context is used. If you do not
        specify a channel and no other channels exist, the statement is
        applied to the default channel. For example, to start privilege
        checks on the channel <literal>channel_1</literal> on a running
        replication slave, issue the following statements:

The user name and host name for the user account must follow the
        syntax described in <xref linkend="account-names" />, and the
        user must not be an anonymous user (with a blank user name) or
        the <literal>CURRENT_USER</literal>. The account must have the
        <literal role="priv">REPLICATION_APPLIER</literal> privilege,
        plus the required privileges to execute the transactions
        replicated on the channel. When you restart the replication
        channel, the privilege checks are applied from that point on.
        For more information, see
        <xref linkend="replication-privilege-checks" />.

<literal>MASTER_COMPRESSION_ALGORITHMS</literal> and
        <literal>MASTER_ZSTD_COMPRESSION_LEVEL</literal> (available as
        of MySQL 8.0.18) enable control over the use of compression for
        connections to the master:

itemizedlist.para:
<literal>MASTER_COMPRESSION_ALGORITHMS</literal> specifies
            the permitted compression algorithms. The available
            algorithms are the same as for the
            <literal role="sysvar">protocol_compression_algorithms</literal>
            system variable. The default value is
            <literal>uncompressed</literal>.

The value of
            <literal>MASTER_COMPRESSION_ALGORITHMS</literal> applies
            only if the
            <literal role="sysvar">slave_compressed_protocol</literal>
            system variable is disabled. If
            <literal role="sysvar">slave_compressed_protocol</literal>
            is enabled, it takes precedence over
            <literal>MASTER_COMPRESSION_ALGORITHMS</literal> and
            connections to the master use <literal>zlib</literal>
            compression if both master and slave support that algorithm.

<literal>MASTER_ZSTD_COMPRESSION_LEVEL</literal> is the
            compression level to use for connections that use the
            <literal>zstd</literal> compression algorithm. The permitted
            levels are from 1 to 22, with larger values indicating
            increasing levels of compression. The default
            <literal>zstd</literal> compression level is 3. The
            compression level setting has no effect on connections that
            do not use <literal>zstd</literal> compression.

description.para:
For more information, see
        <xref linkend="connection-compression-control" />.

The <literal>MASTER_SSL_<replaceable>xxx</replaceable></literal>
        options and the <literal>MASTER_TLS_VERSION</literal> option
        specify how the slave uses encryption and ciphers to secure the
        replication connection. These options can be changed even on
        slaves that are compiled without SSL support. They are saved to
        the master info repository, but are ignored if the slave does
        not have SSL support enabled. The
        <literal>MASTER_SSL_<replaceable>xxx</replaceable></literal> and
        <literal>MASTER_TLS_VERSION</literal> options perform the same
        functions as the
        <literal>--ssl-<replaceable>xxx</replaceable></literal> and
        <literal>--tls-version</literal> client options described in
        <xref linkend="encrypted-connection-options" />. The
        correspondence between the two sets of options, and the use of
        the <literal>MASTER_SSL_<replaceable>xxx</replaceable></literal>
        and <literal>MASTER_TLS_VERSION</literal> options to set up a
        secure connection, is explained in
        <xref linkend="replication-solutions-encrypted-connections" />.

To enable RSA key pair-based password exchange, specify either
        the <literal>MASTER_PUBLIC_KEY_PATH</literal> or the
        <literal>GET_MASTER_PUBLIC_KEY=1</literal> option. Either of
        these options provides the RSA public key to the slave:

itemizedlist.para:
<literal>MASTER_PUBLIC_KEY_PATH</literal> indicates the path
            name to a file containing a slave-side copy of the public
            key required by the master for RSA key pair-based password
            exchange. The file must be in PEM format. This option
            applies to slaves that authenticate with the
            <literal>sha256_password</literal> or
            <literal>caching_sha2_password</literal> authentication
            plugin. (For <literal>sha256_password</literal>,
            <literal>MASTER_PUBLIC_KEY_PATH</literal> can be used only
            if MySQL was built using OpenSSL.)

<literal>GET_MASTER_PUBLIC_KEY</literal> indicates whether
