            to request from the master the public key required for RSA
            key pair-based password exchange. This option applies to
            slaves that authenticate with the
            <literal>caching_sha2_password</literal> authentication
            plugin. For connections by accounts that authenticate using
            this plugin, the master does not send the public key unless
            requested, so it must be requested or specified in the
            client. If <literal>MASTER_PUBLIC_KEY_PATH</literal> is
            given and specifies a valid public key file, it takes
            precedence over <literal>GET_MASTER_PUBLIC_KEY</literal>.

description.para:
The <literal>MASTER_HEARTBEAT_PERIOD</literal>,
        <literal>MASTER_CONNECT_RETRY</literal>, and
        <literal>MASTER_RETRY_COUNT</literal> options control how the
        slave recognizes that the connection to the master has been lost
        and makes attempts to reconnect.

itemizedlist.para:
The <literal role="sysvar">slave_net_timeout</literal>
            system variable specifies the number of seconds that the
            slave waits for either more data or a heartbeat signal from
            the master, before the slave considers the connection
            broken, aborts the read, and tries to reconnect. The default
            value is 60 seconds (one minute).

The heartbeat interval, which stops the connection timeout
            occurring in the absence of data if the connection is still
            good, is controlled by the
            <literal>MASTER_HEARTBEAT_PERIOD</literal> option. A
            heartbeat signal is sent to the slave after that number of
            seconds, and the waiting period is reset whenever the
            master's binary log is updated with an event. Heartbeats are
            therefore sent by the master only if there are no unsent
            events in the binary log file for a period longer than this.
            The heartbeat interval <replaceable>interval</replaceable>
            is a decimal value having the range 0 to 4294967 seconds and
            a resolution in milliseconds; the smallest nonzero value is
            0.001. Setting <replaceable>interval</replaceable> to 0
            disables heartbeats altogether. The heartbeat interval
            defaults to half the value of the
            <literal role="sysvar">slave_net_timeout</literal> system
            variable. It is recorded in the master info log and shown in
            the
            <literal role="ps">replication_connection_configuration</literal>
            Performance Schema table. Issuing <literal role="stmt">RESET
            SLAVE</literal> resets the heartbeat interval to the default
            value.

Note that a change to the value or default setting of
            <literal role="sysvar">slave_net_timeout</literal> does not
            automatically change the heartbeat interval, whether that
            has been set explicitly or is using a previously calculated
            default. A warning is issued if you set
            <literal>@@GLOBAL.slave_net_timeout</literal> to a value
            less than that of the current heartbeat interval. If
            <literal role="sysvar">slave_net_timeout</literal> is
            changed, you must also issue <literal role="stmt">CHANGE
            MASTER TO</literal> to adjust the heartbeat interval to an
            appropriate value so that the heartbeat signal occurs before
            the connection timeout. If you do not do this, the heartbeat
            signal has no effect, and if no data is received from the
            master, the slave can make repeated reconnection attempts,
            creating zombie dump threads.

If the slave does need to reconnect, the first retry occurs
            immediately after the timeout.
            <literal>MASTER_CONNECT_RETRY</literal> specifies the
            interval between reconnection attempts, and
            <literal>MASTER_RETRY_COUNT</literal> limits the number of
            reconnection attempts. If both the default settings are
            used, the slave waits 60 seconds between reconnection
            attempts (<literal>MASTER_CONNECT_RETRY=60</literal>), and
            keeps attempting to reconnect at this rate for 60 days
            (<literal>MASTER_RETRY_COUNT=86400</literal>). These values
            are recorded in the master info log and shown in the
            <literal role="ps">replication_connection_configuration</literal>
            Performance Schema table.
            <literal>MASTER_RETRY_COUNT</literal> supersedes the
            <option role="mysqld">--master-retry-count</option> server
            startup option.

description.para:
<literal>MASTER_DELAY</literal> specifies how many seconds
        behind the master the slave must lag. An event received from the
        master is not executed until at least
        <replaceable>interval</replaceable> seconds later than its
        execution on the master. The default is 0. An error occurs if
        <replaceable>interval</replaceable> is not a nonnegative integer
        in the range from 0 to 2<superscript>31</superscript>minus1.
        For more information, see <xref linkend="replication-delayed" />.

A <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> statement employing the
        <literal>MASTER_DELAY</literal> option can be executed on a
        running slave when the slave SQL thread is stopped.

<literal>MASTER_BIND</literal> is for use on replication slaves
        having multiple network interfaces, and determines which of the
        slave's network interfaces is chosen for connecting to the
        master.

The address configured with this option, if any, can be seen in
        the <literal>Master_Bind</literal> column of the output from
        <literal role="stmt">SHOW SLAVE STATUS</literal>. In the master
        info repository table
        <literal>mysql.slave_master_info</literal>, the value can be
        seen as the <literal>Master_bind</literal> column.

The ability to bind a replication slave to a specific network
        interface is also supported by NDB Cluster.

<literal>MASTER_LOG_FILE</literal> and
        <literal>MASTER_LOG_POS</literal> are the coordinates at which
        the slave I/O thread should begin reading from the master the
        next time the thread starts. <literal>RELAY_LOG_FILE</literal>
        and <literal>RELAY_LOG_POS</literal> are the coordinates at
        which the slave SQL thread should begin reading from the relay
        log the next time the thread starts. If you specify either of
        <literal>MASTER_LOG_FILE</literal> or
        <literal>MASTER_LOG_POS</literal>, you cannot specify
        <literal>RELAY_LOG_FILE</literal> or
        <literal>RELAY_LOG_POS</literal>. If you specify either of
        <literal>MASTER_LOG_FILE</literal> or
        <literal>MASTER_LOG_POS</literal>, you also cannot specify
        <literal>MASTER_AUTO_POSITION = 1</literal> (described later in
        this section). If neither of <literal>MASTER_LOG_FILE</literal>
        or <literal>MASTER_LOG_POS</literal> is specified, the slave
        uses the last coordinates of the <emphasis>slave SQL
        thread</emphasis> before <literal role="stmt">CHANGE MASTER
        TO</literal> was issued. This ensures that there is no
        discontinuity in replication, even if the slave SQL thread was
        late compared to the slave I/O thread, when you merely want to
        change, say, the password to use.

<literal>RELAY_LOG_FILE</literal> can use either an absolute or
        relative path, and uses the same base name as
        <literal>MASTER_LOG_FILE</literal>. A <literal>CHANGE MASTER
        TO</literal> statement employing
        <literal>RELAY_LOG_FILE</literal>,
        <literal>RELAY_LOG_POS</literal>, or both options can be
        executed on a running slave when the slave SQL thread is
        stopped. Relay logs are preserved if at least one of the slave
        SQL thread and the slave I/O thread is running. If both threads
        are stopped, all relay log files are deleted unless at least one
        of <literal>RELAY_LOG_FILE</literal> or
        <literal>RELAY_LOG_POS</literal> is specified. Note that the
        Group Replication applier channel
        (<literal>group_replication_applier</literal>) has no I/O
        thread, only a SQL thread. For this channel, the relay logs are
        not preserved when the SQL thread is stopped.

When <literal>MASTER_AUTO_POSITION = 1</literal> is used with
        <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal>, the slave attempts to
        connect to the master using the GTID-based replication protocol.
        This option can be used with <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal>
        only if both the slave SQL and slave I/O threads are stopped.
        Both the slave and the master must have GTIDs enabled
        (<literal role="sysvar">GTID_MODE=ON</literal>,
        <literal>ON_PERMISSIVE,</literal> or
        <literal>OFF_PERMISSIVE</literal> on the slave, and
        <literal role="sysvar">GTID_MODE=ON</literal> on the master).
        Auto-positioning is used for the connection, so the coordinates
        represented by <literal>MASTER_LOG_FILE</literal> and
        <literal>MASTER_LOG_POS</literal> are not used, and the use of
        either or both of these options together with
        <literal>MASTER_AUTO_POSITION = 1</literal> causes an error. If
        multi-source replication is enabled on the slave, you need to
        set the <literal>MASTER_AUTO_POSITION = 1</literal> option for
        each applicable replication channel.

With <literal>MASTER_AUTO_POSITION = 1</literal> set, in the
        initial connection handshake, the slave sends a GTID set
        containing the transactions that it has already received,
        committed, or both. The master responds by sending all
        transactions recorded in its binary log whose GTID is not
        included in the GTID set sent by the slave. This exchange
        ensures that the master only sends the transactions with a GTID
        that the slave has not already recorded or committed. If the
        slave receives transactions from more than one master, as in the
        case of a diamond topology, the auto-skip function ensures that
        the transactions are not applied twice. For details of how the
        GTID set sent by the slave is computed, see
        <xref linkend="replication-gtids-auto-positioning" />.

If any of the transactions that should be sent by the master
        have been purged from the master's binary log, or added to the
        set of GTIDs in the <literal role="sysvar">gtid_purged</literal>
        system variable by another method, the master sends the error
        <errorname>ER_MASTER_HAS_PURGED_REQUIRED_GTIDS</errorname> to
        the slave, and replication does not start. The GTIDs of the
        missing purged transactions are identified and listed in the
        master's error log in the warning message
        <errorname>ER_FOUND_MISSING_GTIDS</errorname>. Also, if during
        the exchange of transactions it is found that the slave has
        recorded or committed transactions with the master's UUID in the
        GTID, but the master itself has not committed them, the master
        sends the error
        <errorname>ER_SLAVE_HAS_MORE_GTIDS_THAN_MASTER</errorname> to
        the slave and replication does not start. For information on how
        to handle these situations, see
        <xref linkend="replication-gtids-auto-positioning" />.

You can see whether replication is running with auto-positioning
        enabled by checking the Performance Schema
        <literal role="ps">replication_connection_status</literal> table
        or the output of <literal role="stmt">SHOW SLAVE
        STATUS</literal>. Disabling the
        <literal>MASTER_AUTO_POSITION</literal> option again makes the
        slave revert to file-based replication, in which case you must
        also specify one or both of the
        <literal>MASTER_LOG_FILE</literal> or
        <literal>MASTER_LOG_POS</literal> options.

<literal>IGNORE_SERVER_IDS</literal> takes a comma-separated
        list of 0 or more server IDs. Events originating from the
        corresponding servers are ignored, with the exception of log
        rotation and deletion events, which are still recorded in the
        relay log.

In circular replication, the originating server normally acts as
        the terminator of its own events, so that they are not applied
        more than once. Thus, this option is useful in circular
        replication when one of the servers in the circle is removed.
        Suppose that you have a circular replication setup with 4
        servers, having server IDs 1, 2, 3, and 4, and server 3 fails.
        When bridging the gap by starting replication from server 2 to
        server 4, you can include <literal>IGNORE_SERVER_IDS =
        (3)</literal> in the <literal role="stmt">CHANGE MASTER
        TO</literal> statement that you issue on server 4 to tell it to
        use server 2 as its master instead of server 3. Doing so causes
        it to ignore and not to propagate any statements that originated
        with the server that is no longer in use.

If <literal>IGNORE_SERVER_IDS</literal> contains the
        server's own ID and the server was started with the
        <option role="mysqld">--replicate-same-server-id</option> option
        enabled, an error results.

The master info repository and the output of
        <literal role="stmt">SHOW SLAVE STATUS</literal> provide the
        list of servers that are currently ignored. For more
        information, see <xref linkend="slave-logs-status" />, and
        <xref linkend="show-slave-status" />.

If a <literal role="stmt">CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> statement
        is issued without any <literal>IGNORE_SERVER_IDS</literal>
        option, any existing list is preserved. To clear the list of
        ignored servers, it is necessary to use the option with an empty
        list:

description.programlisting:
>
CHANGE MASTER TO IGNORE_SERVER_IDS = ();

description.para:
<literal>RESET SLAVE ALL</literal> clears
        <literal>IGNORE_SERVER_IDS</literal>.

Invoking <literal role="stmt">CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> causes
        the previous values for <literal>MASTER_HOST</literal>,
        <literal>MASTER_PORT</literal>,
        <literal>MASTER_LOG_FILE</literal>, and
        <literal>MASTER_LOG_POS</literal> to be written to the error
        log, along with other information about the slave's state
        prior to execution.

<literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> causes an implicit commit of
        an ongoing transaction. See <xref linkend="implicit-commit" />.

From MySQL 5.7, the strict requirement to execute
        <literal role="stmt">STOP SLAVE</literal> prior to issuing any
        <literal role="stmt">CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> statement (and
        <literal role="stmt">START SLAVE</literal> afterward) is
        removed. Instead of depending on whether the slave is stopped,
        the behavior of <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> depends on
        the states of the slave SQL thread and slave I/O threads; which
        of these threads is stopped or running now determines the
        options that can or cannot be used with a <literal>CHANGE MASTER
        TO</literal> statement at a given point in time. The rules for
        making this determination are listed here:

itemizedlist.para:
If the SQL thread is stopped, you can execute
            <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> using any combination
            that is otherwise allowed of
            <literal>RELAY_LOG_FILE</literal>,
            <literal>RELAY_LOG_POS</literal>, and
            <literal>MASTER_DELAY</literal> options, even if the slave
            I/O thread is running. No other options may be used with
            this statement when the I/O thread is running.

If the I/O thread is stopped, you can execute
            <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> using any of the options
            for this statement (in any allowed combination)
            <emphasis>except</emphasis>
            <literal>RELAY_LOG_FILE</literal>,
            <literal>RELAY_LOG_POS</literal>,
            <literal>MASTER_DELAY</literal>, or
            <literal>MASTER_AUTO_POSITION = 1</literal> even when the
            SQL thread is running.

Both the SQL thread and the I/O thread must be stopped
            before issuing a <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal>
            statement that employs <literal>MASTER_AUTO_POSITION =
            1</literal>.

description.para:
You can check the current state of the slave SQL and I/O threads
        using <literal role="stmt">SHOW SLAVE STATUS</literal>. Note
        that the Group Replication applier channel
        (<literal>group_replication_applier</literal>) has no I/O
        thread, only a SQL thread.

For more information, see
        <xref linkend="replication-solutions-switch" />.

If you are using statement-based replication and temporary
        tables, it is possible for a <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal>
        statement following a <literal>STOP SLAVE</literal> statement to
        leave behind temporary tables on the slave. A warning
        (<literal role="error">ER_WARN_OPEN_TEMP_TABLES_MUST_BE_ZERO</literal>)
        is now issued whenever this occurs. You can avoid this in such
        cases by making sure that the value of the
        <literal role="statvar">Slave_open_temp_tables</literal> system
        status variable is equal to 0 prior to executing such a
        <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> statement.

<literal role="stmt">CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> is useful for
        setting up a slave when you have the snapshot of the master and
        have recorded the master binary log coordinates corresponding to
        the time of the snapshot. After loading the snapshot into the
        slave to synchronize it with the master, you can run
        <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO
        MASTER_LOG_FILE='<replaceable>log_name</replaceable>',
        MASTER_LOG_POS=<replaceable>log_pos</replaceable></literal> on
        the slave to specify the coordinates at which the slave should
        begin reading the master binary log.

The following example changes the master server the slave uses
        and establishes the master binary log coordinates from which the
        slave begins reading. This is used when you want to set up the
        slave to replicate the master:

description.programlisting:
>
CHANGE MASTER TO
  MASTER_HOST='master2.example.com',
  MASTER_USER='replication',
  MASTER_PASSWORD='<replaceable>password</replaceable>',
  MASTER_PORT=3306,
  MASTER_LOG_FILE='master2-bin.001',
  MASTER_LOG_POS=4,
  MASTER_CONNECT_RETRY=10;

description.para:
The next example shows an operation that is less frequently
        employed. It is used when the slave has relay log files that you
        want it to execute again for some reason. To do this, the master
        need not be reachable. You need only use
        <literal role="stmt">CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> and start the
        SQL thread (<literal>START SLAVE SQL_THREAD</literal>):

description.programlisting:
>
CHANGE MASTER TO
  RELAY_LOG_FILE='slave-relay-bin.006',
  RELAY_LOG_POS=4025;

syntax.programlisting:
>
CHANGE MASTER TO <replaceable>option</replaceable> [, <replaceable>option</replaceable>] ... [ <replaceable>channel_option</replaceable> ]

<replaceable>option</replaceable>:
    MASTER_BIND = '<replaceable>interface_name</replaceable>'
  | MASTER_HOST = '<replaceable>host_name</replaceable>'
  | MASTER_USER = '<replaceable>user_name</replaceable>'
  | MASTER_PASSWORD = '<replaceable>password</replaceable>'
  | MASTER_PORT = <replaceable>port_num</replaceable>
  | PRIVILEGE_CHECKS_USER = {'<replaceable>account</replaceable>' | NULL}
  | MASTER_CONNECT_RETRY = <replaceable>interval</replaceable>
  | MASTER_RETRY_COUNT = <replaceable>count</replaceable>
  | MASTER_DELAY = <replaceable>interval</replaceable>
  | MASTER_HEARTBEAT_PERIOD = <replaceable>interval</replaceable>
  | MASTER_LOG_FILE = '<replaceable>master_log_name</replaceable>'
  | MASTER_LOG_POS = <replaceable>master_log_pos</replaceable>
  | MASTER_AUTO_POSITION = {0|1}
  | RELAY_LOG_FILE = '<replaceable>relay_log_name</replaceable>'
  | RELAY_LOG_POS = <replaceable>relay_log_pos</replaceable>
  | MASTER_COMPRESSION_ALGORITHMS = '<replaceable>value</replaceable>'
  | MASTER_ZSTD_COMPRESSION_LEVEL = <replaceable>level</replaceable>
  | MASTER_SSL = {0|1}
  | MASTER_SSL_CA = '<replaceable>ca_file_name</replaceable>'
  | MASTER_SSL_CAPATH = '<replaceable>ca_directory_name</replaceable>'
  | MASTER_SSL_CERT = '<replaceable>cert_file_name</replaceable>'
  | MASTER_SSL_CRL = '<replaceable>crl_file_name</replaceable>'
  | MASTER_SSL_CRLPATH = '<replaceable>crl_directory_name</replaceable>'
  | MASTER_SSL_KEY = '<replaceable>key_file_name</replaceable>'
  | MASTER_SSL_CIPHER = '<replaceable>cipher_list</replaceable>'
  | MASTER_SSL_VERIFY_SERVER_CERT = {0|1}
  | MASTER_TLS_VERSION = '<replaceable>protocol_list</replaceable>'
  | MASTER_PUBLIC_KEY_PATH = '<replaceable>key_file_name</replaceable>'
  | GET_MASTER_PUBLIC_KEY = {0|1}
  | IGNORE_SERVER_IDS = (<replaceable>server_id_list</replaceable>)

<replaceable>channel_option</replaceable>:
    FOR CHANNEL <replaceable>channel</replaceable>

<replaceable>server_id_list</replaceable>:
    [<replaceable>server_id</replaceable> [, <replaceable>server_id</replaceable>] ... ]

description.para:
<literal>CHANGE REPLICATION FILTER</literal> sets one or more
        replication filtering rules on the slave in the same way as
        starting the slave <command>mysqld</command> with replication
        filtering options such as
        <option role="mysqld">--replicate-do-db</option> or
        <option role="mysqld">--replicate-wild-ignore-table</option>.
        Unlike the case with the server options, this statement does not
        require restarting the server to take effect, only that the
        slave SQL thread be stopped using
        <literal condition="stop-slave" role="stmt">STOP SLAVE
        SQL_THREAD</literal> first (and restarted with
        <literal condition="start-slave" role="stmt">START SLAVE
        SQL_THREAD</literal> afterwards). <literal role="stmt">CHANGE
        REPLICATION FILTER</literal> requires the
        <literal role="priv">REPLICATION_SLAVE_ADMIN</literal> or
        <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege. Use the
        <literal>FOR CHANNEL
        <replaceable>channel</replaceable></literal> clause to make a
        replication filter specific to a replication channel, for
        example on a multi-source replication slave. Filters applied
        without a specific <literal>FOR CHANNEL</literal> clause are
        considered global filters, meaning that they are applied to all
        replication channels.

<note>
          <para>
            Global replication filters cannot be set on a MySQL server
            instance that is configured for Group Replication, because
            filtering transactions on some servers would make the group
            unable to reach agreement on a consistent state. Channel
            specific replication filters can be set on replication
            channels that are not directly involved with Group
            Replication, such as where a group member also acts as a
            replication slave to a master that is outside the group.
            They cannot be set on the
            <literal>group_replication_applier</literal> or
            <literal>group_replication_recovery</literal> channels.
          </para>
        </note>

The following list shows the <literal>CHANGE REPLICATION
        FILTER</literal> options and how they relate to
        <option>--replicate-*</option> server options:

itemizedlist.para:
<literal>REPLICATE_DO_DB</literal>: Include updates based on
            database name. Equivalent to
            <option role="mysqld">--replicate-do-db</option>.

<literal>REPLICATE_IGNORE_DB</literal>: Exclude updates
            based on database name. Equivalent to
            <option role="mysqld">--replicate-ignore-db</option>.

<literal>REPLICATE_DO_TABLE</literal>: Include updates based
            on table name. Equivalent to
            <option role="mysqld">--replicate-do-table</option>.

<literal>REPLICATE_IGNORE_TABLE</literal>: Exclude updates
            based on table name. Equivalent to
            <option role="mysqld">--replicate-ignore-table</option>.

<literal>REPLICATE_WILD_DO_TABLE</literal>: Include updates
            based on wildcard pattern matching table name. Equivalent to
            <option role="mysqld">--replicate-wild-do-table</option>.

<literal>REPLICATE_WILD_IGNORE_TABLE</literal>: Exclude
            updates based on wildcard pattern matching table name.
            Equivalent to
            <option role="mysqld">--replicate-wild-ignore-table</option>.

<literal>REPLICATE_REWRITE_DB</literal>: Perform updates on
            slave after substituting new name on slave for specified
            database on master. Equivalent to
            <option role="mysqld">--replicate-rewrite-db</option>.

description.para:
The precise effects of <literal>REPLICATE_DO_DB</literal> and
        <literal>REPLICATE_IGNORE_DB</literal> filters are dependent on
        whether statement-based or row-based replication is in effect.
        See <xref linkend="replication-rules" />, for more information.

Multiple replication filtering rules can be created in a single
        <literal>CHANGE REPLICATION FILTER</literal> statement by
        separating the rules with commas, as shown here:

Issuing the statement just shown is equivalent to starting the
        slave <command>mysqld</command> with the options
        <option role="mysqld">--replicate-do-db=d1</option>
        <option role="mysqld">--replicate-ignore-db=d2</option>.

On a multi-source replication slave, which uses multiple
        replication channels to process transaction from different
        sources, use the <literal>FOR CHANNEL
        <replaceable>channel</replaceable></literal> clause to set a
        replication filter on a replication channel:

description.programlisting: >CHANGE REPLICATION FILTER REPLICATE_DO_DB = (d1) FOR CHANNEL channel_1;

description.para:
This enables you to create a channel specific replication filter
        to filter out selected data from a source. When a <literal>FOR
        CHANNEL</literal> clause is provided, the replication filter
        statement acts on that slave replication channel removing any
        existing replication filter which has the same filter type as
        the specified replication filters, and replacing them with the
        specified filter. Filter types not explicitly listed in the
        statement are not modified. If issued against a slave
        replication channel which is not configured, the statement fails
        with an <errortext>ER_SLAVE_CONFIGURATION</errortext> error. If
        issued against Group Replication channels, the statement fails
        with an
        <errortext>ER_SLAVE_CHANNEL_OPERATION_NOT_ALLOWED</errortext>
        error.

On a replication slave with multiple replication channels
        configured, issuing <literal role="stmt">CHANGE REPLICATION
        FILTER</literal> with no <literal>FOR CHANNEL</literal> clause
        configures the replication filter for every configured slave
        replication channel, and for the global replication filters. For
        every filter type, if the filter type is listed in the
        statement, then any existing filter rules of that type are
        replaced by the filter rules specified in the most recently
        issued statement, otherwise the old value of the filter type is
        retained. For more information see
        <xref linkend="replication-rules-channel-based-filters" />.

If the same filtering rule is specified multiple times, only the
        <emphasis>last</emphasis> such rule is actually used. For
        example, the two statements shown here have exactly the same
        effect, because the first <literal>REPLICATE_DO_DB</literal>
        rule in the first statement is ignored:

Names of tables and database not containing any special
        characters need not be quoted. Values used with
        <literal>REPLICATION_WILD_TABLE</literal> and
        <literal>REPLICATION_WILD_IGNORE_TABLE</literal> are string
        expressions, possibly containing (special) wildcard characters,
        and so must be quoted. This is shown in the following example
        statements:

Values used with <literal>REPLICATE_REWRITE_DB</literal>
        represent <emphasis>pairs</emphasis> of database names; each
        such value must be enclosed in parentheses. The following
        statement rewrites statements occurring on database
        <literal>db1</literal> on the master to database
        <literal>db2</literal> on the slave:

description.programlisting:
>
CHANGE REPLICATION FILTER REPLICATE_REWRITE_DB = ((db1, db2));

description.para:
The statement just shown contains two sets of parentheses, one
        enclosing the pair of database names, and the other enclosing
        the entire list. This is perhaps more easily seen in the
        following example, which creates two
        <literal>rewrite-db</literal> rules, one rewriting database
        <literal>dbA</literal> to <literal>dbB</literal>, and one
        rewriting database <literal>dbC</literal> to
        <literal>dbD</literal>:

The <literal role="stmt">CHANGE REPLICATION FILTER</literal>
        statement replaces replication filtering rules only for the
        filter types and replication channels affected by the statement,
        and leaves other rules and channels unchanged. If you want to
        unset all filters of a given type, set the filter's value
        to an explicitly empty list, as shown in this example, which
        removes all existing <literal>REPLICATE_DO_DB</literal> and
        <literal>REPLICATE_IGNORE_DB</literal> rules:

Setting a filter to empty in this way removes all existing
        rules, does not create any new ones, and does not restore any
        rules set at mysqld startup using <option>--replicate-*</option>
        options on the command line or in the configuration file.

The <literal condition="reset-slave" role="stmt">RESET SLAVE
        ALL</literal> statement removes channel specific replication
        filters that were set on channels deleted by the statement. When
        the deleted channel or channels are recreated, any global
        replication filters specified for the slave are copied to them,
        and no channel specific replication filters are applied.
For more information, see <xref linkend="replication-rules" />.

syntax.programlisting:
>
CHANGE REPLICATION FILTER <replaceable>filter</replaceable>[, <replaceable>filter</replaceable>]
	[, ...] [FOR CHANNEL <replaceable>channel</replaceable>]

<replaceable>filter</replaceable>:
    REPLICATE_DO_DB = (<replaceable>db_list</replaceable>)
  | REPLICATE_IGNORE_DB = (<replaceable>db_list</replaceable>)
  | REPLICATE_DO_TABLE = (<replaceable>tbl_list</replaceable>)
  | REPLICATE_IGNORE_TABLE = (<replaceable>tbl_list</replaceable>)
  | REPLICATE_WILD_DO_TABLE = (<replaceable>wild_tbl_list</replaceable>)
  | REPLICATE_WILD_IGNORE_TABLE = (<replaceable>wild_tbl_list</replaceable>)
  | REPLICATE_REWRITE_DB = (<replaceable>db_pair_list</replaceable>)

<replaceable>db_list</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>db_name</replaceable>[, <replaceable>db_name</replaceable>][, ...]

<replaceable>tbl_list</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>db_name.table_name</replaceable>[, <replaceable>db_name.table_name</replaceable>][, ...]
<replaceable>wild_tbl_list</replaceable>:
    '<replaceable>db_pattern.table_pattern</replaceable>'[, '<replaceable>db_pattern.table_pattern</replaceable>'][, ...]

<replaceable>db_pair_list</replaceable>:
    (<replaceable>db_pair</replaceable>)[, (<replaceable>db_pair</replaceable>)][, ...]

<replaceable>db_pair</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>from_db</replaceable>, <replaceable>to_db</replaceable>

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">RESET SLAVE</literal> makes the slave
        forget its replication position in the master's binary log. This
        statement is meant to be used for a clean start: It clears the
        master info and relay log info repositories, deletes all the
        relay log files, and starts a new relay log file. It also resets
        to 0 the replication delay specified with the
        <literal>MASTER_DELAY</literal> option to <literal>CHANGE MASTER
        TO</literal>.

For a server where GTIDs are in use
        (<literal role="sysvar">gtid_mode</literal> is
        <literal>ON</literal>), issuing <literal role="stmt">RESET
        SLAVE</literal> has no effect on the GTID execution history. The
        statement does not change the values of
        <literal>gtid_executed</literal> or
        <literal>gtid_purged</literal>, or the
        <literal>mysql.gtid_executed</literal> table. If you need to
        reset the GTID execution history, use <literal role="stmt">RESET
        MASTER</literal>, even if the GTID-enabled server is a
        replication slave where binary logging is disabled.

<literal role="stmt">RESET SLAVE</literal> requires the
        <literal role="priv">RELOAD</literal> privilege.

To use <literal role="stmt">RESET SLAVE</literal>, the slave
        replication threads must be stopped, so on a running slave use
        <literal role="stmt">STOP SLAVE</literal> before issuing
        <literal role="stmt">RESET SLAVE</literal>. To use
        <literal role="stmt">RESET SLAVE</literal> on a Group
        Replication group member, the member status must be
        <literal>OFFLINE</literal>, meaning that the plugin is loaded
        but the member does not currently belong to any group. A group
        member can be taken offline by using a <literal role="stmt">STOP
        GROUP REPLICATION</literal> statement.

The optional <literal>FOR CHANNEL
        <replaceable>channel</replaceable></literal> clause enables you
        to name which replication channel the statement applies to.
        Providing a <literal>FOR CHANNEL
        <replaceable>channel</replaceable></literal> clause applies the
        <literal>RESET SLAVE</literal> statement to a specific
        replication channel. Combining a <literal>FOR CHANNEL
        <replaceable>channel</replaceable></literal> clause with the
        <literal>ALL</literal> option deletes the specified channel. If
        no channel is named and no extra channels exist, the statement
        applies to the default channel. Issuing a
        <literal condition="reset-slave" role="stmt">RESET SLAVE
        ALL</literal> statement without a <literal>FOR CHANNEL
        <replaceable>channel</replaceable></literal> clause when
        multiple replication channels exist deletes
        <emphasis>all</emphasis> replication channels and recreates only
        the default channel. See <xref linkend="replication-channels" />
        for more information.

<literal role="stmt">RESET SLAVE</literal> does not change any
        replication connection parameters such as the master host,
        master port, master user, or master password.
        <literal role="stmt">RESET SLAVE</literal> also does not affect
        the <literal>PRIVILEGE_CHECKS_USER</literal> account. If you
        want to reset the connection parameters intentionally, you need
        to use <literal condition="reset-slave" role="stmt">RESET SLAVE
        ALL</literal>, which clears the connection parameters, including
        the <literal>MASTER_USER</literal> and
        <literal>PRIVILEGE_CHECKS_USER</literal> accounts.
        <literal>RESET SLAVE ALL</literal> also clears the
        <literal>IGNORE_SERVER_IDS</literal> list set by
        <literal role="stmt">CHANGE MASTER TO</literal>. When you have
        used <literal>RESET SLAVE ALL</literal>, you must issue a
        <literal role="stmt">CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> statement after
        the server start to specify new connection parameters.

In the event of a server crash or deliberate restart after
        issuing <literal role="stmt">RESET SLAVE</literal> but before
        issuing <literal role="stmt">START SLAVE</literal>, retention of
        the replication connection parameters depends on the repository
        used for the master info log:

itemizedlist.para:
From MySQL 8.0.13, when
            <literal role="sysvar">master_info_repository=TABLE</literal>
            is set on the server (which is the default from MySQL 8.0),
            replication connection parameters are preserved in the
            crash-safe <literal>InnoDB</literal> table
            <literal>mysql.slave_master_info</literal> as part of the
            <literal role="stmt">RESET SLAVE</literal> operation. They
            are also retained in memory. In the event of a server crash
            or deliberate restart after issuing
            <literal role="stmt">RESET SLAVE</literal> but before
            issuing <literal role="stmt">START SLAVE</literal>, the
            replication connection parameters are retrieved from the
            table and reused for the new connection.

When
            <literal role="sysvar">master_info_repository=FILE</literal>
            is set on the server, replication connection parameters are
            only retained in memory. If the slave
            <command>mysqld</command> is restarted immediately after
            issuing <literal role="stmt">RESET SLAVE</literal> due to a
            server crash or deliberate restart, the connection
            parameters are lost. In that case, you must issue a
            <literal role="stmt">CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> statement
            after the server start to respecify the connection
            parameters before issuing <literal role="stmt">START
            SLAVE</literal>.

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">RESET SLAVE</literal> does not change any
        replication filter settings (such as
        <option role="mysqld">--replicate-ignore-table</option>) for
        channels affected by the statement. However, <literal>RESET
        SLAVE ALL</literal> removes the replication filters that were
        set on the channels deleted by the statement. When the deleted
        channel or channels are recreated, any global replication
        filters specified for the slave are copied to them, and no
        channel specific replication filters are applied. For more
        information see
        <xref linkend="replication-rules-channel-based-filters" />.

<literal>RESET SLAVE</literal> causes an implicit commit of an
        ongoing transaction. See <xref linkend="implicit-commit" />.

If the slave SQL thread was in the middle of replicating
        temporary tables when it was stopped, and
        <literal role="stmt">RESET SLAVE</literal> is issued, these
        replicated temporary tables are deleted on the slave.

<literal>RESET SLAVE</literal> does not reset the heartbeat
        period
        (<literal role="statvar">Slave_heartbeat_period</literal>) or
        <literal>SSL_VERIFY_SERVER_CERT</literal>.

This statement skips the next <replaceable>N</replaceable>
        events from the master. This is useful for recovering from
        replication stops caused by a statement.

This statement is valid only when the slave threads are not
        running. Otherwise, it produces an error.

<literal role="stmt">START SLAVE</literal> with no
        <replaceable>thread_type</replaceable> options starts both of
        the slave threads. The I/O thread reads events from the master
        server and stores them in the relay log. The SQL thread reads
        events from the relay log and executes them.
        <literal role="stmt">START SLAVE</literal> requires the
        <literal role="priv">REPLICATION_SLAVE_ADMIN</literal> or
        <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege.

If <literal role="stmt">START SLAVE</literal> succeeds in
        starting the slave threads, it returns without any error.
        However, even in that case, it might be that the slave threads
        start and then later stop (for example, because they do not
        manage to connect to the master or read its binary log, or some
        other problem). <literal role="stmt">START SLAVE</literal> does
        not warn you about this. You must check the slave's error log
        for error messages generated by the slave threads, or check that
        they are running satisfactorily with <literal role="stmt">SHOW
        SLAVE STATUS</literal>.

<literal>START SLAVE</literal> causes an implicit commit of an
        ongoing transaction. See <xref linkend="implicit-commit" />.

<literal role="sysvar">gtid_next</literal> must be set to
        <literal>AUTOMATIC</literal> before issuing this statement.

The optional <literal>FOR CHANNEL
        <replaceable>channel</replaceable></literal> clause enables you
        to name which replication channel the statement applies to.
        Providing a <literal>FOR CHANNEL
        <replaceable>channel</replaceable></literal> clause applies the
        <literal>START SLAVE</literal> statement to a specific
        replication channel. If no clause is named and no extra channels
        exist, the statement applies to the default channel. If a
        <literal>START SLAVE</literal> statement does not have a channel
        defined when using multiple channels, this statement starts the
        specified threads for all channels. This statement is disallowed
        for the <literal>group_replication_recovery</literal> channel.
        See <xref linkend="replication-channels" /> for more information.

You can add <literal>IO_THREAD</literal> and
        <literal>SQL_THREAD</literal> options to the statement to name
        which of the threads to start. Note that the Group Replication
        applier channel (<literal>group_replication_applier</literal>)
        has no I/O thread, only a SQL thread. Specifying the
        <literal>IO_THREAD</literal> or <literal>SQL_THREAD</literal>
        options when you start this channel has no benefit.

MySQL supports pluggable user-password authentication with
        <literal>START SLAVE</literal> with the <literal>USER</literal>,
        <literal>PASSWORD</literal>, <literal>DEFAULT_AUTH</literal> and
        <literal>PLUGIN_DIR</literal> options, as described in the
        following list:

itemizedlist.para:
<literal>USER</literal>: User name. Cannot be set to an
            empty or null string, or left unset if
            <literal>PASSWORD</literal> is used.
<literal>PASSWORD</literal>: Password.

<literal>DEFAULT_AUTH</literal>: Name of plugin; default is
            MySQL native authentication.
<literal>PLUGIN_DIR</literal>: Location of plugin.

description.para:
You cannot use the <literal>SQL_THREAD</literal> option when
        specifying any of <literal>USER</literal>,
        <literal>PASSWORD</literal>, <literal>DEFAULT_AUTH</literal>, or
        <literal>PLUGIN_DIR</literal>, unless the
        <literal>IO_THREAD</literal> option is also provided.

See <xref linkend="pluggable-authentication" />, for more
        information.

If an insecure connection is used with any these options, the
        server issues the warning <errortext>Sending passwords in plain
        text without SSL/TLS is extremely insecure</errortext>.

<literal>START SLAVE ... UNTIL</literal> supports two additional
        options for use with global transaction identifiers (GTIDs) (see
        <xref linkend="replication-gtids" />). Each of these takes a set
        of one or more global transaction identifiers
        <replaceable>gtid_set</replaceable> as an argument (see
        <xref linkend="replication-gtids-concepts-gtid-sets" />, for more
        information).

When no <replaceable>thread_type</replaceable> is specified,
        <literal>START SLAVE UNTIL SQL_BEFORE_GTIDS</literal> causes the
        slave SQL thread to process transactions until it has reached
        the <emphasis>first</emphasis> transaction whose GTID is listed
        in the <replaceable>gtid_set</replaceable>. <literal>START SLAVE
        UNTIL SQL_AFTER_GTIDS</literal> causes the slave threads to
        process all transactions until the
        <replaceable>last</replaceable> transaction in the
        <replaceable>gtid_set</replaceable> has been processed by both
        threads. In other words, <literal>START SLAVE UNTIL
        SQL_BEFORE_GTIDS</literal> causes the slave SQL thread to
        process all transactions occurring before the first GTID in the
        <replaceable>gtid_set</replaceable> is reached, and
        <literal>START SLAVE UNTIL SQL_AFTER_GTIDS</literal> causes the
        slave threads to handle all transactions, including those whose
        GTIDs are found in <replaceable>gtid_set</replaceable>, until
        each has encountered a transaction whose GTID is not part of the
        set. <literal>SQL_BEFORE_GTIDS</literal> and
        <literal>SQL_AFTER_GTIDS</literal> each support the
        <literal>SQL_THREAD</literal> and <literal>IO_THREAD</literal>
        options, although using <literal>IO_THREAD</literal> with them
        currently has no effect.

For example, <literal>START SLAVE SQL_THREAD UNTIL
        SQL_BEFORE_GTIDS =
        3E11FA47-71CA-11E1-9E33-C80AA9429562:11-56</literal> causes the
        slave SQL thread to process all transactions originating from
        the master whose <literal role="sysvar">server_uuid</literal> is
        <literal>3E11FA47-71CA-11E1-9E33-C80AA9429562</literal> until it
        encounters the transaction having sequence number 11; it then
        stops without processing this transaction. In other words, all
        transactions up to and including the transaction with sequence
        number 10 are processed. Executing <literal>START SLAVE
        SQL_THREAD UNTIL SQL_AFTER_GTIDS =
        3E11FA47-71CA-11E1-9E33-C80AA9429562:11-56</literal>, on the
        other hand, would cause the slave SQL thread to obtain all
        transactions just mentioned from the master, including all of
        the transactions having the sequence numbers 11 through 56, and
        then to stop without processing any additional transactions;
        that is, the transaction having sequence number 56 would be the
        last transaction fetched by the slave SQL thread.

When using a multithreaded slave



        with <literal>slave_preserve_commit_order=0</literal> set, there
        is a chance of gaps in the sequence of transactions that have
        been executed from the relay log in the following cases:

itemizedlist.para: killing the coordinator thread
after an error occurs in the applier threads
<command>mysqld</command> shuts down unexpectedly

description.para:
Use the <literal condition="start-slave" role="stmt">START SLAVE
        UNTIL SQL_AFTER_MTS_GAPS</literal> statement to cause a
        multithreaded slave's worker threads to only run until no
        more gaps are found in the relay log, and then to stop. This
        statement can take an <literal>SQL_THREAD</literal> option, but
        the effects of the statement remain unchanged. It has no effect
        on the slave I/O thread (and cannot be used with the
        <literal>IO_THREAD</literal> option).

Issuing <literal role="stmt">START SLAVE</literal> on a
        multithreaded slave with gaps in the sequence of transactions
        executed from the relay log generates a warning. In such a
        situation, the solution is to use
        <literal condition="start-slave" role="stmt">START SLAVE UNTIL
        SQL_AFTER_MTS_GAPS</literal>, then issue
        <literal role="stmt">RESET SLAVE</literal> to remove any
        remaining relay logs. See
        <xref linkend="replication-features-transaction-inconsistencies" />
        for more information.

To change a failed multithreaded slave to single-threaded mode,
        you can issue the following series of statements, in the order
        shown:

syntax.programlisting:
>
START SLAVE [<replaceable>thread_types</replaceable>] [<replaceable>until_option</replaceable>] [<replaceable>connection_options</replaceable>] [<replaceable>channel_option</replaceable>]

<replaceable>thread_types</replaceable>:
    [<replaceable>thread_type</replaceable> [, <replaceable>thread_type</replaceable>] ... ]

<replaceable>thread_type</replaceable>:
    IO_THREAD | SQL_THREAD

<replaceable>until_option</replaceable>:
    UNTIL {   {SQL_BEFORE_GTIDS | SQL_AFTER_GTIDS} = <replaceable>gtid_set</replaceable>
          |   MASTER_LOG_FILE = '<replaceable>log_name</replaceable>', MASTER_LOG_POS = <replaceable>log_pos</replaceable>
          |   RELAY_LOG_FILE = '<replaceable>log_name</replaceable>', RELAY_LOG_POS = <replaceable>log_pos</replaceable>
          |   SQL_AFTER_MTS_GAPS  }

<replaceable>connection_options</replaceable>:
    [USER='<replaceable>user_name</replaceable>'] [PASSWORD='<replaceable>user_pass</replaceable>'] [DEFAULT_AUTH='<replaceable>plugin_name</replaceable>'] [PLUGIN_DIR='<replaceable>plugin_dir</replaceable>']


<replaceable>channel_option</replaceable>:
    FOR CHANNEL <replaceable>channel</replaceable>

<replaceable>gtid_set</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>uuid_set</replaceable> [, <replaceable>uuid_set</replaceable>] ...
    | ''

<replaceable>uuid_set</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>uuid</replaceable>:<replaceable>interval</replaceable>[:<replaceable>interval</replaceable>]...

<replaceable>uuid</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>hhhhhhhh</replaceable>-<replaceable>hhhh</replaceable>-<replaceable>hhhh</replaceable>-<replaceable>hhhh</replaceable>-<replaceable>hhhhhhhhhhhh</replaceable>

<replaceable>h</replaceable>:
    [0-9,A-F]

<replaceable>interval</replaceable>:
    <replaceable>n</replaceable>[-<replaceable>n</replaceable>]

    (<replaceable>n</replaceable> >= 1)

description.para:
Stops the slave threads. <literal role="stmt">STOP
        SLAVE</literal> requires the
        <literal role="priv">REPLICATION_SLAVE_ADMIN</literal> or
        <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege. Recommended best
        practice is to execute <literal>STOP SLAVE</literal> on the
        slave before stopping the slave server (see
        <xref linkend="server-shutdown" />, for more information).

<emphasis>When using the row-based logging format</emphasis>:
        You should execute <literal>STOP SLAVE</literal> or
        <literal>STOP SLAVE SQL_THREAD</literal> on the slave prior to
        shutting down the slave server if you are replicating any tables
        that use a nontransactional storage engine (see the
        <citetitle>Note</citetitle> later in this section).

Like <literal role="stmt">START SLAVE</literal>, this statement
        may be used with the <literal>IO_THREAD</literal> and
        <literal>SQL_THREAD</literal> options to name the thread or
        threads to be stopped. Note that the Group Replication applier
        channel (<literal>group_replication_applier</literal>) has no
        I/O thread, only a SQL thread. Using the
        <literal>SQL_THREAD</literal> option therefore stops this
        channel completely.

<literal>STOP SLAVE</literal> causes an implicit commit of an
        ongoing transaction. See <xref linkend="implicit-commit" />.

<literal role="sysvar">gtid_next</literal> must be set to
        <literal>AUTOMATIC</literal> before issuing this statement.

You can control how long <literal>STOP SLAVE</literal> waits
        before timing out by setting the
        <literal role="sysvar">rpl_stop_slave_timeout</literal> system
        variable. This can be used to avoid deadlocks between
        <literal>STOP SLAVE</literal> and other slave SQL statements
        using different client connections to the slave. When the
        timeout value is reached, the issuing client returns an error
        message and stops waiting, but the <literal>STOP SLAVE</literal>
        instruction remains in effect. Once the slave threads are no
        longer busy, the <literal>STOP SLAVE</literal> statement is
        executed and the slave stops.

Some <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal> statements are allowed
        while the slave is running, depending on the states of the slave
        SQL and I/O threads. However, using <literal>STOP
        SLAVE</literal> prior to executing <literal>CHANGE MASTER
        TO</literal> in such cases is still supported. See
        <xref linkend="change-master-to" />, and
        <xref linkend="replication-solutions-switch" />, for more
        information.

The optional <literal>FOR CHANNEL
        <replaceable>channel</replaceable></literal> clause enables you
        to name which replication channel the statement applies to.
        Providing a <literal>FOR CHANNEL
        <replaceable>channel</replaceable></literal> clause applies the
        <literal>STOP SLAVE</literal> statement to a specific
        replication channel. If no channel is named and no extra
        channels exist, the statement applies to the default channel. If
        a <literal>STOP SLAVE</literal> statement does not name a
        channel when using multiple channels, this statement stops the
        specified threads for all channels. This statement cannot be
        used with the <literal>group_replication_recovery</literal>
        channel. See <xref linkend="replication-channels" /> for more
        information.

<emphasis>When using statement-based replication</emphasis>:
        changing the master while it has open temporary tables is
        potentially unsafe. This is one of the reasons why
        statement-based replication of temporary tables is not
        recommended. You can find out whether there are any temporary
        tables on the slave by checking the value of
        <literal role="statvar">Slave_open_temp_tables</literal>; when
        using statement-based replication, this value should be 0 before
        executing <literal>CHANGE MASTER TO</literal>. If there are any
        temporary tables open on the slave, issuing a <literal>CHANGE
        MASTER TO</literal> statement after issuing a <literal>STOP
        SLAVE</literal> causes an
        <literal role="error">ER_WARN_OPEN_TEMP_TABLES_MUST_BE_ZERO</literal>
        warning.

When using a multithreaded slave
        (<literal role="sysvar">slave_parallel_workers</literal> is a
        nonzero value), any gaps in the sequence of transactions
        executed from the relay log are closed as part of stopping the
        worker threads. If the slave is stopped unexpectedly (for
        example due to an error in a worker thread, or another thread
        issuing <literal role="stmt">KILL</literal>) while a
        <literal role="stmt">STOP SLAVE</literal> statement is
        executing, the sequence of executed transactions from the relay
        log may become inconsistent. See
        <xref linkend="replication-features-transaction-inconsistencies" />
        for more information.

If the current replication event group has modified one or more
        nontransactional tables, STOP SLAVE waits for up to 60 seconds
        for the event group to complete, unless you issue a
        <literal condition="kill" role="stmt">KILL QUERY</literal> or
        <literal condition="kill" role="stmt">KILL CONNECTION</literal>
        statement for the slave SQL thread. If the event group remains
        incomplete after the timeout, an error message is logged.

syntax.programlisting:
>
STOP SLAVE [<replaceable>thread_types</replaceable>] [<replaceable>channel_option</replaceable>]

<replaceable>thread_types</replaceable>:
    [<replaceable>thread_type</replaceable> [, <replaceable>thread_type</replaceable>] ... ]

<replaceable>thread_type</replaceable>: IO_THREAD | SQL_THREAD

<replaceable>channel_option</replaceable>:
    FOR CHANNEL <replaceable>channel</replaceable>

description.para:
The <literal role="stmt">ALTER USER</literal> statement modifies
        MySQL accounts. It enables authentication, role, SSL/TLS,
        resource-limit, and password-management properties to be
        modified for existing accounts. It can also be used to lock and
        unlock accounts.

In most cases, <literal role="stmt">ALTER USER</literal>
        requires the global <literal role="priv">CREATE USER</literal>
        privilege, or the <literal role="priv">UPDATE</literal>
        privilege for the <literal>mysql</literal> system schema. The
        exceptions are:

itemizedlist.para:
Any client who connects to the server using a nonanonymous
            account can change the password for that account. (In
            particular, you can change your own password.) To see which
            account the server authenticated you as, invoke the
            <literal role="func">CURRENT_USER()</literal> function:

For <literal>DEFAULT ROLE</literal> syntax,
            <literal role="stmt">ALTER USER</literal> requires these
            privileges:

Setting the default roles for another user requires the
                global <literal role="priv">CREATE USER</literal>
                privilege, or the <literal role="priv">UPDATE</literal>
                privilege for the <literal>mysql.default_roles</literal>
                system table.

Setting the default roles for yourself requires no
                special privileges, as long as the roles you want as the
                default have been granted to you.

Statements that modify secondary passwords require these
            privileges:

The
                <literal role="priv">APPLICATION_PASSWORD_ADMIN</literal>
                privilege is required to use the <literal>RETAIN CURRENT
                PASSWORD</literal> or <literal>DISCARD OLD
                PASSWORD</literal> clause for <literal role="stmt">ALTER
                USER</literal> statements that apply to your own
                account. The privilege is required to manipulate your
                own secondary password because most users require only
                one password.

If an account is to be permitted to manipulate secondary
                passwords for all accounts, it requires the
                <literal role="priv">CREATE USER</literal> privilege
                rather than
                <literal role="priv">APPLICATION_PASSWORD_ADMIN</literal>.

description.para:
When the <literal role="sysvar">read_only</literal> system
        variable is enabled, <literal role="stmt">ALTER USER</literal>
        additionally requires the
        <literal role="priv">CONNECTION_ADMIN</literal> or
        <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege.

By default, an error occurs if you try to modify a user that
        does not exist. If the <literal>IF EXISTS</literal> clause is
        given, the statement produces a warning for each named user that
        does not exist, rather than an error.

syntax.programlisting:
>
ALTER USER [IF EXISTS]
    <replaceable>user</replaceable> [<replaceable>auth_option</replaceable>] [, <replaceable>user</replaceable> [<replaceable>auth_option</replaceable>]] ...
    [REQUIRE {NONE | <replaceable>tls_option</replaceable> [[AND] <replaceable>tls_option</replaceable>] ...}]
    [WITH <replaceable>resource_option</replaceable> [<replaceable>resource_option</replaceable>] ...]
    [<replaceable>password_option</replaceable> | <replaceable>lock_option</replaceable>] ...

ALTER USER [IF EXISTS] USER() <replaceable>user_func_auth_option</replaceable>

ALTER USER [IF EXISTS]
    <replaceable>user</replaceable> DEFAULT ROLE
    {NONE | ALL | <replaceable>role</replaceable> [, <replaceable>role</replaceable> ] ...}

<replaceable>user</replaceable>:
    (see <xref linkend="account-names" />)

<replaceable>auth_option</replaceable>: {
    IDENTIFIED BY '<replaceable>auth_string</replaceable>'
        [REPLACE '<replaceable>current_auth_string</replaceable>']
        [RETAIN CURRENT PASSWORD]
  | IDENTIFIED BY RANDOM PASSWORD
        [REPLACE '<replaceable>current_auth_string</replaceable>']
        [RETAIN CURRENT PASSWORD]
  | IDENTIFIED WITH <replaceable>auth_plugin</replaceable>
  | IDENTIFIED WITH <replaceable>auth_plugin</replaceable> BY '<replaceable>auth_string</replaceable>'
        [REPLACE '<replaceable>current_auth_string</replaceable>']
        [RETAIN CURRENT PASSWORD]
  | IDENTIFIED WITH <replaceable>auth_plugin</replaceable> BY RANDOM PASSWORD
        [REPLACE '<replaceable>current_auth_string</replaceable>']
        [RETAIN CURRENT PASSWORD]
  | IDENTIFIED WITH <replaceable>auth_plugin</replaceable> AS '<replaceable>auth_string</replaceable>'
  | DISCARD OLD PASSWORD
}

<replaceable>user_func_auth_option</replaceable>: {
    IDENTIFIED BY '<replaceable>auth_string</replaceable>'
        [REPLACE '<replaceable>current_auth_string</replaceable>']
        [RETAIN CURRENT PASSWORD]
  | DISCARD OLD PASSWORD
}

<replaceable>tls_option</replaceable>: {
   SSL
 | X509
 | CIPHER '<replaceable>cipher</replaceable>'
 | ISSUER '<replaceable>issuer</replaceable>'
 | SUBJECT '<replaceable>subject</replaceable>'
}

<replaceable>resource_option</replaceable>: {
    MAX_QUERIES_PER_HOUR <replaceable>count</replaceable>
  | MAX_UPDATES_PER_HOUR <replaceable>count</replaceable>
  | MAX_CONNECTIONS_PER_HOUR <replaceable>count</replaceable>
  | MAX_USER_CONNECTIONS <replaceable>count</replaceable>
}

<replaceable>password_option</replaceable>: {
    PASSWORD EXPIRE [DEFAULT | NEVER | INTERVAL <replaceable>N</replaceable> DAY]
  | PASSWORD HISTORY {DEFAULT | <replaceable>N</replaceable>}
  | PASSWORD REUSE INTERVAL {DEFAULT | <replaceable>N</replaceable> DAY}
  | PASSWORD REQUIRE CURRENT [DEFAULT | OPTIONAL]
  | FAILED_LOGIN_ATTEMPTS <replaceable>N</replaceable>
  | PASSWORD_LOCK_TIME {<replaceable>N</replaceable> | UNBOUNDED}
}

<replaceable>lock_option</replaceable>: {
    ACCOUNT LOCK
  | ACCOUNT UNLOCK
}

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">CREATE ROLE</literal> creates one or more
        roles, which are named collections of privileges. To use this
        statement, you must have the global <literal role="priv">CREATE
        ROLE</literal> or <literal role="priv">CREATE USER</literal>
        privilege. When the <literal role="sysvar">read_only</literal>
        system variable is enabled, <literal role="stmt">CREATE
        ROLE</literal> additionally requires the
        <literal role="priv">CONNECTION_ADMIN</literal> or
        <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege.

A role when created is locked, has no password, and is assigned
        the default authentication plugin. (These role attributes can be
        changed later with the <literal role="stmt">ALTER USER</literal>
        statement, by users who have the global
        <literal role="priv">CREATE USER</literal> privilege.)

<literal role="stmt">CREATE ROLE</literal> either succeeds for
        all named roles or rolls back and has no effect if any error
        occurs. By default, an error occurs if you try to create a role
        that already exists. If the <literal>IF NOT EXISTS</literal>
        clause is given, the statement produces a warning for each named
        role that already exists, rather than an error.

The statement is written to the binary log if it succeeds, but
        not if it fails; in that case, rollback occurs and no changes
        are made. A statement written to the binary log includes all
        named roles. If the <literal>IF NOT EXISTS</literal> clause is
        given, this includes even roles that already exist and were not
        created.

Each role name uses the format described in
        <xref linkend="role-names" />. For example:

The host name part of the role name, if omitted, defaults to
        <literal>'%'</literal>.
For role usage examples, see <xref linkend="roles" />.

The <literal role="stmt">CREATE USER</literal> statement creates
        new MySQL accounts. It enables authentication, role, SSL/TLS,
        resource-limit, and password-management properties to be
        established for new accounts. It also controls whether accounts
        are initially locked or unlocked.

To use <literal role="stmt">CREATE USER</literal>, you must have
        the global <literal role="priv">CREATE USER</literal> privilege,
        or the <literal role="priv">INSERT</literal> privilege for the
        <literal>mysql</literal> system schema. When the
        <literal role="sysvar">read_only</literal> system variable is
        enabled, <literal role="stmt">CREATE USER</literal> additionally
        requires the <literal role="priv">CONNECTION_ADMIN</literal> or
        <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege.

<literal role="stmt">CREATE USER</literal> either succeeds for
        all named users or rolls back and has no effect if any error
        occurs. By default, an error occurs if you try to create a user
        that already exists. If the <literal>IF NOT EXISTS</literal>
        clause is given, the statement produces a warning for each named
        user that already exists, rather than an error.

<literal role="stmt">DROP ROLE</literal> removes one or more
        roles (named collections of privileges). To use this statement,
        you must have the global <literal role="priv">DROP
        ROLE</literal> or <literal role="priv">CREATE USER</literal>
        privilege. When the <literal role="sysvar">read_only</literal>
        system variable is enabled, <literal role="stmt">DROP
        ROLE</literal> additionally requires the
        <literal role="priv">CONNECTION_ADMIN</literal> or
        <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege.

As of MySQL 8.0.16, users who have the
        <literal role="priv">CREATE USER</literal> privilege can use
        this statement to drop accounts that are locked or unlocked.
        Users who have the <literal role="priv">DROP ROLE</literal>
        privilege can use this statement only to drop accounts that are
        locked (unlocked accounts are presumably user accounts used to
        log in to the server and not just as roles).

Roles named in the
        <literal role="sysvar">mandatory_roles</literal> system variable
        value cannot be dropped.

<literal role="stmt">DROP ROLE</literal> either succeeds for all
        named roles or rolls back and has no effect if any error occurs.
        By default, an error occurs if you try to drop a role that does
        not exist. If the <literal>IF EXISTS</literal> clause is given,
        the statement produces a warning for each named role that does
        not exist, rather than an error.

The statement is written to the binary log if it succeeds, but
        not if it fails; in that case, rollback occurs and no changes
        are made. A statement written to the binary log includes all
        named roles. If the <literal>IF EXISTS</literal> clause is
        given, this includes even roles that do not exist and were not
        dropped.

Each role name uses the format described in
        <xref linkend="role-names" />. For example:

The host name part of the role name, if omitted, defaults to
        <literal>'%'</literal>.

A dropped role is automatically revoked from any user account
        (or role) to which the role was granted. Within any current
        session for such an account, its adjusted privileges apply
        beginning with the next statement executed.

The <literal role="stmt">DROP USER</literal> statement removes
        one or more MySQL accounts and their privileges. It removes
        privilege rows for the account from all grant tables.

Roles named in the
        <literal role="sysvar">mandatory_roles</literal> system variable
        value cannot be dropped.

To use <literal role="stmt">DROP USER</literal>, you must have
        the global <literal role="priv">CREATE USER</literal> privilege,
        or the <literal role="priv">DELETE</literal> privilege for the
        <literal>mysql</literal> system schema. When the
        <literal role="sysvar">read_only</literal> system variable is
        enabled, <literal role="stmt">DROP USER</literal> additionally
        requires the <literal role="priv">CONNECTION_ADMIN</literal> or
        <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege.

<literal role="stmt">DROP USER</literal> either succeeds for all
        named users or rolls back and has no effect if any error occurs.
        By default, an error occurs if you try to drop a user that does
        not exist. If the <literal>IF EXISTS</literal> clause is given,
        the statement produces a warning for each named user that does
        not exist, rather than an error.

The statement is written to the binary log if it succeeds, but
        not if it fails; in that case, rollback occurs and no changes
        are made. A statement written to the binary log includes all
        named users. If the <literal>IF EXISTS</literal> clause is
        given, this includes even users that do not exist and were not
        dropped.

Each account name uses the format described in
        <xref linkend="account-names" />. For example:

description.programlisting:
>
DROP USER 'jeffrey'@'localhost';

description.para:
The host name part of the account name, if omitted, defaults to
        <literal>'%'</literal>.

syntax.programlisting:
>
GRANT
    <replaceable>priv_type</replaceable> [(<replaceable>column_list</replaceable>)]
      [, <replaceable>priv_type</replaceable> [(<replaceable>column_list</replaceable>)]] ...
    ON [<replaceable>object_type</replaceable>] <replaceable>priv_level</replaceable>
    TO <replaceable>user_or_role</replaceable> [, <replaceable>user_or_role</replaceable>] ...
    [WITH GRANT OPTION]
    [AS <replaceable>user</replaceable>
        [WITH ROLE
            DEFAULT
          | NONE
          | ALL
          | ALL EXCEPT <replaceable>role</replaceable> [, <replaceable>role</replaceable> ] ...
          | <replaceable>role</replaceable> [, <replaceable>role</replaceable> ] ...
        ]
    ]
}

GRANT PROXY ON <replaceable>user_or_role</replaceable>
    TO <replaceable>user_or_role</replaceable> [, <replaceable>user_or_role</replaceable>] ...
    [WITH GRANT OPTION]

GRANT <replaceable>role</replaceable> [, <replaceable>role</replaceable>] ...
    TO <replaceable>user_or_role</replaceable> [, <replaceable>user_or_role</replaceable>] ...
    [WITH ADMIN OPTION]

<replaceable>object_type</replaceable>: {
    TABLE
  | FUNCTION
  | PROCEDURE
}

<replaceable>priv_level</replaceable>: {
    *
  | *.*
  | <replaceable>db_name</replaceable>.*
  | <replaceable>db_name.tbl_name</replaceable>
  | <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>
  | <replaceable>db_name</replaceable>.<replaceable>routine_name</replaceable>
}

<replaceable>user_or_role</replaceable>: {
    <replaceable>user</replaceable> (see <xref linkend="account-names" />)
  | <replaceable>role</replaceable> (see <xref linkend="role-names" />)
}

syntax.para:
The <literal role="stmt">GRANT</literal> statement assigns
        privileges and roles to MySQL user accounts and roles. There are
        several aspects to the <literal role="stmt">GRANT</literal>
        statement, described under the following topics:

description.para:
The <literal role="stmt">RENAME USER</literal> statement renames
        existing MySQL accounts. An error occurs for old accounts that
        do not exist or new accounts that already exist.

To use <literal role="stmt">RENAME USER</literal>, you must have
        the global <literal role="priv">CREATE USER</literal> privilege,
        or the <literal role="priv">UPDATE</literal> privilege for the
        <literal>mysql</literal> system schema. When the
        <literal role="sysvar">read_only</literal> system variable is
        enabled, <literal role="stmt">RENAME USER</literal> additionally
        requires the <literal role="priv">CONNECTION_ADMIN</literal> or
        <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege.

Each account name uses the format described in
        <xref linkend="account-names" />. For example:

description.programlisting:
>
RENAME USER 'jeffrey'@'localhost' TO 'jeff'@'127.0.0.1';

description.para:
The host name part of the account name, if omitted, defaults to
        <literal>'%'</literal>.

<literal role="stmt">RENAME USER</literal> causes the privileges
        held by the old user to be those held by the new user. However,
        <literal role="stmt">RENAME USER</literal> does not
        automatically drop or invalidate databases or objects within
        them that the old user created. This includes stored programs or
        views for which the <literal>DEFINER</literal> attribute names
        the old user. Attempts to access such objects may produce an
        error if they execute in definer security context. (For
        information about security context, see
        <xref linkend="stored-objects-security" />.)

The privilege changes take effect as indicated in
        <xref linkend="privilege-changes" />.

The <literal role="stmt">REVOKE</literal> statement enables
        system administrators to revoke privileges and roles, which can
        be revoked from user accounts and roles.

For details on the levels at which privileges exist, the
        permissible <replaceable>priv_type</replaceable>,
        <replaceable>priv_level</replaceable>, and
        <replaceable>object_type</replaceable> values, and the syntax
        for specifying users and passwords, see <xref linkend="grant" />.
For information about roles, see <xref linkend="roles" />.

When the <literal role="sysvar">read_only</literal> system
        variable is enabled, <literal role="stmt">REVOKE</literal>
        requires the <literal role="priv">CONNECTION_ADMIN</literal> or
        <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege in addition to
        any other required privileges described in the following
        discussion.

<literal role="stmt">REVOKE</literal> either succeeds for all
        named users and roles or rolls back and has no effect if any
        error occurs. The statement is written to the binary log only if
        it succeeds for all named users and roles.

Each account name uses the format described in
        <xref linkend="account-names" />. Each role name uses the format
        described in <xref linkend="role-names" />. For example:

The host name part of the account or role name, if omitted,
        defaults to <literal>'%'</literal>.

To use the first <literal role="stmt">REVOKE</literal> syntax,
        you must have the <literal role="priv">GRANT OPTION</literal>
        privilege, and you must have the privileges that you are
        revoking.

To revoke all privileges, use the second syntax, which drops all
        global, database, table, column, and routine privileges for the
        named users or roles:

description.programlisting:
>
REVOKE ALL PRIVILEGES, GRANT OPTION
  FROM <replaceable>user_or_role</replaceable> [, <replaceable>user_or_role</replaceable>] ...

description.para:
<literal>REVOKE ALL PRIVILEGES, GRANT OPTION</literal> does not
        revoke any roles.

To use this <literal role="stmt">REVOKE</literal> syntax, you
        must have the global <literal role="priv">CREATE USER</literal>
        privilege, or the <literal role="priv">UPDATE</literal>
        privilege for the <literal>mysql</literal> system schema.

The syntax for which the <literal role="stmt">REVOKE</literal>
        keyword is followed by one or more role names takes a
        <literal>FROM</literal> clause indicating one or more users or
        roles from which to revoke the roles.

Roles named in the
        <literal role="sysvar">mandatory_roles</literal> system variable
        value cannot be revoked.

A revoked role immediately affects any user account from which
        it was revoked, such that within any current session for the
        account, its privileges are adjusted for the next statement
        executed.

Revoking a role revokes the role itself, not the privileges that
        it represents. Suppose that an account is granted a role that
        includes a given privilege, and is also granted the privilege
        explicitly or another role that includes the privilege. In this
        case, the account still possesses that privilege if the first
        role is revoked. For example, if an account is granted two roles
        that each include <literal role="priv">SELECT</literal>, the
        account still can select after either role is revoked.

<literal>REVOKE ALL ON *.*</literal> (at the global level)
        revokes all granted static global privileges and all granted
        dynamic privileges.

User accounts and roles from which privileges and roles are to
        be revoked must exist, but the privileges and roles to be
        revoked need not be currently granted to them.

A revoked privilege that is granted but not known to the server
        is revoked with a warning. This situtation can occur for dynamic
        privileges. For example, a dynamic privilege can be granted
        while the component that registers it is installed, but if that
        component is subsequently uninstalled, the privilege becomes
        unregistered, although accounts that possess the privilege still
        possess it and it can be revoked from them.

syntax.programlisting:
>
REVOKE
    <replaceable>priv_type</replaceable> [(<replaceable>column_list</replaceable>)]
      [, <replaceable>priv_type</replaceable> [(<replaceable>column_list</replaceable>)]] ...
    ON [<replaceable>object_type</replaceable>] <replaceable>priv_level</replaceable>
    FROM <replaceable>user_or_role</replaceable> [, <replaceable>user_or_role</replaceable>] ...

REVOKE ALL [PRIVILEGES], GRANT OPTION
    FROM <replaceable>user_or_role</replaceable> [, <replaceable>user_or_role</replaceable>] ...

REVOKE PROXY ON <replaceable>user_or_role</replaceable>
    FROM <replaceable>user_or_role</replaceable> [, <replaceable>user_or_role</replaceable>] ...

REVOKE <replaceable>role</replaceable> [, <replaceable>role</replaceable> ] ...
    FROM <replaceable>user_or_role</replaceable> [, <replaceable>user_or_role</replaceable> ] ...

<replaceable>user_or_role</replaceable>: {
    <replaceable>user</replaceable> (see <xref linkend="account-names" />)
  | <replaceable>role</replaceable> (see <xref linkend="role-names" />.
}

description.para:
For each <replaceable>user</replaceable> named immediately after
        the <literal>TO</literal> keyword, this statement defines which
        roles become active when the user connects to the server and
        authenticates, or when the user executes the
        <literal condition="set-role" role="stmt">SET ROLE
        DEFAULT</literal> statement during a session.

<literal role="stmt">SET DEFAULT ROLE</literal> is alternative
        syntax for <literal condition="alter-user" role="stmt">ALTER
        USER ... DEFAULT ROLE</literal> (see
        <xref linkend="alter-user" />). However,
        <literal role="stmt">ALTER USER</literal> can set the default
        for only a single user, whereas <literal role="stmt">SET DEFAULT
        ROLE</literal> can set the default for multiple users. On the
        other hand, you can specify <literal>CURRENT_USER</literal> as
        the user name for the <literal role="stmt">ALTER USER</literal>
        statement, whereas you cannot for <literal role="stmt">SET
        DEFAULT ROLE</literal>.

<literal role="stmt">SET DEFAULT ROLE</literal> requires these
        privileges:

itemizedlist.para:
