Setting the default roles for another user requires the
            global <literal role="priv">CREATE USER</literal> privilege,
            or the <literal role="priv">UPDATE</literal> privilege for
            the <literal>mysql.default_roles</literal> system table.

Setting the default roles for yourself requires no special
            privileges, as long as the roles you want as the default
            have been granted to you.

description.para:
Each role name uses the format described in
        <xref linkend="role-names" />. For example:

description.programlisting:
>
SET DEFAULT ROLE administrator, developer TO 'joe'@'10.0.0.1';

description.para:
The host name part of the role name, if omitted, defaults to
        <literal>'%'</literal>.

The clause following the <literal>DEFAULT ROLE</literal>
        keywords permits these values:

itemizedlist.para:
<literal>NONE</literal>: Set the default to
            <literal>NONE</literal> (no roles).

<literal>ALL</literal>: Set the default to all roles granted
            to the account.

<literal><replaceable>role</replaceable> [,
            <replaceable>role</replaceable> ] ...</literal>: Set the
            default to the named roles, which must exist and be granted
            to the account at the time <literal role="stmt">SET DEFAULT
            ROLE</literal> is executed.

description.para:
The <literal role="stmt">SET PASSWORD</literal> statement
        assigns a password to a MySQL user account. The password may be
        either explicitly specified in the statement or randomly
        generated by MySQL. The statement may also include a
        password-verification clause that specifies the account current
        password to be replaced, and a clause that manages whether an
        account has a secondary password.
        <literal>'<replaceable>auth_string</replaceable>'</literal> and
        <literal>'<replaceable>current_auth_string</replaceable>'</literal>
        each represent a cleartext (unencrypted) password.

The <literal>REPLACE
        '<replaceable>current_auth_string</replaceable>'</literal>
        clause performs password verification and is available as of
        MySQL 8.0.13. If given:

itemizedlist.para:
<literal>REPLACE</literal> specifies the account current
            password to be replaced, as a cleartext (unencrypted)
            string.

The clause must be given if password changes for the account
            are required to specify the current password, as
            verification that the user attempting to make the change
            actually knows the current password.

The clause is optional if password changes for the account
            may but need not specify the current password.

The statement fails if the clause is given but does not
            match the current password, even if the clause is optional.

<literal>REPLACE</literal> can be specified only when
            changing the account password for the current user.

description.para:
For more information about password verification by specifying
        the current password, see <xref linkend="password-management" />.

The <literal>RETAIN CURRENT PASSWORD</literal> clause implements
        dual-password capability and is available as of MySQL 8.0.14. If
        given:

itemizedlist.para:
<literal>RETAIN CURRENT PASSWORD</literal> retains an
            account current password as its secondary password,
            replacing any existing secondary password. The new password
            becomes the primary password, but clients can use the
            account to connect to the server using either the primary or
            secondary password. (Exception: If the new password
            specified by the <literal role="stmt">SET PASSWORD</literal>
            statement is empty, the secondary password becomes empty as
            well, even if <literal>RETAIN CURRENT PASSWORD</literal> is
            given.)

If you specify <literal>RETAIN CURRENT PASSWORD</literal>
            for an account that has an empty primary password, the
            statement fails.

If an account has a secondary password and you change its
            primary password without specifying <literal>RETAIN CURRENT
            PASSWORD</literal>, the secondary password remains
            unchanged.

description.para:
For more information about use of dual passwords, see
        <xref linkend="password-management" />.

<literal role="stmt">SET PASSWORD</literal> permits these
        <replaceable>auth_option</replaceable> syntaxes:

itemizedlist.para:
<literal>=
            '<replaceable>auth_string</replaceable>'</literal>
Assigns the account the given literal password.
<literal>TO RANDOM</literal>

Assigns the account a password randomly generated by MySQL.
            The statement also returns the cleartext password in a
            result set to make it available to the user or application
            executing the statement.

For details about the result set and characteristics of
            randomly generated passwords, see
            <xref linkend="random-password-generation" />.
Random password generation is available as of MySQL 8.0.18.

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">SET PASSWORD</literal> can be used with or
        without a <literal>FOR</literal> clause that explicitly names a
        user account:

itemizedlist.para:
With a <literal>FOR
            <replaceable>user</replaceable></literal> clause, the
            statement sets the password for the named account, which
            must exist:

With no <literal>FOR
            <replaceable>user</replaceable></literal> clause, the
            statement sets the password for the current user:

Any client who connects to the server using a nonanonymous
            account can change the password for that account. (In
            particular, you can change your own password.) To see which
            account the server authenticated you as, invoke the
            <literal role="func">CURRENT_USER()</literal> function:

description.para:
If a <literal>FOR <replaceable>user</replaceable></literal>
        clause is given, the account name uses the format described in
        <xref linkend="account-names" />. For example:

description.programlisting:
>
SET PASSWORD FOR 'bob'@'%.example.org' = '<replaceable>auth_string</replaceable>';

description.para:
The host name part of the account name, if omitted, defaults to
        <literal>'%'</literal>.

<literal role="stmt">SET PASSWORD</literal> interprets the
        string as a cleartext string, passes it to the authentication
        plugin associated with the account, and stores the result
        returned by the plugin in the account row in the
        <literal>mysql.user</literal> system table. (The plugin is given
        the opportunity to hash the value into the encryption format it
        expects. The plugin may use the value as specified, in which
        case no hashing occurs.)

Setting the password for a named account (with a
        <literal>FOR</literal> clause) requires the
        <literal role="stmt">UPDATE</literal> privilege for the
        <literal>mysql</literal> system schema. Setting the password for
        yourself (for a nonanonymous account with no
        <literal>FOR</literal> clause) requires no special privileges.

Statements that modify secondary passwords require these
        privileges:

itemizedlist.para:
The
            <literal role="priv">APPLICATION_PASSWORD_ADMIN</literal>
            privilege is required to use the <literal>RETAIN CURRENT
            PASSWORD</literal> clause for <literal role="stmt">SET
            PASSWORD</literal> statements that apply to your own
            account. The privilege is required to manipulate your own
            secondary password because most users require only one
            password.

If an account is to be permitted to manipulate secondary
            passwords for all accounts, it should be granted the
            <literal role="priv">CREATE USER</literal> privilege rather
            than
            <literal role="priv">APPLICATION_PASSWORD_ADMIN</literal>.

description.para:
When the <literal role="sysvar">read_only</literal> system
        variable is enabled, <literal role="stmt">SET PASSWORD</literal>
        requires the <literal role="priv">CONNECTION_ADMIN</literal> or
        <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege in addition to
        any other required privileges.

syntax.programlisting:
>
SET PASSWORD [FOR <replaceable>user</replaceable>] <replaceable>auth_option</replaceable>
    [REPLACE '<replaceable>current_auth_string</replaceable>']
    [RETAIN CURRENT PASSWORD]

<replaceable>auth_option</replaceable>: {
    = '<replaceable>auth_string</replaceable>'
  | TO RANDOM
}

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">SET ROLE</literal> modifies the current
        user's effective privileges within the current session by
        specifying which of its granted roles are active. Granted roles
        include those granted explicitly to the user and those named in
        the <literal role="sysvar">mandatory_roles</literal> system
        variable value.
Examples:

Each role name uses the format described in
        <xref linkend="role-names" />. The host name part of the role
        name, if omitted, defaults to <literal>'%'</literal>.

Privileges that the user has been granted directly (rather than
        through roles) remain unaffected by changes to the active roles.
The statement permits these role specifiers:

itemizedlist.para:
<literal>DEFAULT</literal>: Activate the account default
            roles. Default roles are those specified with
            <literal role="stmt">SET DEFAULT ROLE</literal>.

When a user connects to the server and authenticates
            successfully, the server determines which roles to activate
            as the default roles. If the
            <literal role="sysvar">activate_all_roles_on_login</literal>
            system variable is enabled, the server activates all granted
            roles. Otherwise, the server executes
            <literal condition="set-role" role="stmt">SET ROLE
            DEFAULT</literal> implicitly. The server activates only
            default roles that can be activated. The server writes
            warnings to its error log for default roles that cannot be
            activated, but the client receives no warnings.

If a user executes
            <literal condition="set-role" role="stmt">SET ROLE
            DEFAULT</literal> during a session, an error occurs if any
            default role cannot be activated (for example, if it does
            not exist or is not granted to the user). In this case, the
            current active roles are not changed.

<literal>NONE</literal>: Set the active roles to
            <literal>NONE</literal> (no active roles).

<literal>ALL</literal>: Activate all roles granted to the
            account.

<literal>ALL EXCEPT <replaceable>role</replaceable> [,
            <replaceable>role</replaceable> ] ...</literal>: Activate
            all roles granted to the account except those named. The
            named roles need not exist or be granted to the account.

<literal><replaceable>role</replaceable> [,
            <replaceable>role</replaceable> ] ...</literal>: Activate
            the named roles, which must be granted to the account.

syntax.programlisting:
>
SET ROLE {
    DEFAULT
  | NONE
  | ALL
  | ALL EXCEPT <replaceable>role</replaceable> [, <replaceable>role</replaceable> ] ...
  | <replaceable>role</replaceable> [, <replaceable>role</replaceable> ] ...
}

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">ALTER RESOURCE GROUP</literal> is used for
        resource group management (see
        <xref linkend="resource-groups" />). This statement alters
        modifiable attributes of an existing resource group. It requires
        the <literal role="priv">RESOURCE_GROUP_ADMIN</literal>
        privilege.

<replaceable>group_name</replaceable> identifies which resource
        group to alter. If the group does not exist, an error occurs.

The attributes for CPU affinity, priority, and whether the group
        is enabled can be modified with <literal role="stmt">ALTER
        RESOURCE GROUP</literal>. These attributes are specified the
        same way as described for <literal role="stmt">CREATE RESOURCE
        GROUP</literal> (see <xref linkend="create-resource-group" />).
        Only the attributes specified are altered. Unspecified
        attributes retain their current values.

The <literal>FORCE</literal> modifier is used with
        <literal>DISABLE</literal>. It determines statement behavior if
        the resource group has any threads assigned to it:

itemizedlist.para:
If <literal>FORCE</literal> is not given, existing threads
            in the group continue to run until they terminate, but new
            threads cannot be assigned to the group.

If <literal>FORCE</literal> is given, existing threads in
            the group are moved to their respective default group
            (system threads to <literal>SYS_default</literal>, user
            threads to <literal>USR_default</literal>).

description.para:
The name and type attributes are set at group creation time and
        cannot be modified thereafter with <literal role="stmt">ALTER
        RESOURCE GROUP</literal>.
Examples:

itemizedlist.para: Alter a group CPU affinity:
Alter a group thread priority:

Disable a group, moving any threads assigned to it to the
            default groups:

itemizedlist.programlisting:
>
ALTER RESOURCE GROUP rg3 DISABLE FORCE;

description.para:
Resource group management is local to the server on which it
        occurs. <literal role="stmt">ALTER RESOURCE GROUP</literal>
        statements are not written to the binary log and are not
        replicated.

<literal role="stmt">CREATE RESOURCE GROUP</literal> is used for
        resource group management (see
        <xref linkend="resource-groups" />). This statement creates a new
        resource group and assigns its initial attribute values. It
        requires the <literal role="priv">RESOURCE_GROUP_ADMIN</literal>
        privilege.

<replaceable>group_name</replaceable> identifies which resource
        group to create. If the group already exists, an error occurs.

The <literal>TYPE</literal> attribute is required. It should be
        <literal>SYSTEM</literal> for a system resource group,
        <literal>USER</literal> for a user resource group. The group
        type affects permitted <literal>THREAD_PRIORITY</literal>
        values, as described later.

The <literal>VCPU</literal> attribute indicates the CPU
        affinity; that is, the set of virtual CPUs the group can use:

itemizedlist.para:
If <literal>VCPU</literal> is not given, the resource group
            has no CPU affinity and can use all available CPUs.

If <literal>VCPU</literal> is given, the attribute value is
            a list of comma-separated CPU numbers or ranges:

Each number must be an integer in the range from 0 to
                the number of CPUs minus 1. For example, on a system
                with 64 CPUs, the number can range from 0 to 63.

A range is given in the form
                <replaceable>M</replaceable> minus
                <replaceable>N</replaceable>, where
                <replaceable>M</replaceable> is less than or equal to
                <replaceable>N</replaceable> and both numbers are in the
                CPU range.

If a CPU number is an integer outside the permitted
                range or is not an integer, an error occurs.

description.para:
Example <literal>VCPU</literal> specifiers (these are all
        equivalent):

The <literal>THREAD_PRIORITY</literal> attribute indicates the
        priority for threads assigned to the group:

itemizedlist.para:
If <literal>THREAD_PRIORITY</literal> is not given, the
            default priority is 0.

If <literal>THREAD_PRIORITY</literal> is given, the
            attribute value must be in the range from -20 (highest
            priority) to 19 (lowest priority). The priority for system
            resource groups must be in the range from -20 to 0. The
            priority for user resource groups must be in the range from
            0 to 19. Use of different ranges for system and user groups
            ensures that user threads never have a higher priority than
            system threads.

description.para:
<literal>ENABLE</literal> and <literal>DISABLE</literal> specify
        that the resource group is initially enabled or disabled. If
        neither is specified, the group is enabled by default. A
        disabled group cannot have threads assigned to it.
Examples:

itemizedlist.para:
Create an enabled user group that has a single CPU and the
            lowest priority:

itemizedlist.programlisting:
>
CREATE RESOURCE GROUP rg1
  TYPE = USER
  VCPU = 0
  THREAD_PRIORITY = 19;

itemizedlist.para:
Create a disabled system group that has no CPU affinity (can
            use all CPUs) and the highest priority:

itemizedlist.programlisting:
>
CREATE RESOURCE GROUP rg2
  TYPE = SYSTEM
  THREAD_PRIORITY = -20
  DISABLE;

description.para:
Resource group management is local to the server on which it
        occurs. <literal role="stmt">CREATE RESOURCE GROUP</literal>
        statements are not written to the binary log and are not
        replicated.

<literal role="stmt">DROP RESOURCE GROUP</literal> is used for
        resource group management (see
        <xref linkend="resource-groups" />). This statement drops a
        resource group. It requires the
        <literal role="priv">RESOURCE_GROUP_ADMIN</literal> privilege.

<replaceable>group_name</replaceable> identifies which resource
        group to drop. If the group does not exist, an error occurs.

The <literal>FORCE</literal> modifier determines statement
        behavior if the resource group has any threads assigned to it:

itemizedlist.para:
If <literal>FORCE</literal> is not given and any threads are
            assigned to the group, an error occurs.

If <literal>FORCE</literal> is given, existing threads in
            the group are moved to their respective default group
            (system threads to <literal>SYS_default</literal>, user
            threads to <literal>USR_default</literal>).

description.para: Examples:

itemizedlist.para: Drop a group, failing if the group contains any threads:

Drop a group and move existing threads to the default
            groups:

description.para:
Resource group management is local to the server on which it
        occurs. <literal role="stmt">DROP RESOURCE GROUP</literal>
        statements are not written to the binary log and are not
        replicated.

<literal role="stmt">SET RESOURCE GROUP</literal> is used for
        resource group management (see
        <xref linkend="resource-groups" />). This statement assigns
        threads to a resource group. It requires the
        <literal role="priv">RESOURCE_GROUP_ADMIN</literal> or
        <literal role="priv">RESOURCE_GROUP_USER</literal> privilege.

<replaceable>group_name</replaceable> identifies which resource
        group to be assigned. Any <replaceable>thread_id</replaceable>
        values indicate threads to assign to the group. Thread IDs can
        be determined from the Performance Schema
        <literal role="ps">threads</literal> table. If the resource
        group or any named thread ID does not exist, an error occurs.

With no <literal>FOR</literal> clause, the statement assigns the
        current thread for the session to the resource group.

With a <literal>FOR</literal> clause that names thread IDs, the
        statement assigns those threads to the resource group.

For attempts to assign a system thread to a user resource group
        or a user thread to a system resource group, a warning occurs.
Examples:

itemizedlist.para: Assign the current session thread to a group:
Assign the named threads to a group:

description.para:
Resource group management is local to the server on which it
        occurs. <literal role="stmt">SET RESOURCE GROUP</literal>
        statements are not written to the binary log and are not
        replicated.

An alternative to <literal role="stmt">SET RESOURCE
        GROUP</literal> is the
        <literal role="opthint">RESOURCE_GROUP</literal> optimizer hint,
        which assigns individual statements to a resource group. See
        <xref linkend="optimizer-hints" />.

<literal role="stmt">ANALYZE TABLE</literal> generates table
        statistics:

itemizedlist.para:
<literal role="stmt">ANALYZE TABLE</literal> without either
            <literal>HISTOGRAM</literal> clause performs a key
            distribution analysis and stores the distribution for the
            named table or tables. For <literal>MyISAM</literal> tables,
            <literal role="stmt">ANALYZE TABLE</literal> for key
            distribution analysis is equivalent to using
            <command>myisamchk --analyze</command>.

<literal role="stmt">ANALYZE TABLE</literal> with the
            <literal>UPDATE HISTOGRAM</literal> clause generates
            histogram statistics for the named table columns and stores
            them in the data dictionary. Only one table name is
            permitted for this syntax.

<literal role="stmt">ANALYZE TABLE</literal> with the
            <literal>DROP HISTOGRAM</literal> clause removes histogram
            statistics for the named table columns from the data
            dictionary. Only one table name is permitted for this
            syntax.

description.para:
This statement requires <literal role="priv">SELECT</literal>
        and <literal role="priv">INSERT</literal> privileges for the
        table.

<literal role="stmt">ANALYZE TABLE</literal> works with
        <literal>InnoDB</literal>, <literal>NDB</literal>, and
        <literal>MyISAM</literal> tables. It does not work with views.

If the <literal role="sysvar">innodb_read_only</literal> system
        variable is enabled, <literal role="stmt">ANALYZE
        TABLE</literal> may fail because it cannot update statistics
        tables in the data dictionary, which use
        <literal>InnoDB</literal>. For <literal role="stmt">ANALYZE
        TABLE</literal> operations that update the key distribution,
        failure may occur even if the operation updates the table itself
        (for example, if it is a <literal>MyISAM</literal> table). To
        obtain the updated distribution statistics, set
        <literal role="sysvar">information_schema_stats_expiry=0</literal>.

<literal role="stmt">ANALYZE TABLE</literal> is supported for
        partitioned tables, and you can use <literal>ALTER TABLE ...
        ANALYZE PARTITION</literal> to analyze one or more partitions;
        for more information, see <xref linkend="alter-table" />, and
        <xref linkend="partitioning-maintenance" />.

During the analysis, the table is locked with a read lock for
        <literal>InnoDB</literal> and <literal>MyISAM</literal>.

<literal role="stmt">ANALYZE TABLE</literal> removes the table
        from the table definition cache, which requires a flush lock. If
        there are long running statements or transactions still using
        the table, subsequent statements and transactions must wait for
        those operations to finish before the flush lock is released.
        Because <literal role="stmt">ANALYZE TABLE</literal> itself
        typically finishes quickly, it may not be apparent that delayed
        transactions or statements involving the same table are due to
        the remaining flush lock.

By default, the server writes <literal role="stmt">ANALYZE
        TABLE</literal> statements to the binary log so that they
        replicate to replication slaves. To suppress logging, specify
        the optional <literal>NO_WRITE_TO_BINLOG</literal> keyword or
        its alias <literal>LOCAL</literal>.

syntax.programlisting:
>
ANALYZE [NO_WRITE_TO_BINLOG | LOCAL]
    TABLE <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> [, <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>] ...

ANALYZE [NO_WRITE_TO_BINLOG | LOCAL]
    TABLE <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>
    UPDATE HISTOGRAM ON <replaceable>col_name</replaceable> [, <replaceable>col_name</replaceable>] ...
        [WITH <replaceable>N</replaceable> BUCKETS]

ANALYZE [NO_WRITE_TO_BINLOG | LOCAL]
    TABLE <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>
    DROP HISTOGRAM ON <replaceable>col_name</replaceable> [, <replaceable>col_name</replaceable>] ...

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">CHECK TABLE</literal> checks a table or
        tables for errors. <literal role="stmt">CHECK TABLE</literal>
        can also check views for problems, such as tables that are
        referenced in the view definition that no longer exist.
To check a table, you must have some privilege for it.

<literal role="stmt">CHECK TABLE</literal> works for
        <literal role="se">InnoDB</literal>,
        <literal role="se">MyISAM</literal>,
        <literal role="se">ARCHIVE</literal>, and
        <literal role="se">CSV</literal> tables.

Before running <literal role="stmt">CHECK TABLE</literal> on
        <literal>InnoDB</literal> tables, see
        <xref linkend="check-table-innodb" />.

<literal role="stmt">CHECK TABLE</literal> is supported for
        partitioned tables, and you can use <literal>ALTER TABLE ...
        CHECK PARTITION</literal> to check one or more partitions; for
        more information, see <xref linkend="alter-table" />, and
        <xref linkend="partitioning-maintenance" />.

<literal role="stmt">CHECK TABLE</literal> ignores virtual
        generated columns that are not indexed.

syntax.programlisting:
>
CHECK TABLE <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> [, <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>] ... [<replaceable>option</replaceable>] ...

<replaceable>option</replaceable>: {
    FOR UPGRADE
  | QUICK
  | FAST
  | MEDIUM
  | EXTENDED
  | CHANGED
}

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">CHECKSUM TABLE</literal> reports a
        <link linkend="glos_checksum">checksum</link> for the contents
        of a table. You can use this statement to verify that the
        contents are the same before and after a backup, rollback, or
        other operation that is intended to put the data back to a known
        state.

This statement requires the
        <literal role="priv">SELECT</literal> privilege for the table.

This statement is not supported for views. If you run
        <literal role="stmt">CHECKSUM TABLE</literal> against a view,
        the <literal>Checksum</literal> value is always
        <literal>NULL</literal>, and a warning is returned.

For a nonexistent table, <literal role="stmt">CHECKSUM
        TABLE</literal> returns <literal>NULL</literal> and generates a
        warning.

During the checksum operation, the table is locked with a read
        lock for <literal>InnoDB</literal> and
        <literal>MyISAM</literal>.

<literal role="stmt">OPTIMIZE TABLE</literal> reorganizes the
        physical storage of table data and associated index data, to
        reduce storage space and improve I/O efficiency when accessing
        the table. The exact changes made to each table depend on the
        <link linkend="glos_storage_engine">storage engine</link> used
        by that table.

Use <literal role="stmt">OPTIMIZE TABLE</literal> in these
        cases, depending on the type of table:

itemizedlist.para:
After doing substantial insert, update, or delete operations
            on an <literal>InnoDB</literal> table that has its own
            <link linkend="glos_ibd_file">.ibd file</link> because it
            was created with the
            <literal role="sysvar">innodb_file_per_table</literal>
            option enabled. The table and indexes are reorganized, and
            disk space can be reclaimed for use by the operating system.

After doing substantial insert, update, or delete operations
            on columns that are part of a <literal>FULLTEXT</literal>
            index in an <literal>InnoDB</literal> table. Set the
            configuration option
            <literal role="sysvar">innodb_optimize_fulltext_only=1</literal>
            first. To keep the index maintenance period to a reasonable
            time, set the
            <literal role="sysvar">innodb_ft_num_word_optimize</literal>
            option to specify how many words to update in the search
            index, and run a sequence of <literal>OPTIMIZE
            TABLE</literal> statements until the search index is fully
            updated.

After deleting a large part of a <literal>MyISAM</literal>
            or <literal>ARCHIVE</literal> table, or making many changes
            to a <literal>MyISAM</literal> or <literal>ARCHIVE
            </literal>table with variable-length rows (tables that have
            <literal role="type">VARCHAR</literal>,
            <literal role="type">VARBINARY</literal>,
            <literal role="type">BLOB</literal>, or
            <literal role="type">TEXT</literal> columns). Deleted rows
            are maintained in a linked list and subsequent
            <literal role="stmt">INSERT</literal> operations reuse old
            row positions. You can use <literal role="stmt">OPTIMIZE
            TABLE</literal> to reclaim the unused space and to
            defragment the data file. After extensive changes to a
            table, this statement may also improve performance of
            statements that use the table, sometimes significantly.

description.para:
This statement requires <literal role="priv">SELECT</literal>
        and <literal role="priv">INSERT</literal> privileges for the
        table.

<literal role="stmt">OPTIMIZE TABLE</literal> works for
        <literal role="se">InnoDB</literal>,
        <literal role="se">MyISAM</literal>, and
        <literal role="se">ARCHIVE</literal> tables.
        <literal role="stmt">OPTIMIZE TABLE</literal> is also supported
        for dynamic columns of in-memory
        <literal role="se">NDB</literal> tables. It does not work for
        fixed-width columns of in-memory tables, nor does it work for
        Disk Data tables. The performance of <literal>OPTIMIZE</literal>
        on NDB Cluster tables can be tuned using
        <option role="mysqld">--ndb-optimization-delay</option>, which
        controls the length of time to wait between processing batches
        of rows by <literal role="stmt">OPTIMIZE TABLE</literal>. For
        more information, see
        <xref linkend="mysql-cluster-limitations-resolved" />.

For NDB Cluster tables, <literal role="stmt">OPTIMIZE
        TABLE</literal> can be interrupted by (for example) killing the
        SQL thread performing the <literal>OPTIMIZE</literal> operation.

By default, <literal role="stmt">OPTIMIZE TABLE</literal> does
        <emphasis>not</emphasis> work for tables created using any other
        storage engine and returns a result indicating this lack of
        support. You can make <literal role="stmt">OPTIMIZE
        TABLE</literal> work for other storage engines by starting
        <command>mysqld</command> with the
        <option role="mysqld">--skip-new</option> option. In this case,
        <literal role="stmt">OPTIMIZE TABLE</literal> is just mapped to
        <literal role="stmt">ALTER TABLE</literal>.
This statement does not work with views.

<literal role="stmt">OPTIMIZE TABLE</literal> is supported for
        partitioned tables. For information about using this statement
        with partitioned tables and table partitions, see
        <xref linkend="partitioning-maintenance" />.

By default, the server writes <literal role="stmt">OPTIMIZE
        TABLE</literal> statements to the binary log so that they
        replicate to replication slaves. To suppress logging, specify
        the optional <literal>NO_WRITE_TO_BINLOG</literal> keyword or
        its alias <literal>LOCAL</literal>.

<literal role="stmt">REPAIR TABLE</literal> repairs a possibly
        corrupted table, for certain storage engines only.

This statement requires <literal role="priv">SELECT</literal>
        and <literal role="priv">INSERT</literal> privileges for the
        table.

Although normally you should never have to run
        <literal role="stmt">REPAIR TABLE</literal>, if disaster
        strikes, this statement is very likely to get back all your data
        from a <literal>MyISAM</literal> table. If your tables become
        corrupted often, try to find the reason for it, to eliminate the
        need to use <literal role="stmt">REPAIR TABLE</literal>. See
        <xref linkend="crashing" />, and
        <xref linkend="myisam-table-problems" />.

<literal role="stmt">REPAIR TABLE</literal> checks the table to
        see whether an upgrade is required. If so, it performs the
        upgrade, following the same rules as
        <literal condition="check-table" role="stmt">CHECK TABLE ... FOR
        UPGRADE</literal>. See <xref linkend="check-table" />, for more
        information.

A user-defined function (UDF) is a way to extend MySQL with a
        new function that works like a native (built-in) MySQL function
        such as <literal role="func">ABS()</literal> or
        <literal role="func">CONCAT()</literal>.

<replaceable>function_name</replaceable> is the name that should
        be used in SQL statements to invoke the function. The
        <literal>RETURNS</literal> clause indicates the type of the
        function's return value. <literal role="type">DECIMAL</literal>
        is a legal value after <literal>RETURNS</literal>, but currently
        <literal role="type">DECIMAL</literal> functions return string
        values and should be written like <literal>STRING</literal>
        functions.

<replaceable>shared_library_name</replaceable> is the base name
        of the shared library file that contains the code that
        implements the function. The file must be located in the plugin
        directory. This directory is given by the value of the
        <literal role="sysvar">plugin_dir</literal> system variable. For
        more information, see <xref linkend="udf-loading" />.

To create a function, you must have the
        <literal role="priv">INSERT</literal> privilege for the
        <literal>mysql</literal> system schema. This is necessary
        because <literal role="stmt">CREATE FUNCTION</literal> adds a
        row to the <literal>mysql.func</literal> system table that
        records the function's name, type, and shared library name.

UDFs registered using <literal role="stmt">CREATE
        FUNCTION</literal> are listed in the Performance Schema
        <literal role="ps">user_defined_functions</literal> table; see
        <xref linkend="user-defined-functions-table" />.

This statement drops the user-defined function (UDF) named
        <replaceable>function_name</replaceable>.

To drop a function, you must have the
        <literal role="priv">DELETE</literal> privilege for the
        <literal>mysql</literal> system schema. This is because
        <literal role="stmt">DROP FUNCTION</literal> removes a row from
        the <literal>mysql.func</literal> system table that records the
        function's name, type, and shared library name.

This statement installs one or more server components, which
        become active immediately. A component provides services that
        are available to the server and other components; see
        <xref linkend="server-components" />.
        <literal role="stmt">INSTALL COMPONENT</literal> requires the
        <literal role="priv">INSERT</literal> privilege for the
        <literal>mysql.component</literal> system table.
Example:

description.programlisting:
>
INSTALL COMPONENT 'file://component1', 'file://component2';

description.para:
Component names are URNs that begin with
        <literal>file://</literal> and indicate the base name of the
        file that implements the component, located in the directory
        named by the <literal role="sysvar">plugin_dir</literal> system
        variable. Component names do not include any platform-dependent
        file name suffix such as <filename>.so</filename> or
        <filename>.dll</filename>. (These naming details are subject to
        change because component name interpretation is itself performed
        by a service and the component infrastructure makes it possible
        to replace the default service implementation with alternative
        implementations.)

If any error occurs, the statement fails and has no effect. For
        example, this happens if a component name is erroneous, a named
        component does not exist or is already installed, or component
        initialization fails.

A loader service handles component loading, which includes
        adding installed components to the
        <literal>mysql.component</literal> system table that serves as a
        registry. For subsequent server restarts, any components listed
        in <literal>mysql.component</literal> are loaded by the loader
        service during the startup sequence. This occurs even if the
        server is started with the
        <option role="mysqld">--skip-grant-tables</option> option.

If a component depends on services not present in the registry
        and you attempt to install the component without also installing
        the component or components that provide the services on which
        it depends, an error occurs:

description.programlisting:
>
ERROR 3527 (HY000): Cannot satisfy dependency for service 'component_a'
required by component 'component_b'.

description.para:
To avoid this problem, either install all components in the same
        statement, or install the dependent component after installing
        any components on which it depends.

This statement installs a server plugin. It requires the
        <literal role="priv">INSERT</literal> privilege for the
        <literal>mysql.plugin</literal> system table.

<replaceable>plugin_name</replaceable> is the name of the plugin
        as defined in the plugin descriptor structure contained in the
        library file (see <xref linkend="plugin-data-structures" />).
        Plugin names are not case-sensitive. For maximal compatibility,
        plugin names should be limited to ASCII letters, digits, and
        underscore because they are used in C source files, shell
        command lines, M4 and Bourne shell scripts, and SQL
        environments.

<replaceable>shared_library_name</replaceable> is the name of
        the shared library that contains the plugin code. The name
        includes the file name extension (for example,
        <filename>libmyplugin.so</filename>,
        <filename>libmyplugin.dll</filename>, or
        <filename>libmyplugin.dylib</filename>).

The shared library must be located in the plugin directory (the
        directory named by the
        <literal role="sysvar">plugin_dir</literal> system variable).
        The library must be in the plugin directory itself, not in a
        subdirectory. By default,
        <literal role="sysvar">plugin_dir</literal> is the
        <filename>plugin</filename> directory under the directory named
        by the <literal>pkglibdir</literal> configuration variable, but
        it can be changed by setting the value of
        <literal role="sysvar">plugin_dir</literal> at server startup.
        For example, set its value in a <filename>my.cnf</filename>
        file:

description.programlisting:
>
[mysqld]
plugin_dir=<replaceable>/path/to/plugin/directory</replaceable>

description.para:
If the value of <literal role="sysvar">plugin_dir</literal> is a
        relative path name, it is taken to be relative to the MySQL base
        directory (the value of the
        <literal role="sysvar">basedir</literal> system variable).

<literal role="stmt">INSTALL PLUGIN</literal> loads and
        initializes the plugin code to make the plugin available for
        use. A plugin is initialized by executing its initialization
        function, which handles any setup that the plugin must perform
        before it can be used. When the server shuts down, it executes
        the deinitialization function for each plugin that is loaded so
        that the plugin has a chance to perform any final cleanup.

<literal role="stmt">INSTALL PLUGIN</literal> also registers the
        plugin by adding a line that indicates the plugin name and
        library file name to the <literal>mysql.plugin</literal> system
        table. At server startup, the server loads and initializes any
        plugin that is listed in <literal>mysql.plugin</literal>. This
        means that a plugin is installed with
        <literal role="stmt">INSTALL PLUGIN</literal> only once, not
        every time the server starts. Plugin loading at startup does not
        occur if the server is started with the
        <option role="mysqld">--skip-grant-tables</option> option.

A plugin library can contain multiple plugins. For each of them
        to be installed, use a separate <literal role="stmt">INSTALL
        PLUGIN</literal> statement. Each statement names a different
        plugin, but all of them specify the same library name.

This statement deactivates and uninstalls one or more server
        components. A component provides services that are available to
        the server and other components; see
        <xref linkend="server-components" />.
        <literal role="stmt">UNINSTALL COMPONENT</literal> is the
        complement of <literal role="stmt">INSTALL COMPONENT</literal>.
        It requires the <literal role="priv">DELETE</literal> privilege
        for the <literal>mysql.component</literal> system table.
Example:

description.programlisting:
>
UNINSTALL COMPONENT 'file://component1', 'file://component2';

description.para:
For information about component naming, see
        <xref linkend="install-component" />.

If any error occurs, the statement fails and has no effect. For
        example, this happens if a component name is erroneous, a named
        component is not installed, or cannot be uninstalled because
        other installed components depend on it.

A loader service handles component unloading, which includes
        removing uninstalled components from the
        <literal>mysql.component</literal> system table that serves as a
        registry. As a result, unloaded components are not loaded during
        the startup sequence for subsequent server restarts.

This statement removes an installed server plugin. It requires
        the <literal role="priv">DELETE</literal> privilege for the
        <literal>mysql.plugin</literal> system table.
        <literal role="stmt">UNINSTALL PLUGIN</literal> is the
        complement of <literal role="stmt">INSTALL PLUGIN</literal>.

<replaceable>plugin_name</replaceable> must be the name of some
        plugin that is listed in the <literal>mysql.plugin</literal>
        table. The server executes the plugin's deinitialization
        function and removes the row for the plugin from the
        <literal>mysql.plugin</literal> system table, so that subsequent
        server restarts will not load and initialize the plugin.
        <literal role="stmt">UNINSTALL PLUGIN</literal> does not remove
        the plugin's shared library file.

The <literal role="stmt">CLONE</literal> statement is used to
      clone data locally or from a remote MySQL server instance. To use
      <literal role="stmt">CLONE</literal> syntax, the clone plugin must
      be installed. See <xref linkend="clone-plugin" />.

<literal condition="clone" role="stmt">CLONE LOCAL DATA
      DIRECTORY</literal> syntax clones data from the local MySQL data
      directory to a directory on the same server or node where the
      MySQL server instance runs. The <literal>'clone_dir'</literal>
      directory is the full path of the local directory that data is
      cloned to. An absolute path is required. The specified directory
      must not exist, but the specified path must be an existent path.
      The MySQL server requires the necessary write access to create the
      specified directory. For more information, see
      <xref linkend="clone-plugin-local" />.

<literal condition="clone" role="stmt">CLONE INSTANCE</literal>
      syntax clones data from a remote MySQL server instance (the donor)
      and transfers it to the MySQL instance where the cloning operation
      was initiated (the recipient).

itemizedlist.para:
<literal><replaceable>user</replaceable></literal> is the
          clone user on the donor MySQL server instance.

<literal><replaceable>host</replaceable></literal> is the
          <literal role="sysvar">hostname</literal> address of the donor
          MySQL server instance. Internet Protocol version 6 (IPv6)
          address format is not supported. An alias to the IPv6 address
          can be used instead. An IPv4 address can be used as is.

<literal><replaceable>port</replaceable></literal> is the
          <literal role="sysvar">port</literal> number of the donor
          MySQL server instance. (The mysqlxprotocol port specified by
          <literal role="sysvar">mysqlx_port</literal> is not supported.
          Connecting to the donor MySQL server instance through router
          is also not supported.)

<literal>IDENTIFIED BY
          '<replaceable>password</replaceable>'</literal> specifies the
          password of the clone user on the donor MySQL server instance.

<literal>DATA DIRECTORY [=]
          '<replaceable>clone_dir</replaceable>'</literal> is an
          optional clause used to specify a directory on the recipient
          for the data you are cloning. Use this option if you do not
          want to remove existing data in the recipient data directory.
          An absolute path is required, and the directory must not
          exist. The MySQL server must have the necessary write access
          to create the directory.

When the optional <literal>DATA DIRECTORY [=]
          '<replaceable>clone_dir</replaceable>'</literal> clause is not
          used, a cloning operation removes existing data in the
          recipient data directory, replaces it with the cloned data,
          and automatically restarts the server afterward.

<literal>[REQUIRE [NO] SSL]</literal> explicitly specifies
          whether an encrypted connection is to be used or not when
          transferring cloned data over the network. An error is
          returned if the explicit specification cannot be satisfied. If
          an SSL clause is not specified, clone attempts to establish an
          encrypted connection by default, falling back to an insecure
          connection if the secure connection attempt fails. A secure
          connection is required when cloning encrypted data regardless
          of whether this clause is specified. For more information, see
          <xref linkend="clone-plugin-remote-ssl" />.

description.para:
For additional information about cloning data from a remote MySQL
      server instance, see <xref linkend="clone-plugin-remote" />.

<literal condition="set-variable" role="stmt">SET</literal>
        syntax for variable assignment enables you to assign values to
        different types of variables that affect the operation of the
        server or clients:

itemizedlist.para:
User-defined variables. See
            <xref linkend="user-variables" />.

Stored procedure and function parameters, and stored program
            local variables. See
            <xref linkend="stored-program-variables" />.

System variables. See
            <xref linkend="server-system-variables" />. System variables
            also can be set at server startup, as described in
            <xref linkend="using-system-variables" />.

description.para:
This statement maps all strings sent between the server and the
        current client with the given mapping. <literal>SET CHARACTER
        SET</literal> sets three session system variables:
        <literal role="sysvar">character_set_client</literal> and
        <literal role="sysvar">character_set_results</literal> are set
        to the given character set, and
        <literal role="sysvar">character_set_connection</literal> to the
        value of
        <literal role="sysvar">character_set_database</literal>. See
        <xref linkend="charset-connection" />.

<replaceable>charset_name</replaceable> may be quoted or
        unquoted.

The default character set mapping can be restored by using the
        value <literal>DEFAULT</literal>. The default depends on the
        server configuration.

Some character sets cannot be used as the client character set.
        Attempting to use them with <literal role="stmt">SET CHARACTER
        SET</literal> produces an error. See
        <xref linkend="charset-connection-impermissible-client-charset" />.

This statement sets the three session system variables
        <literal role="sysvar">character_set_client</literal>,
        <literal role="sysvar">character_set_connection</literal>, and
        <literal role="sysvar">character_set_results</literal> to the
        given character set. Setting
        <literal role="sysvar">character_set_connection</literal> to
        <literal>charset_name</literal> also sets
        <literal role="sysvar">collation_connection</literal> to the
        default collation for <literal>charset_name</literal>. See
        <xref linkend="charset-connection" />.

The optional <literal>COLLATE</literal> clause may be used to
        specify a collation explicitly. If given, the collation must one
        of the permitted collations for
        <replaceable>charset_name</replaceable>.

<replaceable>charset_name</replaceable> and
        <replaceable>collation_name</replaceable> may be quoted or
        unquoted.

The default mapping can be restored by using a value of
        <literal>DEFAULT</literal>. The default depends on the server
        configuration.

Some character sets cannot be used as the client character set.
        Attempting to use them with <literal role="stmt">SET
        NAMES</literal> produces an error. See
        <xref linkend="charset-connection-impermissible-client-charset" />.

Lists the binary log files on the server. This statement is used
        as part of the procedure described in
        <xref linkend="purge-binary-logs" />, that shows how to determine
        which logs can be purged. <literal role="stmt">SHOW BINARY
        LOGS</literal> requires the <literal role="priv">REPLICATION
        CLIENT</literal> or <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal>
        privilege.

Encrypted binary log files have a 512-byte file header that
        stores information required for encryption and decryption of the
        file. This is included in the file size displayed by
        <literal role="stmt">SHOW BINARY LOGS</literal>. The
        <literal>Encrypted</literal> column shows whether or not the
        binary log file is encrypted. Binary log encryption is active if
        <literal role="sysvar">binlog_encryption=ON</literal> is set for
        the server. Existing binary log files are not encrypted or
        decrypted if binary log encryption is activated or deactivated
        while the server is running.

syntax.programlisting:
>
SHOW BINARY LOGS
SHOW MASTER LOGS

description.para:
Shows the events in the binary log. If you do not specify
        <literal>'<replaceable>log_name</replaceable>'</literal>, the
        first binary log is displayed. <literal>SHOW BINLOG
        EVENTS</literal> requires the <literal role="priv">REPLICATION
        SLAVE</literal> privilege.

The <literal role="stmt">SHOW CHARACTER SET</literal> statement
        shows all available character sets. The
        <literal role="op">LIKE</literal> clause, if present, indicates
        which character set names to match. The <literal>WHERE</literal>
        clause can be given to select rows using more general
        conditions, as discussed in <xref linkend="extended-show" />. For
        example:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SHOW CHARACTER SET LIKE 'latin%';</userinput>
+---------+-----------------------------+-------------------+--------+
| Charset | Description                 | Default collation | Maxlen |
+---------+-----------------------------+-------------------+--------+
| latin1  | cp1252 West European        | latin1_swedish_ci |      1 |
| latin2  | ISO 8859-2 Central European | latin2_general_ci |      1 |
| latin5  | ISO 8859-9 Turkish          | latin5_turkish_ci |      1 |
| latin7  | ISO 8859-13 Baltic          | latin7_general_ci |      1 |
+---------+-----------------------------+-------------------+--------+

description.para:
This statement lists collations supported by the server. By
        default, the output from <literal role="stmt">SHOW
        COLLATION</literal> includes all available collations. The
        <literal role="op">LIKE</literal> clause, if present, indicates
        which collation names to match. The <literal>WHERE</literal>
        clause can be given to select rows using more general
        conditions, as discussed in <xref linkend="extended-show" />. For
        example:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SHOW COLLATION WHERE Charset = 'latin1';</userinput>
+-------------------+---------+----+---------+----------+---------+
| Collation         | Charset | Id | Default | Compiled | Sortlen |
+-------------------+---------+----+---------+----------+---------+
| latin1_german1_ci | latin1  |  5 |         | Yes      |       1 |
| latin1_swedish_ci | latin1  |  8 | Yes     | Yes      |       1 |
| latin1_danish_ci  | latin1  | 15 |         | Yes      |       1 |
| latin1_german2_ci | latin1  | 31 |         | Yes      |       2 |
| latin1_bin        | latin1  | 47 |         | Yes      |       1 |
| latin1_general_ci | latin1  | 48 |         | Yes      |       1 |
| latin1_general_cs | latin1  | 49 |         | Yes      |       1 |
| latin1_spanish_ci | latin1  | 94 |         | Yes      |       1 |
+-------------------+---------+----+---------+----------+---------+

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">SHOW COLUMNS</literal> displays information
        about the columns in a given table. It also works for views.
        <literal role="stmt">SHOW COLUMNS</literal> displays information
        only for those columns for which you have some privilege.

An alternative to <literal><replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>
        FROM <replaceable>db_name</replaceable></literal> syntax is
        <replaceable>db_name.tbl_name</replaceable>. These two
        statements are equivalent:

The optional <literal>EXTENDED</literal> keyword causes the
        output to include information about hidden columns that MySQL
        uses internally and are not accessible by users.

The optional <literal>FULL</literal> keyword causes the output
        to include the column collation and comments, as well as the
        privileges you have for each column.

The <literal role="op">LIKE</literal> clause, if present,
        indicates which column names to match. The
        <literal>WHERE</literal> clause can be given to select rows
        using more general conditions, as discussed in
        <xref linkend="extended-show" />.

The data types may differ from what you expect them to be based
        on a <literal role="stmt">CREATE TABLE</literal> statement
        because MySQL sometimes changes data types when you create or
        alter a table. The conditions under which this occurs are
        described in <xref linkend="silent-column-changes" />.

<literal role="stmt">SHOW COLUMNS</literal> displays the
        following values for each table column:

itemizedlist.para: <literal>Field</literal>
The name of the column.
<literal>Type</literal>
The column data type.
<literal>Collation</literal>

The collation for nonbinary string columns, or
            <literal>NULL</literal> for other columns. This value is
            displayed only if you use the <literal>FULL</literal>
            keyword.
<literal>Null</literal>

The column nullability. The value is <literal>YES</literal>
            if <literal>NULL</literal> values can be stored in the
            column, <literal>NO</literal> if not.
<literal>Key</literal>
Whether the column is indexed:

If <literal>Key</literal> is empty, the column either is
                not indexed or is indexed only as a secondary column in
                a multiple-column, nonunique index.

If <literal>Key</literal> is <literal>PRI</literal>, the
                column is a <literal>PRIMARY KEY</literal> or is one of
                the columns in a multiple-column <literal>PRIMARY
                KEY</literal>.

If <literal>Key</literal> is <literal>UNI</literal>, the
                column is the first column of a
                <literal>UNIQUE</literal> index. (A
                <literal>UNIQUE</literal> index permits multiple
                <literal>NULL</literal> values, but you can tell whether
                the column permits <literal>NULL</literal> by checking
                the <literal>Null</literal> field.)

If <literal>Key</literal> is <literal>MUL</literal>, the
                column is the first column of a nonunique index in which
                multiple occurrences of a given value are permitted
                within the column.

If more than one of the <literal>Key</literal> values
            applies to a given column of a table, <literal>Key</literal>
            displays the one with the highest priority, in the order
            <literal>PRI</literal>, <literal>UNI</literal>,
            <literal>MUL</literal>.

A <literal>UNIQUE</literal> index may be displayed as
            <literal>PRI</literal> if it cannot contain
            <literal>NULL</literal> values and there is no
            <literal>PRIMARY KEY</literal> in the table. A
            <literal>UNIQUE</literal> index may display as
            <literal>MUL</literal> if several columns form a composite
            <literal>UNIQUE</literal> index; although the combination of
            the columns is unique, each column can still hold multiple
            occurrences of a given value.
<literal>Default</literal>

The default value for the column. This is
            <literal>NULL</literal> if the column has an explicit
            default of <literal>NULL</literal>, or if the column
            definition includes no <literal>DEFAULT</literal> clause.
<literal>Extra</literal>

Any additional information that is available about a given
            column. The value is nonempty in these cases:

<literal>auto_increment</literal> for columns that have
                the <literal>AUTO_INCREMENT</literal> attribute.

<literal>on update CURRENT_TIMESTAMP</literal> for
                <literal role="type">TIMESTAMP</literal> or
                <literal role="type">DATETIME</literal> columns that
                have the <literal>ON UPDATE CURRENT_TIMESTAMP</literal>
                attribute.

<literal>VIRTUAL GENERATED</literal> or <literal>VIRTUAL
                STORED</literal> for generated columns.

<literal>DEFAULT_GENERATED</literal> for columns that
                have an expression default value.
<literal>Privileges</literal>

The privileges you have for the column. This value is
            displayed only if you use the <literal>FULL</literal>
            keyword.
<literal>Comment</literal>

Any comment included in the column definition. This value is
            displayed only if you use the <literal>FULL</literal>
            keyword.

description.para:
Table column information is also available from the
        <literal>INFORMATION_SCHEMA</literal>
        <literal role="is">COLUMNS</literal> table. See
        <xref linkend="columns-table" />. The extended information about
        hidden columns is available only using <literal>SHOW EXTENDED
        COLUMNS</literal>; it cannot be obtained from the
        <literal role="is">COLUMNS</literal> table.

You can list a table's columns with the <command>mysqlshow
        <replaceable>db_name</replaceable>
        <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable></command> command.

The <literal role="stmt">DESCRIBE</literal> statement provides
        information similar to <literal role="stmt">SHOW
        COLUMNS</literal>. See <xref linkend="describe" />.

The <literal role="stmt">SHOW CREATE TABLE</literal>,
        <literal role="stmt">SHOW TABLE STATUS</literal>, and
        <literal role="stmt">SHOW INDEX</literal> statements also
        provide information about tables. See <xref linkend="show" />.

Shows the <literal role="stmt">CREATE DATABASE</literal>
        statement that creates the named database. If the
        <literal>SHOW</literal> statement includes an <literal>IF NOT
        EXISTS</literal> clause, the output too includes such a clause.
        <literal condition="show-create-database" role="stmt">SHOW
        CREATE SCHEMA</literal> is a synonym for
        <literal role="stmt">SHOW CREATE DATABASE</literal>.

This statement displays the <literal role="stmt">CREATE
        EVENT</literal> statement needed to re-create a given event. It
        requires the <literal role="priv">EVENT</literal> privilege for
        the database from which the event is to be shown. For example
        (using the same event <literal>e_daily</literal> defined and
        then altered in <xref linkend="show-events" />):

This statement is similar to <literal role="stmt">SHOW CREATE
        PROCEDURE</literal> but for stored functions. See
        <xref linkend="show-create-procedure" />.

This statement is a MySQL extension. It returns the exact string
        that can be used to re-create the named stored procedure. A
        similar statement, <literal role="stmt">SHOW CREATE
        FUNCTION</literal>, displays information about stored functions
        (see <xref linkend="show-create-function" />).

To use either statement, you must have the global
        <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> privilege.

As of MySQL 8.0.16, MySQL implements <literal>CHECK</literal>
        constraints and <literal role="stmt">SHOW CREATE TABLE</literal>
        displays them. All <literal>CHECK</literal> constraints are
        displayed as table constraints. That is, a
        <literal>CHECK</literal> constraint originally specified as part
        of a column definition displays as a separate clause not part of
        the column definition. Example:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>CREATE TABLE t1 (</userinput>
         <userinput>i1 INT CHECK (i1 <> 0),      -- column constraint</userinput>
         <userinput>i2 INT,</userinput>
         <userinput>CHECK (i2 > i1),             -- table constraint</userinput>
         <userinput>CHECK (i2 <> 0) NOT ENFORCED -- table constraint, not enforced</userinput>
       <userinput>);</userinput>

mysql> <userinput>SHOW CREATE TABLE t1\G</userinput>
*************************** 1. row ***************************
       Table: t1
Create Table: CREATE TABLE `t1` (
  `i1` int(11) DEFAULT NULL,
  `i2` int(11) DEFAULT NULL,
  CONSTRAINT `t1_chk_1` CHECK ((`i1` <> 0)),
  CONSTRAINT `t1_chk_2` CHECK ((`i2` > `i1`)),
  CONSTRAINT `t1_chk_3` CHECK ((`i2` <> 0)) /*!80016 NOT ENFORCED */
) ENGINE=InnoDB DEFAULT CHARSET=utf8mb4 COLLATE=utf8mb4_0900_ai_ci

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">SHOW CREATE TABLE</literal> quotes table
        and column names according to the value of the
        <literal role="sysvar">sql_quote_show_create</literal> option.
        See <xref linkend="server-system-variables" />.

For information about how <literal role="stmt">CREATE
        TABLE</literal> statements are stored by MySQL, see
        <xref linkend="create-table-statement-retention" />.

This statement shows the <literal role="stmt">CREATE
        TRIGGER</literal> statement that creates the named trigger. This
        statement requires the <literal role="priv">TRIGGER</literal>
        privilege for the table associated with the trigger.

This statement shows the <literal role="stmt">CREATE
        USER</literal> statement that creates the named user. An error
        occurs if the user does not exist. The statement requires the
        <literal role="priv">SELECT</literal> privilege for the
        <literal>mysql</literal> system schema, except to see
        information for the current user. For the current user, the
        <literal role="priv">SELECT</literal> privilege for the
        <literal>mysql.user</literal> system table is required for
        display of the password hash in the <literal>IDENTIFIED
        AS</literal> clause; otherwise, the hash displays as
        <literal><secret></literal>.

To name the account, use the format described in
        <xref linkend="account-names" />. The host name part of the
        account name, if omitted, defaults to <literal>'%'</literal>. It
        is also possible to specify
        <literal role="func">CURRENT_USER</literal> or
        <literal role="func">CURRENT_USER()</literal> to refer to the
        account associated with the current session.

Password hash values displayed in the <literal>IDENTIFIED
        WITH</literal> clause of output from <literal role="stmt">SHOW
        CREATE USER</literal> may contain unprintable characters that
        have adverse effects on terminal displays and in other
        environments. Enabling the
        <literal role="sysvar">print_identified_with_as_hex</literal>
        system variable (available as of MySQL 8.0.17) causes
        <literal role="stmt">SHOW CREATE USER</literal> to display such
        hash values as hexadecimal strings rather than as regular string
        literals. Hash values that do not contain unprintable characters
        still display as regular string literals, even with this
        variable enabled.

This statement shows the <literal role="stmt">CREATE
        VIEW</literal> statement that creates the named view.

<literal role="stmt">SHOW DATABASES</literal> lists the
        databases on the MySQL server host.
        <literal condition="show-databases" role="stmt">SHOW
        SCHEMAS</literal> is a synonym for <literal role="stmt">SHOW
        DATABASES</literal>. The <literal role="op">LIKE</literal>
        clause, if present, indicates which database names to match. The
        <literal>WHERE</literal> clause can be given to select rows
        using more general conditions, as discussed in
        <xref linkend="extended-show" />.

You see only those databases for which you have some kind of
        privilege, unless you have the global <literal role="stmt">SHOW
        DATABASES</literal> privilege. You can also get this list using
        the <command>mysqlshow</command> command.

If the server was started with the
        <option role="mysqld">--skip-show-database</option> option, you
        cannot use this statement at all unless you have the
        <literal role="priv">SHOW DATABASES</literal> privilege.

MySQL implements databases as directories in the data directory,
        so this statement simply lists directories in that location.
        However, the output may include names of directories that do not
        correspond to actual databases.

Database information is also available from the
        <literal>INFORMATION_SCHEMA</literal>
        <literal role="is">SCHEMATA</literal> table. See
        <xref linkend="schemata-table" />.

<literal role="stmt">SHOW ENGINE</literal> displays operational
        information about a storage engine. It requires the
        <literal role="priv">PROCESS</literal> privilege. The statement
        has these variants:

description.programlisting:
>
SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS
SHOW ENGINE INNODB MUTEX
SHOW ENGINE PERFORMANCE_SCHEMA STATUS

description.para:
<literal condition="show-engine" role="stmt">SHOW ENGINE INNODB
        STATUS</literal> displays extensive information from the
        standard <literal>InnoDB</literal> Monitor about the state of
        the <literal>InnoDB</literal> storage engine. For information
        about the standard monitor and other <literal>InnoDB</literal>
        Monitors that provide information about
        <literal>InnoDB</literal> processing, see
        <xref linkend="innodb-monitors" />.

<literal condition="show-engine" role="stmt">SHOW ENGINE INNODB
        MUTEX</literal> displays <literal>InnoDB</literal>
        <link linkend="glos_mutex">mutex</link> and
        <link linkend="glos_rw_lock">rw-lock</link> statistics.

Mutex statistics collection is configured dynamically using the
        following options:

itemizedlist.para: To enable the collection of mutex statistics, run:
To reset mutex statistics, run:
To disable the collection of mutex statistics, run:

description.para:
Collection of mutex statistics for
        <literal condition="show-engine" role="stmt">SHOW ENGINE INNODB
        MUTEX</literal> can also be enabled by setting
        <literal role="sysvar">innodb_monitor_enable='all'</literal>, or
        disabled by setting
        <literal role="sysvar">innodb_monitor_disable='all'</literal>.

<literal condition="show-engine" role="stmt">SHOW ENGINE INNODB
        MUTEX</literal> output has these columns:

itemizedlist.para: <literal>Type</literal>
Always <literal>InnoDB</literal>.
<literal>Name</literal>

For mutexes, the <literal>Name</literal> field reports only
            the mutex name. For rwlocks, the <literal>Name</literal>
            field reports the source file where the rwlock is
            implemented, and the line number in the file where the
            rwlock is created. The line number is specific to your
            version of MySQL.
<literal>Status</literal>

The mutex status. This field reports the number of spins,
            waits, and calls. Statistics for low-level operating system
            mutexes, which are implemented outside of
            <literal>InnoDB</literal>, are not reported.
<literal>spins</literal> indicates the number of spins.

<literal>waits</literal> indicates the number of mutex
                waits.

<literal>calls</literal> indicates how many times the
                mutex was requested.

description.para:
<literal>SHOW ENGINE INNODB MUTEX</literal> skips the
        <link linkend="glos_mutex">mutexes</link> and
        <link linkend="glos_rw_lock">rw-locks</link> of
        <link linkend="glos_buffer_pool">buffer pool</link> blocks, as
        the amount of output can be overwhelming on systems with a large
        buffer pool. (There is one mutex and one rw-lock in each 16K
        buffer pool block, and there are 65,536 blocks per gigabyte.)
        <literal>SHOW ENGINE INNODB MUTEX</literal> also does not list
        any mutexes or rw-locks that have never been waited on
        (<literal>os_waits=0</literal>). Thus, <literal>SHOW ENGINE
        INNODB MUTEX</literal> only displays information about mutexes
        and rw-locks outside of the buffer pool that have caused at
        least one OS-level <link linkend="glos_wait">wait</link>.

Use <literal condition="show-engine" role="stmt">SHOW ENGINE
        PERFORMANCE_SCHEMA STATUS</literal> to inspect the internal
        operation of the Performance Schema code:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SHOW ENGINE PERFORMANCE_SCHEMA STATUS\G</userinput>
...
*************************** 3. row ***************************
  Type: performance_schema
  Name: events_waits_history.size
Status: 76
*************************** 4. row ***************************
  Type: performance_schema
  Name: events_waits_history.count
Status: 10000
*************************** 5. row ***************************
  Type: performance_schema
  Name: events_waits_history.memory
Status: 760000
...
*************************** 57. row ***************************
  Type: performance_schema
  Name: performance_schema.memory
Status: 26459600
...

description.para:
This statement is intended to help the DBA understand the
        effects that different Performance Schema options have on memory
        requirements.

<literal>Name</literal> values consist of two parts, which name
        an internal buffer and a buffer attribute, respectively.
        Interpret buffer names as follows:

itemizedlist.para:
An internal buffer that is not exposed as a table is named
            within parentheses. Examples:
            <literal>(pfs_cond_class).size</literal>,
            <literal>(pfs_mutex_class).memory</literal>.

An internal buffer that is exposed as a table in the
            <literal>performance_schema</literal> database is named
            after the table, without parentheses. Examples:
            <literal>events_waits_history.size</literal>,
            <literal>mutex_instances.count</literal>.

A value that applies to the Performance Schema as a whole
            begins with <literal>performance_schema</literal>. Example:
            <literal>performance_schema.memory</literal>.

description.para: Buffer attributes have these meanings:

itemizedlist.para:
<literal>size</literal> is the size of the internal record
            used by the implementation, such as the size of a row in a
            table. <literal>size</literal> values cannot be changed.

<literal>count</literal> is the number of internal records,
            such as the number of rows in a table.
            <literal>count</literal> values can be changed using
            Performance Schema configuration options.

For a table,
            <literal><replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>.memory</literal>
            is the product of <literal>size</literal> and
            <literal>count</literal>. For the Performance Schema as a
            whole, <literal>performance_schema.memory</literal> is the
            sum of all the memory used (the sum of all other
            <literal>memory</literal> values).

description.para:
In some cases, there is a direct relationship between a
        Performance Schema configuration parameter and a <literal>SHOW
        ENGINE</literal> value. For example,
        <literal>events_waits_history_long.count</literal> corresponds
        to
        <literal role="sysvar">performance_schema_events_waits_history_long_size</literal>.
        In other cases, the relationship is more complex. For example,
        <literal>events_waits_history.count</literal> corresponds to
        <literal role="sysvar">performance_schema_events_waits_history_size</literal>
        (the number of rows per thread) multiplied by
        <literal role="sysvar">performance_schema_max_thread_instances</literal>
        ( the number of threads).
