description.para:
The Performance Schema provides tables that expose replication
        information. This is similar to the information available from
        the <literal role="stmt">SHOW SLAVE STATUS</literal> statement,
        but represented in table form. For details, see
        <xref linkend="performance-schema-replication-tables" />.

With a <literal role="op">LIKE</literal> clause, the statement
        displays only rows for those variables with names that match the
        pattern:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SHOW STATUS LIKE 'Key%';</userinput>
+--------------------+----------+
| Variable_name      | Value    |
+--------------------+----------+
| Key_blocks_used    | 14955    |
| Key_read_requests  | 96854827 |
| Key_reads          | 162040   |
| Key_write_requests | 7589728  |
| Key_writes         | 3813196  |
+--------------------+----------+

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">SHOW TABLE STATUS</literal> works likes
        <literal role="stmt">SHOW TABLES</literal>, but provides a lot
        of information about each non-<literal>TEMPORARY</literal>
        table. You can also get this list using the <command>mysqlshow
        --status <replaceable>db_name</replaceable></command> command.
        The <literal role="op">LIKE</literal> clause, if present,
        indicates which table names to match. The
        <literal>WHERE</literal> clause can be given to select rows
        using more general conditions, as discussed in
        <xref linkend="extended-show" />.

<literal role="stmt">SHOW TABLES</literal> lists the
        non-<literal>TEMPORARY</literal> tables in a given database. You
        can also get this list using the <command>mysqlshow
        <replaceable>db_name</replaceable></command> command. The
        <literal role="op">LIKE</literal> clause, if present, indicates
        which table names to match. The <literal>WHERE</literal> clause
        can be given to select rows using more general conditions, as
        discussed in <xref linkend="extended-show" />.

Matching performed by the <literal>LIKE</literal> clause is
        dependent on the setting of the
        <literal role="sysvar">lower_case_table_names</literal> system
        variable.

The optional <literal>EXTENDED</literal> modifier causes
        <literal role="stmt">SHOW TABLES</literal> to list hidden tables
        created by failed <literal role="stmt">ALTER TABLE</literal>
        statements. These temporary tables have names beginning with
        <literal>#sql</literal> and can be dropped using
        <literal role="stmt">DROP TABLE</literal>.

This statement also lists any views in the database. The
        optional <literal>FULL</literal> modifier causes
        <literal role="stmt">SHOW TABLES</literal> to display a second
        output column with values of <literal>BASE TABLE</literal> for a
        table, <literal>VIEW</literal> for a view, or <literal>SYSTEM
        VIEW</literal> for an <literal>INFORMATION_SCHEMA</literal>
        table.

If you have no privileges for a base table or view, it does not
        show up in the output from <literal role="stmt">SHOW
        TABLES</literal> or <command>mysqlshow db_name</command>.

<literal role="stmt">SHOW TRIGGERS</literal> lists the triggers
        currently defined for tables in a database (the default database
        unless a <literal>FROM</literal> clause is given). This
        statement returns results only for databases and tables for
        which you have the <literal role="priv">TRIGGER</literal>
        privilege. The <literal role="op">LIKE</literal> clause, if
        present, indicates which table names (not trigger names) to
        match and causes the statement to display triggers for those
        tables. The <literal>WHERE</literal> clause can be given to
        select rows using more general conditions, as discussed in
        <xref linkend="extended-show" />.

For the <literal>ins_sum</literal> trigger defined in
        <xref linkend="triggers" />, the output of
        <literal role="stmt">SHOW TRIGGERS</literal> is as shown here:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>SHOW TRIGGERS LIKE 'acc%'\G</userinput>
*************************** 1. row ***************************
             Trigger: ins_sum
               Event: INSERT
               Table: account
           Statement: SET @sum = @sum + NEW.amount
              Timing: BEFORE
             Created: 2018-08-08 10:10:12.61
            sql_mode: ONLY_FULL_GROUP_BY,STRICT_TRANS_TABLES,
                      NO_ZERO_IN_DATE,NO_ZERO_DATE,
                      ERROR_FOR_DIVISION_BY_ZERO,
                      NO_ENGINE_SUBSTITUTION
             Definer: me@localhost
character_set_client: utf8mb4
collation_connection: utf8mb4_0900_ai_ci
  Database Collation: utf8mb4_0900_ai_ci

description.para:
With a <literal role="op">LIKE</literal> clause, the statement
        displays only rows for those variables with names that match the
        pattern. To obtain the row for a specific variable, use a
        <literal role="op">LIKE</literal> clause as shown:

To get a list of variables whose name match a pattern, use the
        <literal>%</literal> wildcard character in a
        <literal role="op">LIKE</literal> clause:

Wildcard characters can be used in any position within the
        pattern to be matched. Strictly speaking, because
        <literal>_</literal> is a wildcard that matches any single
        character, you should escape it as <literal>\_</literal> to
        match it literally. In practice, this is rarely necessary.

<literal role="stmt">SHOW WARNINGS</literal> is a diagnostic
        statement that displays information about the conditions
        (errors, warnings, and notes) resulting from executing a
        statement in the current session. Warnings are generated for DML
        statements such as <literal role="stmt">INSERT</literal>,
        <literal role="stmt">UPDATE</literal>, and
        <literal role="stmt">LOAD DATA</literal> as well as DDL
        statements such as <literal role="stmt">CREATE TABLE</literal>
        and <literal role="stmt">ALTER TABLE</literal>.

The <literal>LIMIT</literal> clause has the same syntax as for
        the <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> statement. See
        <xref linkend="select" />.

<literal role="stmt">SHOW WARNINGS</literal> is also used
        following <literal role="stmt">EXPLAIN</literal>, to display the
        extended information generated by
        <literal role="stmt">EXPLAIN</literal>. See
        <xref linkend="explain-extended" />.

<literal role="stmt">SHOW WARNINGS</literal> displays
        information about the conditions resulting from execution of the
        most recent nondiagnostic statement in the current session. If
        the most recent statement resulted in an error during parsing,
        <literal role="stmt">SHOW WARNINGS</literal> shows the resulting
        conditions, regardless of statement type (diagnostic or
        nondiagnostic).

The <literal condition="show-warnings" role="stmt">SHOW COUNT(*)
        WARNINGS</literal> diagnostic statement displays the total
        number of errors, warnings, and notes. You can also retrieve
        this number from the
        <literal role="sysvar">warning_count</literal> system variable:

A difference in these statements is that the first is a
        diagnostic statement that does not clear the message list. The
        second, because it is a <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal>
        statement is considered nondiagnostic and does clear the message
        list.

A related diagnostic statement, <literal role="stmt">SHOW
        ERRORS</literal>, shows only error conditions (it excludes
        warnings and notes), and
        <literal condition="show-warnings" role="stmt">SHOW COUNT(*)
        ERRORS</literal> statement displays the total number of errors.
        See <xref linkend="show-errors" />. <literal role="stmt">GET
        DIAGNOSTICS</literal> can be used to examine information for
        individual conditions. See <xref linkend="get-diagnostics" />.

<literal role="stmt">SHOW</literal> has many forms that provide
      information about databases, tables, columns, or status
      information about the server. This section describes those
      following:

description.programlisting:
>
SHOW {BINARY | MASTER} LOGS
SHOW BINLOG EVENTS [IN '<replaceable>log_name</replaceable>'] [FROM <replaceable>pos</replaceable>] [LIMIT [<replaceable>offset</replaceable>,] <replaceable>row_count</replaceable>]
SHOW CHARACTER SET [<replaceable>like_or_where</replaceable>]
SHOW COLLATION [<replaceable>like_or_where</replaceable>]
SHOW [FULL] COLUMNS FROM <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> [FROM <replaceable>db_name</replaceable>] [<replaceable>like_or_where</replaceable>]
SHOW CREATE DATABASE <replaceable>db_name</replaceable>
SHOW CREATE EVENT <replaceable>event_name</replaceable>
SHOW CREATE FUNCTION <replaceable>func_name</replaceable>
SHOW CREATE PROCEDURE <replaceable>proc_name</replaceable>
SHOW CREATE TABLE <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>
SHOW CREATE TRIGGER <replaceable>trigger_name</replaceable>
SHOW CREATE VIEW <replaceable>view_name</replaceable>
SHOW DATABASES [<replaceable>like_or_where</replaceable>]
SHOW ENGINE <replaceable>engine_name</replaceable> {STATUS | MUTEX}
SHOW [STORAGE] ENGINES
SHOW ERRORS [LIMIT [<replaceable>offset</replaceable>,] <replaceable>row_count</replaceable>]
SHOW EVENTS
SHOW FUNCTION CODE <replaceable>func_name</replaceable>
SHOW FUNCTION STATUS [<replaceable>like_or_where</replaceable>]
SHOW GRANTS FOR <replaceable>user</replaceable>
SHOW INDEX FROM <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> [FROM <replaceable>db_name</replaceable>]
SHOW MASTER STATUS
SHOW OPEN TABLES [FROM <replaceable>db_name</replaceable>] [<replaceable>like_or_where</replaceable>]
SHOW PLUGINS
SHOW PROCEDURE CODE <replaceable>proc_name</replaceable>
SHOW PROCEDURE STATUS [<replaceable>like_or_where</replaceable>]
SHOW PRIVILEGES
SHOW [FULL] PROCESSLIST
SHOW PROFILE [<replaceable>types</replaceable>] [FOR QUERY <replaceable>n</replaceable>] [OFFSET <replaceable>n</replaceable>] [LIMIT <replaceable>n</replaceable>]
SHOW PROFILES
SHOW RELAYLOG EVENTS [IN '<replaceable>log_name</replaceable>'] [FROM <replaceable>pos</replaceable>] [LIMIT [<replaceable>offset</replaceable>,] <replaceable>row_count</replaceable>]
SHOW SLAVE HOSTS
SHOW SLAVE STATUS [FOR CHANNEL <replaceable>channel</replaceable>]
SHOW [GLOBAL | SESSION] STATUS [<replaceable>like_or_where</replaceable>]
SHOW TABLE STATUS [FROM <replaceable>db_name</replaceable>] [<replaceable>like_or_where</replaceable>]
SHOW [FULL] TABLES [FROM <replaceable>db_name</replaceable>] [<replaceable>like_or_where</replaceable>]
SHOW TRIGGERS [FROM <replaceable>db_name</replaceable>] [<replaceable>like_or_where</replaceable>]
SHOW [GLOBAL | SESSION] VARIABLES [<replaceable>like_or_where</replaceable>]
SHOW WARNINGS [LIMIT [<replaceable>offset</replaceable>,] <replaceable>row_count</replaceable>]

<replaceable>like_or_where</replaceable>:
    LIKE '<replaceable>pattern</replaceable>'
  | WHERE <replaceable>expr</replaceable>

description.para:
If the syntax for a given <literal role="stmt">SHOW</literal>
      statement includes a <literal condition="like" role="op">LIKE
      '<replaceable>pattern</replaceable>'</literal> part,
      <literal>'<replaceable>pattern</replaceable>'</literal> is a
      string that can contain the SQL <literal>%</literal> and
      <literal>_</literal> wildcard characters. The pattern is useful
      for restricting statement output to matching values.

Several <literal role="stmt">SHOW</literal> statements also accept
      a <literal>WHERE</literal> clause that provides more flexibility
      in specifying which rows to display. See
      <xref linkend="extended-show" />.

<literal role="stmt">BINLOG</literal> is an internal-use
        statement. It is generated by the <command>mysqlbinlog</command>
        program as the printable representation of certain events in
        binary log files. (See <xref linkend="mysqlbinlog" />.) The
        <literal>'<replaceable>str</replaceable>'</literal> value is a
        base 64-encoded string the that server decodes to determine the
        data change indicated by the corresponding event.

To execute <literal role="stmt">BINLOG</literal> statements when
        applying <command>mysqlbinlog</command> output, a user account
        requires the <literal role="priv">BINLOG_ADMIN</literal> or
        <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege, or the
        <literal role="priv">REPLICATION_APPLIER</literal> privilege
        plus the appropriate privileges to execute each log event.

The <literal role="stmt">CACHE INDEX</literal> statement assigns
        table indexes to a specific key cache. It applies only to
        <literal>MyISAM</literal> tables, including partitioned
        <literal>MyISAM</literal> tables. After the indexes have been
        assigned, they can be preloaded into the cache if desired with
        <literal condition="load-index" role="stmt">LOAD INDEX INTO
        CACHE</literal>.

The following statement assigns indexes from the tables
        <literal>t1</literal>, <literal>t2</literal>, and
        <literal>t3</literal> to the key cache named
        <literal>hot_cache</literal>:

description.programlisting:
>
mysql> <userinput>CACHE INDEX t1, t2, t3 IN hot_cache;</userinput>
+---------+--------------------+----------+----------+
| Table   | Op                 | Msg_type | Msg_text |
+---------+--------------------+----------+----------+
| test.t1 | assign_to_keycache | status   | OK       |
| test.t2 | assign_to_keycache | status   | OK       |
| test.t3 | assign_to_keycache | status   | OK       |
+---------+--------------------+----------+----------+

description.para:
The <literal role="stmt">FLUSH</literal> statement has several
        variant forms that clear or reload various internal caches,
        flush tables, or acquire locks. To execute
        <literal role="stmt">FLUSH</literal>, you must have the
        <literal role="priv">RELOAD</literal> privilege. Specific flush
        options might require additional privileges, as described later.

By default, the server writes
        <literal role="stmt">FLUSH</literal> statements to the binary
        log so that they replicate to replication slaves. To suppress
        logging, specify the optional
        <literal>NO_WRITE_TO_BINLOG</literal> keyword or its alias
        <literal>LOCAL</literal>.

The <literal role="stmt">FLUSH</literal> statement causes an
        implicit commit. See <xref linkend="implicit-commit" />.

The <command>mysqladmin</command> utility provides a
        command-line interface to some flush operations, using commands
        such as <literal>flush-hosts</literal>,
        <literal>flush-logs</literal>,
        <literal>flush-privileges</literal>,
        <literal>flush-status</literal>, and
        <literal>flush-tables</literal>. See
        <xref linkend="mysqladmin" />.

Sending a <literal>SIGHUP</literal> signal to the server causes
        several flush operations to occur that are similar to various
        forms of the <literal role="stmt">FLUSH</literal> statement. See
        <xref linkend="server-signal-response" />.

The <literal role="stmt">RESET</literal> statement is similar to
        <literal role="stmt">FLUSH</literal>. See
        <xref linkend="reset" />, for information about using the
        <literal role="stmt">RESET</literal> statement with replication.

syntax.programlisting:
>
FLUSH [NO_WRITE_TO_BINLOG | LOCAL] {
    <replaceable>flush_option</replaceable> [, <replaceable>flush_option</replaceable>] ...
  | <replaceable>tables_option</replaceable>
}

<replaceable>flush_option</replaceable>: {
    BINARY LOGS
  | ENGINE LOGS
  | ERROR LOGS
  | GENERAL LOGS
  | HOSTS
  | LOGS
  | PRIVILEGES
  | OPTIMIZER_COSTS
  | RELAY LOGS [FOR CHANNEL <replaceable>channel</replaceable>]
  | SLOW LOGS
  | STATUS
  | USER_RESOURCES
}

<replaceable>tables_option</replaceable>: {
    TABLES
  | TABLES <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> [, <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>] ...
  | TABLES WITH READ LOCK
  | TABLES <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> [, <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>] ... WITH READ LOCK
  | TABLES <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> [, <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>] ... FOR EXPORT
}

description.para:
Each connection to <command>mysqld</command> runs in a separate
        thread. You can kill a thread with the <literal>KILL
        <replaceable>processlist_id</replaceable></literal> statement.

Thread processlist identifiers can be determined from the
        <literal>ID</literal> column of the
        <literal>INFORMATION_SCHEMA</literal>
        <literal role="is">PROCESSLIST</literal> table, the
        <literal>Id</literal> column of <literal role="stmt">SHOW
        PROCESSLIST</literal> output, and the
        <literal>PROCESSLIST_ID</literal> column of the Performance
        Schema <literal role="ps">threads</literal> table. The value for
        the current thread is returned by the
        <literal role="func">CONNECTION_ID()</literal> function.

<literal role="stmt">KILL</literal> permits an optional
        <literal>CONNECTION</literal> or <literal>QUERY</literal>
        modifier:

itemizedlist.para:
<literal condition="kill" role="stmt">KILL
            CONNECTION</literal> is the same as
            <literal role="stmt">KILL</literal> with no modifier: It
            terminates the connection associated with the given
            <replaceable>processlist_id</replaceable>, after terminating
            any statement the connection is executing.

<literal condition="kill" role="stmt">KILL QUERY</literal>
            terminates the statement the connection is currently
            executing, but leaves the connection itself intact.

description.para:
The ability to see which threads are available to be killed
        depends on the <literal role="priv">PROCESS</literal> privilege:

itemizedlist.para:
Without <literal role="priv">PROCESS</literal>, you can see
            only your own threads.

With <literal role="priv">PROCESS</literal>, you can see all
            threads.

description.para:
The ability to kill threads and statements depends on the
        <literal role="priv">CONNECTION_ADMIN</literal> and
        <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privileges:

itemizedlist.para:
Without <literal role="priv">CONNECTION_ADMIN</literal> or
            <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal>, you can kill only your
            own threads and statements.

With <literal role="priv">CONNECTION_ADMIN</literal> or
            <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal>, you can kill all
            threads and statements, except that to affect a thread or
            statement that is executing with the
            <literal role="priv">SYSTEM_USER</literal> privilege, your
            own session must additionally have the
            <literal role="priv">SYSTEM_USER</literal> privilege.

description.para:
You can also use the <command>mysqladmin processlist</command>
        and <command>mysqladmin kill</command> commands to examine and
        kill threads.

The <literal condition="load-index" role="stmt">LOAD INDEX INTO
        CACHE</literal> statement preloads a table index into the key
        cache to which it has been assigned by an explicit
        <literal role="stmt">CACHE INDEX</literal> statement, or into
        the default key cache otherwise.

<literal condition="load-index" role="stmt">LOAD INDEX INTO
        CACHE</literal> applies only to <literal>MyISAM</literal>
        tables, including partitioned <literal>MyISAM</literal> tables.
        In addition, indexes on partitioned tables can be preloaded for
        one, several, or all partitions.

The <literal>IGNORE LEAVES</literal> modifier causes only blocks
        for the nonleaf nodes of the index to be preloaded.

<literal>IGNORE LEAVES</literal> is also supported for
        partitioned <literal>MyISAM</literal> tables.

syntax.programlisting:
>
LOAD INDEX INTO CACHE
  <replaceable>tbl_index_list</replaceable> [, <replaceable>tbl_index_list</replaceable>] ...

<replaceable>tbl_index_list</replaceable>:
  <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>
    [PARTITION (<replaceable>partition_list</replaceable>)]
    [{INDEX|KEY} (<replaceable>index_name</replaceable>[, <replaceable>index_name</replaceable>] ...)]
    [IGNORE LEAVES]

<replaceable>partition_list</replaceable>: {
    <replaceable>partition_name</replaceable>[, <replaceable>partition_name</replaceable>] ...
  | ALL
}

description.para:
The <literal role="stmt">RESET</literal> statement is used to
        clear the state of various server operations. You must have the
        <literal role="priv">RELOAD</literal> privilege to execute
        <literal role="stmt">RESET</literal>.

For information about the <literal role="stmt">RESET
        PERSIST</literal> statement that removes persisted global system
        variables, see <xref linkend="reset-persist" />.

<literal role="stmt">RESET</literal> acts as a stronger version
        of the <literal role="stmt">FLUSH</literal> statement. See
        <xref linkend="flush" />.

The <literal role="stmt">RESET</literal> statement causes an
        implicit commit. See <xref linkend="implicit-commit" />.

The following list describes the permitted
        <literal role="stmt">RESET</literal> statement
        <replaceable>reset_option</replaceable> values:

itemizedlist.para: <literal>RESET MASTER</literal>

Deletes all binary logs listed in the index file, resets the
            binary log index file to be empty, and creates a new binary
            log file.
<literal>RESET SLAVE</literal>

Makes the slave forget its replication position in the
            master binary logs. Also resets the relay log by deleting
            any existing relay log files and beginning a new one.

description.para:
<literal role="stmt">RESET PERSIST</literal> removes persisted
        global system variable settings from the
        <filename>mysqld-auto.cnf</filename> option file in the data
        directory. Removing a persisted system variable causes the
        variable no longer to be initialized from
        <filename>mysqld-auto.cnf</filename> at server startup. For more
        information about persisting system variables and the
        <filename>mysqld-auto.cnf</filename> file, see
        <xref linkend="persisted-system-variables" />.

The privileges required for <literal role="stmt">RESET
        PERSIST</literal> depend on the type of system variable to be
        removed:

itemizedlist.para:
For dynamic system variables, this statement requires the
            <literal role="priv">SYSTEM_VARIABLES_ADMIN</literal> or
            <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege.

For read-only system variables, this statement requires the
            <literal role="priv">SYSTEM_VARIABLES_ADMIN</literal> and
            <literal role="priv">PERSIST_RO_VARIABLES_ADMIN</literal>
            privileges.

description.para: See <xref linkend="system-variable-privileges" />.

Depending on whether the variable name and <literal>IF
        EXISTS</literal> clauses are present, the
        <literal role="stmt">RESET PERSIST</literal> statement has these
        forms:

itemizedlist.para:
To remove all persisted variables from
            <filename>mysqld-auto.cnf</filename>, use
            <literal role="stmt">RESET PERSIST</literal> without naming
            any system variable:

You must have privileges for removing both dynamic and
            read-only system variables if
            <filename>mysqld-auto.cnf</filename> contains both kinds of
            variables.

To remove a specific persisted variable from
            <filename>mysqld-auto.cnf</filename>, name it in the
            statement:

This includes plugin system variables, even if the plugin is
            not currently installed. If the variable is not present in
            the file, an error occurs.

To remove a specific persisted variable from
            <filename>mysqld-auto.cnf</filename>, but produce a warning
            rather than an error if the variable is not present in the
            file, add an <literal>IF EXISTS</literal> clause to the
            previous syntax:

description.para:
This statement stops and restarts the MySQL server. It requires
        the <literal role="priv">SHUTDOWN</literal> privilege.

One use for <literal role="stmt">RESTART</literal> is when it is
        not possible or convenient to gain command-line access to the
        MySQL server on the server host to restart it. For example,
        <literal condition="set-variable" role="stmt">SET
        PERSIST_ONLY</literal> can be used at runtime to make
        configuration changes to system variables that can be set only
        at server startup, but the server must still be restarted for
        those changes to take effect. The
        <literal role="stmt">RESTART</literal> statement provides a way
        to do so from within client sessions, without requiring
        command-line access on the server host.

A successful <literal role="stmt">RESTART</literal> operation
        requires <command>mysqld</command> to be running in an
        environment that has a monitoring process available to detect a
        server shutdown performed for restart purposes:

itemizedlist.para:
In the presence of a monitoring process,
            <literal role="stmt">RESTART</literal> causes
            <command>mysqld</command> to terminate such that the
            monitoring process can determine that it should start a new
            <command>mysqld</command> instance.

If no monitoring process is present,
            <literal role="stmt">RESTART</literal> fails with an error.

description.para:
These platforms provide the necessary monitoring support for the
        <literal role="stmt">RESTART</literal> statement:

itemizedlist.para:
Windows, when <command>mysqld</command> is started as a
            Windows service or standalone. (<command>mysqld</command>
            forks, and one process acts as a monitor to the other, which
            acts as the server.)

Unix and Unix-like systems that use systemd or
            <command>mysqld_safe</command> to manage
            <command>mysqld</command>.

description.para:
To configure a monitoring environment such that
        <command>mysqld</command> enables the
        <literal role="stmt">RESTART</literal> statement:

Here is a minimal example as implemented in the
        <command>bash</command> shell:

description.programlisting:
>
#!/bin/bash

export MYSQLD_PARENT_PID=$$

export MYSQLD_RESTART_EXIT=16

while true ; do
  bin/mysqld <replaceable>mysqld options here</replaceable>
  if [ $? -ne $MYSQLD_RESTART_EXIT ]; then
    break
  fi
done

description.para:
On Windows, the forking used to implement
        <literal role="stmt">RESTART</literal> makes determining the
        server process to attach to for debugging more difficult. To
        alleviate this, starting the server with
        <option role="mysqld">--gdb</option> suppresses forking, in
        addition to its other actions done to set up a debugging
        environment. In non-debug settings,
        <option role="mysqld">--no-monitor</option> may be used for the
        sole purpose of suppressing forking the monitor process. For a
        server started with either <option role="mysqld">--gdb</option>
        or <option role="mysqld">--no-monitor</option>, executing
        <literal role="stmt">RESTART</literal> causes the server to
        simply exit without restarting.

This statement stops the MySQL server. It requires the
        <literal role="priv">SHUTDOWN</literal> privilege.

<literal role="stmt">SHUTDOWN</literal> provides an SQL-level
        interface to the same functionality available using the
        <command>mysqladmin shutdown</command> command or the
        <literal role="cfunc">mysql_shutdown()</literal> C API function.

These statements provide control over use of
      <link linkend="glos_transaction">transactions</link>:

itemizedlist.para:
<literal>START TRANSACTION</literal> or
          <literal>BEGIN</literal> start a new transaction.

<literal>COMMIT</literal> commits the current transaction,
          making its changes permanent.

<literal>ROLLBACK</literal> rolls back the current
          transaction, canceling its changes.

<literal>SET autocommit</literal> disables or enables the
          default autocommit mode for the current session.

description.para:
By default, MySQL runs with
      <link linkend="glos_autocommit">autocommit</link> mode enabled.
      This means that, when not otherwise inside a transaction, each
      statement is atomic, as if it were surrounded by <literal>START
      TRANSACTION</literal> and <literal>COMMIT</literal>. You cannot
      use <literal>ROLLBACK</literal> to undo the effect; however, if an
      error occurs during statement execution, the statement is rolled
      back.

To disable autocommit mode implicitly for a single series of
      statements, use the <literal>START TRANSACTION</literal>
      statement:

With <literal>START TRANSACTION</literal>, autocommit remains
      disabled until you end the transaction with
      <literal>COMMIT</literal> or <literal>ROLLBACK</literal>. The
      autocommit mode then reverts to its previous state.

<literal>START TRANSACTION</literal> permits several modifiers
      that control transaction characteristics. To specify multiple
      modifiers, separate them by commas.

itemizedlist.para:
The <literal>WITH CONSISTENT SNAPSHOT</literal> modifier
          starts a <link linkend="glos_consistent_read">consistent
          read</link> for storage engines that are capable of it. This
          applies only to <literal>InnoDB</literal>. The effect is the
          same as issuing a <literal>START TRANSACTION</literal>
          followed by a <literal role="stmt">SELECT</literal> from any
          <literal>InnoDB</literal> table. See
          <xref linkend="innodb-consistent-read" />. The <literal>WITH
          CONSISTENT SNAPSHOT</literal> modifier does not change the
          current transaction
          <link linkend="glos_isolation_level">isolation level</link>,
          so it provides a consistent snapshot only if the current
          isolation level is one that permits a consistent read. The
          only isolation level that permits a consistent read is
          <literal role="isolevel">REPEATABLE READ</literal>. For all
          other isolation levels, the <literal>WITH CONSISTENT
          SNAPSHOT</literal> clause is ignored. A warning is generated
          when the <literal>WITH CONSISTENT SNAPSHOT</literal> clause is
          ignored.

The <literal>READ WRITE</literal> and <literal>READ
          ONLY</literal> modifiers set the transaction access mode. They
          permit or prohibit changes to tables used in the transaction.
          The <literal>READ ONLY</literal> restriction prevents the
          transaction from modifying or locking both transactional and
          nontransactional tables that are visible to other
          transactions; the transaction can still modify or lock
          temporary tables.

MySQL enables extra optimizations for queries on
          <literal>InnoDB</literal> tables when the transaction is known
          to be read-only. Specifying <literal>READ ONLY</literal>
          ensures these optimizations are applied in cases where the
          read-only status cannot be determined automatically. See
          <xref linkend="innodb-performance-ro-txn" /> for more
          information.

If no access mode is specified, the default mode applies.
          Unless the default has been changed, it is read/write. It is
          not permitted to specify both <literal>READ WRITE</literal>
          and <literal>READ ONLY</literal> in the same statement.

In read-only mode, it remains possible to change tables
          created with the <literal>TEMPORARY</literal> keyword using
          DML statements. Changes made with DDL statements are not
          permitted, just as with permanent tables.

For additional information about transaction access mode,
          including ways to change the default mode, see
          <xref linkend="set-transaction" />.

If the <literal role="sysvar">read_only</literal> system
          variable is enabled, explicitly starting a transaction with
          <literal>START TRANSACTION READ WRITE</literal> requires the
          <literal role="priv">CONNECTION_ADMIN</literal> or
          <literal role="priv">SUPER</literal> privilege.

description.para:
To disable autocommit mode explicitly, use the following
      statement:

description.programlisting:
>
SET autocommit=0;

description.para:
After disabling autocommit mode by setting the
      <literal role="sysvar">autocommit</literal> variable to zero,
      changes to transaction-safe tables (such as those for
      <literal role="se">InnoDB</literal> or
      <literal role="se">NDB</literal>) are not made permanent
      immediately. You must use <literal role="stmt">COMMIT</literal> to
      store your changes to disk or <literal>ROLLBACK</literal> to
      ignore the changes.

<literal role="sysvar">autocommit</literal> is a session variable
      and must be set for each session. To disable autocommit mode for
      each new connection, see the description of the
      <literal role="sysvar">autocommit</literal> system variable at
      <xref linkend="server-system-variables" />.

<literal>BEGIN</literal> and <literal>BEGIN WORK</literal> are
      supported as aliases of <literal>START TRANSACTION</literal> for
      initiating a transaction. <literal>START TRANSACTION</literal> is
      standard SQL syntax, is the recommended way to start an ad-hoc
      transaction, and permits modifiers that <literal>BEGIN</literal>
      does not.

The <literal>BEGIN</literal> statement differs from the use of the
      <literal>BEGIN</literal> keyword that starts a
      <literal condition="begin-end" role="stmt">BEGIN ... END</literal>
      compound statement. The latter does not begin a transaction. See
      <xref linkend="begin-end" />.

The optional <literal>WORK</literal> keyword is supported for
      <literal>COMMIT</literal> and <literal>ROLLBACK</literal>, as are
      the <literal>CHAIN</literal> and <literal>RELEASE</literal>
      clauses. <literal>CHAIN</literal> and <literal>RELEASE</literal>
      can be used for additional control over transaction completion.
      The value of the <literal role="sysvar">completion_type</literal>
      system variable determines the default completion behavior. See
      <xref linkend="server-system-variables" />.

The <literal>AND CHAIN</literal> clause causes a new transaction
      to begin as soon as the current one ends, and the new transaction
      has the same isolation level as the just-terminated transaction.
      The new transaction also uses the same access mode (<literal>READ
      WRITE</literal> or <literal>READ ONLY</literal>) as the
      just-terminated transaction. The <literal>RELEASE</literal> clause
      causes the server to disconnect the current client session after
      terminating the current transaction. Including the
      <literal>NO</literal> keyword suppresses <literal>CHAIN</literal>
      or <literal>RELEASE</literal> completion, which can be useful if
      the <literal role="sysvar">completion_type</literal> system
      variable is set to cause chaining or release completion by
      default.

syntax.programlisting:
>
START TRANSACTION
    [<replaceable>transaction_characteristic</replaceable> [, <replaceable>transaction_characteristic</replaceable>] ...]

<replaceable>transaction_characteristic</replaceable>: {
    WITH CONSISTENT SNAPSHOT
  | READ WRITE
  | READ ONLY
}

BEGIN [WORK]
COMMIT [WORK] [AND [NO] CHAIN] [[NO] RELEASE]
ROLLBACK [WORK] [AND [NO] CHAIN] [[NO] RELEASE]
SET autocommit = {0 | 1}

description.para:
<literal>InnoDB</literal> supports the SQL statements
      <literal role="stmt">SAVEPOINT</literal>,
      <literal condition="savepoint" role="stmt">ROLLBACK TO
      SAVEPOINT</literal>,
      <literal condition="savepoint" role="stmt">RELEASE
      SAVEPOINT</literal> and the optional <literal>WORK</literal>
      keyword for
      <literal condition="commit" role="stmt">ROLLBACK</literal>.

<literal>LOCK INSTANCE FOR BACKUP</literal> acquires an
      instance-level <emphasis>backup lock</emphasis> that permits DML
      during an online backup while preventing operations that could
      result in an inconsistent snapshot.

Executing the <literal>LOCK INSTANCE FOR BACKUP</literal>
      statement requires the <literal role="priv">BACKUP_ADMIN</literal>
      privilege. The <literal role="priv">BACKUP_ADMIN</literal>
      privilege is automatically granted to users with the
      <literal role="priv">RELOAD</literal> privilege when performing an
      in-place upgrade to MySQL current-series from an earlier
      version.
Multiple sessions can hold a backup lock simultaneously.

<literal>UNLOCK INSTANCE</literal> releases a backup lock held by
      the current session. A backup lock held by a session is also
      released if the session is terminated.

<literal>LOCK INSTANCE FOR BACKUP</literal> prevents files from
      being created, renamed, or removed. <literal role="stmt">REPAIR
      TABLE</literal> <literal role="stmt">TRUNCATE TABLE</literal>,
      <literal role="stmt">OPTIMIZE TABLE</literal>, and account
      management statements are blocked. See
      <xref linkend="account-management-statements" />. Operations that modify
      <literal>InnoDB</literal> files that are not recorded in the
      <literal>InnoDB</literal> redo log are also blocked.

<literal>LOCK INSTANCE FOR BACKUP</literal> permits DDL operations
      that only affect user-created temporary tables. In effect, files
      that belong to user-created temporary tables can be created,
      renamed, or removed while a backup lock is held. Creation of
      binary log files is also permitted.

A backup lock acquired by <literal>LOCK INSTANCE FOR
      BACKUP</literal> is independent of transactional locks and locks
      taken by
      <literal condition="flush-tables-with-read-lock-with-list" role="stmt">FLUSH
      TABLES <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> [,
      <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable>] ... WITH READ LOCK</literal>,
      and the following sequences of statements are permitted:

The <literal role="sysvar">lock_wait_timeout</literal> setting
      defines the amount of time that a <literal>LOCK INSTANCE FOR
      BACKUP</literal> statement waits to acquire a lock before giving
      up.

syntax.programlisting:
>
LOCK INSTANCE FOR BACKUP

UNLOCK INSTANCE

description.para:
MySQL enables client sessions to acquire table locks explicitly
      for the purpose of cooperating with other sessions for access to
      tables, or to prevent other sessions from modifying tables during
      periods when a session requires exclusive access to them. A
      session can acquire or release locks only for itself. One session
      cannot acquire locks for another session or release locks held by
      another session.

Locks may be used to emulate transactions or to get more speed
      when updating tables. This is explained in more detail in
      <xref linkend="lock-tables-restrictions" />.

<literal role="stmt">LOCK TABLES</literal> explicitly acquires
      table locks for the current client session. Table locks can be
      acquired for base tables or views. You must have the
      <literal role="priv">LOCK TABLES</literal> privilege, and the
      <literal role="priv">SELECT</literal> privilege for each object to
      be locked.

For view locking, <literal role="stmt">LOCK TABLES</literal> adds
      all base tables used in the view to the set of tables to be locked
      and locks them automatically. If you lock a table explicitly with
      <literal role="stmt">LOCK TABLES</literal>, any tables used in
      triggers are also locked implicitly, as described in
      <xref linkend="lock-tables-and-triggers" />.

If you lock a table explicitly with <literal role="stmt">LOCK
      TABLES</literal>, any tables related by a foreign key constraint
      are opened and locked implicitly. For foreign key checks, a shared
      read-only lock (<literal condition="lock-tables" role="stmt">LOCK
      TABLES READ</literal>) is taken on related tables. For cascading
      updates, a shared-nothing write lock
      (<literal condition="lock-tables" role="stmt">LOCK TABLES
      WRITE</literal>) is taken on related tables that are involved in
      the operation.

<literal condition="lock-tables" role="stmt">UNLOCK
      TABLES</literal> explicitly releases any table locks held by the
      current session. <literal role="stmt">LOCK TABLES</literal>
      implicitly releases any table locks held by the current session
      before acquiring new locks.

Another use for
      <literal condition="lock-tables" role="stmt">UNLOCK
      TABLES</literal> is to release the global read lock acquired with
      the <literal role="stmt">FLUSH TABLES WITH READ LOCK</literal>
      statement, which enables you to lock all tables in all databases.
      See <xref linkend="flush" />. (This is a very convenient way to get
      backups if you have a file system such as Veritas that can take
      snapshots in time.)

syntax.programlisting:
>
LOCK TABLES
    <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> [[AS] <replaceable>alias</replaceable>] <replaceable>lock_type</replaceable>
    [, <replaceable>tbl_name</replaceable> [[AS] <replaceable>alias</replaceable>] <replaceable>lock_type</replaceable>] ...

<replaceable>lock_type</replaceable>: {
    READ [LOCAL]
  | [LOW_PRIORITY] WRITE
}

UNLOCK TABLES

description.para:
This statement specifies
      <link linkend="glos_transaction">transaction</link>
      characteristics. It takes a list of one or more characteristic
      values separated by commas. Each characteristic value sets the
      transaction <link linkend="glos_isolation_level">isolation
      level</link> or access mode. The isolation level is used for
      operations on <literal role="se">InnoDB</literal> tables. The
      access mode specifies whether transactions operate in read/write
      or read-only mode.

In addition, <literal role="stmt">SET TRANSACTION</literal> can
      include an optional <literal>GLOBAL</literal> or
      <literal>SESSION</literal> keyword to indicate the scope of the
      statement.

For <literal condition="xa-statements" role="stmt">XA
        START</literal>, the <literal>JOIN</literal> and
        <literal>RESUME</literal> clauses are recognized but have no
        effect.

For <literal condition="xa-statements" role="stmt">XA
        END</literal> the <literal>SUSPEND [FOR MIGRATE]</literal>
        clause is recognized but has no effect.

Each XA statement begins with the <literal>XA</literal> keyword,
        and most of them require an <replaceable>xid</replaceable>
        value. An <replaceable>xid</replaceable> is an XA transaction
        identifier. It indicates which transaction the statement applies
        to. <replaceable>xid</replaceable> values are supplied by the
        client, or generated by the MySQL server. An
        <replaceable>xid</replaceable> value has from one to three
        parts:

description.programlisting:
>
<replaceable>xid</replaceable>: <replaceable>gtrid</replaceable> [, <replaceable>bqual</replaceable> [, <replaceable>formatID</replaceable> ]]

description.para:
<replaceable>gtrid</replaceable> is a global transaction
        identifier, <replaceable>bqual</replaceable> is a branch
        qualifier, and <replaceable>formatID</replaceable> is a number
        that identifies the format used by the
        <replaceable>gtrid</replaceable> and
        <replaceable>bqual</replaceable> values. As indicated by the
        syntax, <replaceable>bqual</replaceable> and
        <replaceable>formatID</replaceable> are optional. The default
        <replaceable>bqual</replaceable> value is <literal>''</literal>
        if not given. The default <replaceable>formatID</replaceable>
        value is 1 if not given.

<replaceable>gtrid</replaceable> and
        <replaceable>bqual</replaceable> must be string literals, each
        up to 64 bytes (not characters) long.
        <replaceable>gtrid</replaceable> and
        <replaceable>bqual</replaceable> can be specified in several
        ways. You can use a quoted string (<literal>'ab'</literal>), hex
        string (<literal>X'6162'</literal>, <literal>0x6162</literal>),
        or bit value
        (<literal>b'<replaceable>nnnn</replaceable>'</literal>).
<replaceable>formatID</replaceable> is an unsigned integer.

The <replaceable>gtrid</replaceable> and
        <replaceable>bqual</replaceable> values are interpreted in bytes
        by the MySQL server's underlying XA support routines. However,
        while an SQL statement containing an XA statement is being
        parsed, the server works with some specific character set. To be
        safe, write <replaceable>gtrid</replaceable> and
        <replaceable>bqual</replaceable> as hex strings.

<replaceable>xid</replaceable> values typically are generated by
        the Transaction Manager. Values generated by one TM must be
        different from values generated by other TMs. A given TM must be
        able to recognize its own <replaceable>xid</replaceable> values
        in a list of values returned by the
        <literal condition="xa-statements" role="stmt">XA
        RECOVER</literal> statement.

<literal condition="xa-statements" role="stmt">XA START
        <replaceable>xid</replaceable></literal> starts an XA
        transaction with the given <replaceable>xid</replaceable> value.
        Each XA transaction must have a unique
        <replaceable>xid</replaceable> value, so the value must not
        currently be used by another XA transaction. Uniqueness is
        assessed using the <replaceable>gtrid</replaceable> and
        <replaceable>bqual</replaceable> values. All following XA
        statements for the XA transaction must be specified using the
        same <replaceable>xid</replaceable> value as that given in the
        <literal condition="xa-statements" role="stmt">XA
        START</literal> statement. If you use any of those statements
        but specify an <replaceable>xid</replaceable> value that does
        not correspond to some existing XA transaction, an error occurs.

One or more XA transactions can be part of the same global
        transaction. All XA transactions within a given global
        transaction must use the same <replaceable>gtrid</replaceable>
        value in the <replaceable>xid</replaceable> value. For this
        reason, <replaceable>gtrid</replaceable> values must be globally
        unique so that there is no ambiguity about which global
        transaction a given XA transaction is part of. The
        <replaceable>bqual</replaceable> part of the
        <replaceable>xid</replaceable> value must be different for each
        XA transaction within a global transaction. (The requirement
        that <replaceable>bqual</replaceable> values be different is a
        limitation of the current MySQL XA implementation. It is not
        part of the XA specification.)

The <literal condition="xa-statements" role="stmt">XA
        RECOVER</literal> statement returns information for those XA
        transactions on the MySQL server that are in the
        <literal>PREPARED</literal> state. (See
        <xref linkend="xa-states" />.) The output includes a row for each
        such XA transaction on the server, regardless of which client
        started it.

<literal condition="xa-statements" role="stmt">XA
        RECOVER</literal> requires the
        <literal role="priv">XA_RECOVER_ADMIN</literal> privilege. This
        privilege requirement prevents users from discovering the XID
        values for outstanding prepared XA transactions other than their
        own. It does not affect normal commit or rollback of an XA
        transaction because the user who started it knows its XID.

<literal condition="xa-statements" role="stmt">XA
        RECOVER</literal> output rows look like this (for an example
        <replaceable>xid</replaceable> value consisting of the parts
        <literal>'abc'</literal>, <literal>'def'</literal>, and
        <literal>7</literal>):
The output columns have the following meanings:

itemizedlist.para:
<literal>formatID</literal> is the
            <replaceable>formatID</replaceable> part of the transaction
            <replaceable>xid</replaceable>

<literal>gtrid_length</literal> is the length in bytes of
            the <replaceable>gtrid</replaceable> part of the
            <replaceable>xid</replaceable>

<literal>bqual_length</literal> is the length in bytes of
            the <replaceable>bqual</replaceable> part of the
            <replaceable>xid</replaceable>

<literal>data</literal> is the concatenation of the
            <replaceable>gtrid</replaceable> and
            <replaceable>bqual</replaceable> parts of the
            <replaceable>xid</replaceable>

description.para:
XID values may contain nonprintable characters.
        <literal condition="xa-statements" role="stmt">XA
        RECOVER</literal> permits an optional <literal>CONVERT
        XID</literal> clause so that clients can request XID values in
        hexadecimal.

syntax.programlisting:
>
XA {START|BEGIN} <replaceable>xid</replaceable> [JOIN|RESUME]

XA END <replaceable>xid</replaceable> [SUSPEND [FOR MIGRATE]]

XA PREPARE <replaceable>xid</replaceable>

XA COMMIT <replaceable>xid</replaceable> [ONE PHASE]

XA ROLLBACK <replaceable>xid</replaceable>

XA RECOVER [CONVERT XID]

description.para:
The <literal role="stmt">DESCRIBE</literal> and
      <literal role="stmt">EXPLAIN</literal> statements are synonyms. In
      practice, the <literal role="stmt">DESCRIBE</literal> keyword is
      more often used to obtain information about table structure,
      whereas <literal role="stmt">EXPLAIN</literal> is used to obtain a
      query execution plan (that is, an explanation of how MySQL would
      execute a query).

The <literal role="stmt">HELP</literal> statement returns online
      information from the MySQL Reference Manual. Its proper operation
      requires that the help tables in the <literal>mysql</literal>
      database be initialized with help topic information (see
      <xref linkend="server-side-help-support" />).

The <literal role="stmt">HELP</literal> statement searches the
      help tables for the given search string and displays the result of
      the search. The search string is not case-sensitive.

The search string can contain the wildcard characters
      <literal>%</literal> and <literal>_</literal>. These have the same
      meaning as for pattern-matching operations performed with the
      <literal role="op">LIKE</literal> operator. For example,
      <literal>HELP 'rep%'</literal> returns a list of topics that begin
      with <literal>rep</literal>.

The <literal role="stmt">USE</literal> statement tells MySQL to
      use the named database as the default (current) database for
      subsequent statements. This statement requires some privilege for
      the database or some object within it.

      session or another <literal role="stmt">USE</literal> statement is
      issued:

The database name must be specified on a single line. Newlines in
      database names are not supported.
